Chapter 1

--- Document Chunk 248 ---

--- Document Chunk 249 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 250 ---
1.3 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 251 ---
1.3.1.1 Train control is an important part of any railway operations management system. In the 

--- Document Chunk 252 ---
past a number of different Automatic Train Control (ATC) systems have evolved in 

--- Document Chunk 253 ---
different countries at different times. These systems are incompatible and not 

--- Document Chunk 254 ---
interoperable with each other. Only a few of these systems are used in more than one 

--- Document Chunk 255 ---
country, and even in those cases there have been differences in detailed development 

--- Document Chunk 256 ---
which have resulted in incompatible and not interoperable versions. 

--- Document Chunk 257 ---
1.3.1.2 Many railways anticipate a significant increase in density of train traffic and are rethinking 

--- Document Chunk 258 ---
their infrastructure strategy, to accommodate high levels of traffic, in which ATC systems 

--- Document Chunk 259 ---
play an important part. Also many railways would like to introduce standardised systems 

--- Document Chunk 260 ---
to reduce system costs. In order to establish international standardisation of ATC 

--- Document Chunk 261 ---
systems, the following document specifies the European Rail Traffic Management 

--- Document Chunk 262 ---
System/European Train Control System (ERTMS/ETCS). 

--- Document Chunk 263 ---
1.4 Advantages of an International Interoperable System 

--- Document Chunk 264 ---
1.4.1.1 The advantages expected by the railways can be summarised as: 

--- Document Chunk 265 ---
• Cross border interoperability. 

--- Document Chunk 266 ---
• Improvement of the safety of national and international train traffic. 

--- Document Chunk 267 ---
• Improvement of international passengers and freight train traffic management.  

--- Document Chunk 268 ---
• Shorter headway on heavily trafficked lines, by driving on moving block, enabling 

--- Document Chunk 269 ---
exploitation of maximum track capacity. 

--- Document Chunk 270 ---
• The possibility of step-by-step introduction of the new technology. 

--- Document Chunk 271 ---
• Enabling Pan-European competition between the manufacturers of ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 272 ---
components. Strengthening the position of the European railway industry on the 

--- Document Chunk 273 ---
world market. 

--- Document Chunk 274 ---
• Enabling preconditions for future harmonisation in other areas of rail traffic 

--- Document Chunk 275 ---
management. 

--- Document Chunk 276 ---
1.5 About this Document 

--- Document Chunk 277 ---
1.5.1.1 The purpose of this document is to specify the unified European Train Control System 

--- Document Chunk 278 ---
(ETCS) from a technical point of view. 

--- Document Chunk 279 ---
1.5.1.2 Some parts of the system are only specified to allow a migration from existing train 

--- Document Chunk 280 ---
control systems to ETCS (e.g. STM’s) over a tra nsition period. They might be removed 

--- Document Chunk 281 ---
in a future edition of the standard. 

--- Document Chunk 282 ---
1.5.1.3 To reach technical interoperability it is necessary not only that telegrams are generated 

--- Document Chunk 283 ---
and understood according to well specified rules but also that a train respectively 

--- Document Chunk 284 ---
trackside equipment reacts in a uniform way to information received. Technical 

--- Document Chunk 285 ---
interoperability requires specifications of a detailed level. 

--- Document Chunk 286 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 287 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 288 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 289 ---
SUBSET-026-1 

--- Document Chunk 290 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 291 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 292 ---
System Requirements Specification  

--- Document Chunk 293 ---
Chapter 1  

--- Document Chunk 294 ---
Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 295 ---
Page 7/9 

--- Document Chunk 296 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 297 ---
1.5.1.4 For operational interoperability it is necessary to add operating rules, engineering 

--- Document Chunk 298 ---
standards etc. to the system design. Reaching operational interoperability is outside the 

--- Document Chunk 299 ---
scope of the SRS. 

--- Document Chunk 300 ---
1.6 How to Read and Use the SRS 

--- Document Chunk 301 ---
1.6.1.1 The SRS covers 9 chapters, which are briefly described in the section following this 

--- Document Chunk 302 ---
introduction. 

--- Document Chunk 303 ---
1.6.1.2 All readers may need to refer to the Glossary of terms and abbreviations (SUBSET-023). 

--- Document Chunk 304 ---
1.7 Requirements 

--- Document Chunk 305 ---
1.7.1.1 This specification defines the functions that allow reaching the technical interoperability. 

--- Document Chunk 306 ---
This is materialised through numbered clauses which are formally identified as 

--- Document Chunk 307 ---
containing ERTMS/ETCS on -board and/or ERTM S/ETCS trackside requirements (see 

--- Document Chunk 308 ---
details in chapter 9). 

--- Document Chunk 309 ---
1.7.1.2 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall implement all its allocated requirements, 

--- Document Chunk 310 ---
with the only exceptions and conditions explicitly stated in the Control -Command and 

--- Document Chunk 311 ---
Signalling TSI and in this SRS. 

--- Document Chunk 312 ---
1.7.1.3 For ERTMS/ETCS trackside the implementation of functions has to be defined according 

--- Document Chunk 313 ---
to the characteristics of the specific lines and the related operational needs. In any case, 

--- Document Chunk 314 ---
the requirements of this SRS , which are allocated to the trackside and  related to the 

--- Document Chunk 315 ---
implemented functions, shall be respected. 

--- Document Chunk 316 ---
1.7.1.4 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 317 ---
1.7.1.5 Not specified requirements and solutions shall only be permitted as long as they do not 

--- Document Chunk 318 ---
generate any interoperability problems. 

--- Document Chunk 319 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 320 ---
1.8 Contents of the SRS 

--- Document Chunk 321 ---
1.8.1.1 The SRS defines the system requi rements for the European Train Control System 

--- Document Chunk 322 ---
(ETCS) of ERTMS. 

--- Document Chunk 323 ---
1.8.1.2 This sub-section is intended to give a rough overview of the contents of each chapter 

--- Document Chunk 324 ---
within the SRS so that readers interested only in specialised subjects can easily find the 

--- Document Chunk 325 ---
relevant chapters. 

--- Document Chunk 326 ---
1.8.2 Chapter 1: Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 327 ---
1.8.2.1 Chapter 1 (this chapter) gives a general introduction to the intention and structure of the 

--- Document Chunk 328 ---
SRS, including a brief overview of the contents of each chapter. 

--- Document Chunk 329 ---
1.8.3 Chapter 2: Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 330 ---
1.8.3.1 Chapter 2 gives an overview of the ERTMS/ETCS system structure. 

--- Document Chunk 331 ---
1.8.3.2 Chapter 2 also contains a description of the basic application levels. 

--- Document Chunk 332 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 333 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 334 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 335 ---
SUBSET-026-1 

--- Document Chunk 336 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 337 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 338 ---
System Requirements Specification  

--- Document Chunk 339 ---
Chapter 1  

--- Document Chunk 340 ---
Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 341 ---
Page 8/9 

--- Document Chunk 342 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 343 ---
1.8.3.3 Chapter 2 does not contain technical requirements. 

--- Document Chunk 344 ---
1.8.4 Chapter 3: Principles 

--- Document Chunk 345 ---
1.8.4.1 Chapter 3 specifies the system principles of ETCS/ERTMS. These principles apply to 

--- Document Chunk 346 ---
onboard and trackside subsystems. 

--- Document Chunk 347 ---
1.8.4.2 The principles define the behaviour of the system in general and functional terms. 

--- Document Chunk 348 ---
1.8.5 Chapter 4: Modes and Transitions 

--- Document Chunk 349 ---
1.8.5.1.1 Chapter 4 defines the modes of the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment and all transitions 

--- Document Chunk 350 ---
between modes. 

--- Document Chunk 351 ---
1.8.6 Chapter 5: Procedures 

--- Document Chunk 352 ---
1.8.6.1 Chapter 5 defines the dynamic behaviour of procedures that are necessary for 

--- Document Chunk 353 ---
interoperability. Procedures are presented by a state transition chart and a 

--- Document Chunk 354 ---
corresponding table, where all elements (States, events, transitions) of the cha rt are 

--- Document Chunk 355 ---
defined. The description of the procedures shows all states of the ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 356 ---
onboard unit and the conditions that must be fulfilled to switch from one state to another. 

--- Document Chunk 357 ---
1.8.7 Chapter 6: Management of older System Versions 

--- Document Chunk 358 ---
1.8.7.1.1 Chapter 6 defines the envelope o f legally operated system versions and list s the 

--- Document Chunk 359 ---
exceptions that shall apply by derogation to the requirements listed in the other chapters 

--- Document Chunk 360 ---
of the SRS, when an older ERTMS/ETCS system version is used  by the trackside 

--- Document Chunk 361 ---
subsystem. 

--- Document Chunk 362 ---
1.8.8 Chapter 7: ERTMS/ETCS Language 

--- Document Chunk 363 ---
1.8.8.1 Chapter 7 defines and describes the necessary variables to be used for the data flow 

--- Document Chunk 364 ---
over the air gap between track and train. The grouping of these into packets is described. 

--- Document Chunk 365 ---
The format of messages is given in Chapter 8. 

--- Document Chunk 366 ---
1.8.9 Chapter 8: Messages 

--- Document Chunk 367 ---
1.8.9.1 Chapter 8 defines the application protocol (format and content of messages, logical 

--- Document Chunk 368 ---
sequence for radio) necessary to achieve technical interoperability. 

--- Document Chunk 369 ---
1.8.9.2 The scope of this chapter is limited to the application protoc ol and the content of 

--- Document Chunk 370 ---
messages. 

--- Document Chunk 371 ---
1.8.10 Chapter 9: Classification of the SRS clauses 

--- Document Chunk 372 ---
1.8.10.1 Chapter 9 encloses a classification into categories of all the clauses in the chapters 1 to 

--- Document Chunk 373 ---
8 of the SRS. 

--- Document Chunk 374 ---
1.8.10.2 In particular to assess properly the compliance of an ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 375 ---
with the SRS, it identif ies which clauses contain requirements allocated to the 

--- Document Chunk 376 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment and conversely which ones do not, either because 

--- Document Chunk 377 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 378 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 379 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 380 ---
SUBSET-026-1 

--- Document Chunk 381 ---

System Requirements Specification  

--- Document Chunk 384 ---
Chapter 1  

--- Document Chunk 385 ---
Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 386 ---
Page 9/9 

--- Document Chunk 387 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 388 ---
they contain requirements allocated to the ERTMS/ETCS trackside only or because they 

--- Document Chunk 389 ---
are of another type. 

--- Document Chunk 390 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 391 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 665 ---
2.3 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 666 ---
2.3.1 Scope and purpose 

--- Document Chunk 667 ---
2.3.1.1 The present chapter gives the basic description of the ERTMS/ETCS system proposed 

--- Document Chunk 668 ---
to achieve technical interoperability. 

--- Document Chunk 669 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 670 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 671 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 672 ---
SUBSET-026-2 

--- Document Chunk 673 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 674 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 675 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 676 ---
Chapter 2 

--- Document Chunk 677 ---
Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 678 ---
Page 7/25 

--- Document Chunk 679 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 680 ---
2.4 System structure 

--- Document Chunk 681 ---
2.4.1.1 Due to the nature of the req uired functions, the ERTMS/ETCS system will have to be 

--- Document Chunk 682 ---
partly on the trackside and partly on board the trains. 

--- Document Chunk 683 ---
2.4.1.2 This defines two subsystems, the on-board subsystem and the trackside subsystem. 

--- Document Chunk 684 ---
2.4.1.3 The environment of ERTMS/ETCS system is composed of: 

--- Document Chunk 685 ---
a) the train  with optionally a Train Integrity Monitoring System , which will then be 

--- Document Chunk 686 ---
considered in the train interface specification; 

--- Document Chunk 687 ---
b) the driver, which will then be considered via the driver interface specification; 

--- Document Chunk 688 ---
c) other onboard interfaces (see architecture drawing in 2.5.3); 

--- Document Chunk 689 ---
d) external trackside systems (interlockings, control centres, etc.), for which no 

--- Document Chunk 690 ---
interoperability requirement will be established. 

--- Document Chunk 691 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 692 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 693 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 694 ---
SUBSET-026-2 

--- Document Chunk 695 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 696 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 697 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 698 ---
Chapter 2 

--- Document Chunk 699 ---
Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 700 ---
Page 8/25 

--- Document Chunk 701 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 702 ---
2.5 Subsystems 

--- Document Chunk 703 ---
2.5.1 Trackside subsystem 

--- Document Chunk 704 ---
2.5.1.1 Depending on the application level (see further sections), the trackside subsystem can 

--- Document Chunk 705 ---
be composed of: 

--- Document Chunk 706 ---
a) balise 

--- Document Chunk 707 ---
b) lineside electronic unit 

--- Document Chunk 708 ---
c) the radio communication network(s) (FRMCS and/or GSM-R) 

--- Document Chunk 709 ---
d) the Radio Block Centre (RBC) 

--- Document Chunk 710 ---
e) Euroloop 

--- Document Chunk 711 ---
f) Radio infill unit 

--- Document Chunk 712 ---
g) Key Management Centre (KMC) 

--- Document Chunk 713 ---
h) Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) 

--- Document Chunk 714 ---
2.5.1.2 Balise 

--- Document Chunk 715 ---
2.5.1.2.1 The balise is a transmission device that can send telegrams to the on-board subsystem. 

--- Document Chunk 716 ---
2.5.1.2.2 The balise is based on the existing Eurobalise specifications. These documents are 

--- Document Chunk 717 ---
included in the frame of the ERTMS/ETCS specifications. 

--- Document Chunk 718 ---
2.5.1.2.3 The balises provides the up-link, i. e. the possibility to send messages from trackside to 

--- Document Chunk 719 ---
the on-board subsystem. 

--- Document Chunk 720 ---
2.5.1.2.4 The balises can provide fixed messages or, when connected to a lineside electronic unit, 

--- Document Chunk 721 ---
messages that can be changed. 

--- Document Chunk 722 ---
2.5.1.2.5 The balises will be organised in groups, each balise transmitting a telegram and the 

--- Document Chunk 723 ---
combination of all telegrams defining the message sent by the balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 724 ---
2.5.1.3 Lineside electronic unit 

--- Document Chunk 725 ---
2.5.1.3.1 The lineside electronic units are electronic devices, that generate telegrams to be sent 

--- Document Chunk 726 ---
by balises, on basis of information received from external trackside systems. 

--- Document Chunk 727 ---
2.5.1.4 Trackside radio communication network(s) (FRMCS and/or GSM-R) 

--- Document Chunk 728 ---
2.5.1.4.1 The GSM -R radio communication network is used for the bi -directional exchange of 

--- Document Chunk 729 ---
messages between on-board subsystems and RBC or radio infill units. 

--- Document Chunk 730 ---
2.5.1.4.2 The FRMCS radio communication network is used for the bi -directional exchange of 

--- Document Chunk 731 ---
messages between on-board subsystems and RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 732 ---
2.5.1.5 RBC 

--- Document Chunk 733 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 734 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 735 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 736 ---
SUBSET-026-2 

--- Document Chunk 737 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 738 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 739 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 740 ---
Chapter 2 

--- Document Chunk 741 ---
Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 742 ---
Page 9/25 

--- Document Chunk 743 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 744 ---
2.5.1.5.1 The RBC is a computer-based system that elaborates messages to be sent to the train 

--- Document Chunk 745 ---
on basis of information received from external trackside systems and on basis of 

--- Document Chunk 746 ---
information exchanged with the on-board subsystems. 

--- Document Chunk 747 ---
2.5.1.5.2 The main objective of these messages is to provide movement authorities to allow the 

--- Document Chunk 748 ---
safe movement of trains on the Railway infrastructure area under the responsibility of the 

--- Document Chunk 749 ---
RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 750 ---
2.5.1.5.3 The interoperability requirements for the RBC are mainly related to the data exchange 

--- Document Chunk 751 ---
between the RBC and the on-board subsystem. 

--- Document Chunk 752 ---
2.5.1.5.4 The RBC can be interfaced to the FRMCS and/or GSM-R radio communication 

--- Document Chunk 753 ---
network(s). 

--- Document Chunk 754 ---
2.5.1.6 Euroloop 

--- Document Chunk 755 ---
2.5.1.6.1 The Euroloop subsystem operates on Level 1 lines, providing signalling information in 

--- Document Chunk 756 ---
advance as regard to the next main signal in the train running direction. 

--- Document Chunk 757 ---
2.5.1.6.2 The Euroloop subsystem is composed of an on -board functionality and by one or more 

--- Document Chunk 758 ---
trackside parts.  

--- Document Chunk 759 ---
2.5.1.7 Radio infill Unit 

--- Document Chunk 760 ---
2.5.1.7.1 The RADIO INFILL subsystem operates on Level 1 lines, providing signalling information 

--- Document Chunk 761 ---
in advance as regard to the next main signal in the train running direction. 

--- Document Chunk 762 ---
2.5.1.7.2 The RADIO INFILL subsystem is composed of an on -board functionality and by one or 

--- Document Chunk 763 ---
more trackside parts (named RADIO INFILL Unit). 

--- Document Chunk 764 ---
2.5.1.8 KMC 

--- Document Chunk 765 ---
2.5.1.8.1 The role of the KMC is to manage the cryptographic keys, which are used to secure the 

--- Document Chunk 766 ---
EURORADIO communications between the ERTMS/ETCS entities (ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 767 ---
board equipments, RBCs and RIUs). 

--- Document Chunk 768 ---
2.5.1.9 PKI 

--- Document Chunk 769 ---
2.5.1.9.1 The role of the PKI is to manage and distribute digital certificates, so as to allow a secure 

--- Document Chunk 770 ---
on-line distribution  of cryptographic keys between KMCs and from a KMC  to the 

--- Document Chunk 771 ---
ERTMS/ETCS entities (ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipments, RBCs and RIUs). 

--- Document Chunk 772 ---
2.5.2 On-board subsystem 

--- Document Chunk 773 ---
2.5.2.1 The on-board subsystem can be composed of: 

--- Document Chunk 774 ---
a) the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment; 

--- Document Chunk 775 ---
b) the on-board part of the FRMCS and/or GSM-R radio system(s); 

--- Document Chunk 776 ---
c) the ERTMS/ATO on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 777 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 778 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 779 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 780 ---
SUBSET-026-2 

--- Document Chunk 781 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 782 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 783 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 784 ---
Chapter 2 

--- Document Chunk 785 ---
Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 786 ---
Page 10/25 

--- Document Chunk 787 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 788 ---
2.5.2.2 ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 789 ---
2.5.2.2.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment is a computer-based system that supervises the 

--- Document Chunk 790 ---
movement of the train to which it belongs, on basis of information exchanged with the 

--- Document Chunk 791 ---
trackside subsystem. 

--- Document Chunk 792 ---
2.5.2.2.2 The interoperability requirements for the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment are related 

--- Document Chunk 793 ---
to the functionality and the data exchange between the trackside subsystems and the 

--- Document Chunk 794 ---
on-board subsystem and to the functional data exchange between the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 795 ---
subsystem and: 

--- Document Chunk 796 ---
a) the driver; 

--- Document Chunk 797 ---
b) the train; 

--- Document Chunk 798 ---
c) the onboard part of the existing national train control system(s). 

--- Document Chunk 799 ---
2.5.2.3 Onboard radio communication system(s) (FRMCS and/or GSM-R) 

--- Document Chunk 800 ---
2.5.2.3.1 The GSM-R on-board radio system is used for the bi-directional exchange of messages 

--- Document Chunk 801 ---
between on-board subsystem and RBC or radio infill unit. 

--- Document Chunk 802 ---
2.5.2.3.2 The FRMCS on-board radio system is used for the bi-directional exchange of messages 

--- Document Chunk 803 ---
between on-board subsystem and RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 804 ---
2.5.2.4 ERTMS/ATO on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 805 ---
2.5.2.4.1 The ERTMS/ATO on-board equipment is a computer-based system that can substitute 

--- Document Chunk 806 ---
the driver for acting on the traction/braking of the train, on the basis of information 

--- Document Chunk 807 ---
exchanged with the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment, with the ERTMS/ATO trackside 

--- Document Chunk 808 ---
subsystem and with the train (see SUBSET-125 for details). 

--- Document Chunk 809 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 810 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 811 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 812 ---

--- Document Chunk 938 ---
2.6 Levels and transitions 

--- Document Chunk 939 ---
2.6.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 940 ---
2.6.1.1 The different ERTMS/ETCS application levels (short: levels) are a way to express the 

--- Document Chunk 941 ---
possible operating relationships between track and train. Level definitions are related to 

--- Document Chunk 942 ---
the trackside equipment used, to the way trackside information reaches the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 943 ---
units and to which functions are processed in the trackside and in the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 944 ---
equipment respectively.  

--- Document Chunk 945 ---
2.6.1.2 Different levels have been defined to allow each individual railway administration to 

--- Document Chunk 946 ---
select the appropriate ERTMS/ETCS application trackside, according to their strategies, 

--- Document Chunk 947 ---
to their trackside infrastructure and to the required performance. Furthermore, the 

--- Document Chunk 948 ---
different application levels permit the interfacing of individual signalling systems and train 

--- Document Chunk 949 ---
control systems to ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 950 ---
2.6.1.3 For the purpose of a consistent specification a level 0 has been defined. This level is 

--- Document Chunk 951 ---
used for operation on non-equipped (unfitted) lines or on lines equipped with train control 

--- Document Chunk 952 ---
system(s) but operation under their supervision is currently not possible.  

--- Document Chunk 953 ---
2.6.2 Definitions 

--- Document Chunk 954 ---
2.6.2.1 A train equipped with ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment always co -operates with the 

--- Document Chunk 955 ---
ERTMS/ETCS trackside equipment in a defined ERTMS/ETCS level. 

--- Document Chunk 956 ---
2.6.2.2 All transitions between levels are performed according to well-specified rules. 

--- Document Chunk 957 ---
2.6.2.3 ERTMS/ETCS can be configured to operate in one of the following application levels: 

--- Document Chunk 958 ---
• ERTMS/ETCS Level 0 (train equipped with ERTMS/ETCS operating on a line not 

--- Document Chunk 959 ---
equipped with any train control system  (ERTMS/ETCS or national system ) or on a 

--- Document Chunk 960 ---
line equipped with ERTMS/ETCS and/or national system(s) but operation under their 

--- Document Chunk 961 ---
supervision is currently not possible) 

--- Document Chunk 962 ---
• ERTMS/ETCS Level NTC (train equi pped with ERTMS/ETCS operating on a line 

--- Document Chunk 963 ---
equipped with a national system) 

--- Document Chunk 964 ---
• ERTMS/ETCS Application Level 1 with or without infill transmission (train equipped 

--- Document Chunk 965 ---
with ERTMS/ETCS operating on a line equipped with Eurobalises and optionally 

--- Document Chunk 966 ---
Euroloop or Radio infill) 

--- Document Chunk 967 ---
• ERTMS/ETCS Application Level 2 (train equipped with ERTMS/ETCS operating on a 

--- Document Chunk 968 ---
line controlled by a Radio Block Centre and equipped with Eurobalises and Euroradio) 

--- Document Chunk 969 ---
with train detection and train separation performed by the Radio Block Centre based 

--- Document Chunk 970 ---
on information received from the train and/or by  other trackside equipment outside 

--- Document Chunk 971 ---
the scope of ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 972 ---
• Intentionally deleted 

--- Document Chunk 973 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 974 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 975 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 976 ---
SUBSET-026-2 

--- Document Chunk 977 ---
4.0.0

System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 980 ---
Chapter 2 

--- Document Chunk 981 ---
Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 982 ---
Page 13/25 

--- Document Chunk 983 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 984 ---
2.6.2.4 It is possible to superimpose several application levels in parallel on the same track, for 

--- Document Chunk 985 ---
example parallel operation of a line with a national system and with ERTMS/ETCS level 

--- Document Chunk 986 ---
1 or 2. Other examples might be a station which is shared by trains arriving over level 1 

--- Document Chunk 987 ---
and level 2 lines (junctions). 

--- Document Chunk 988 ---
2.6.2.5 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 989 ---
2.6.2.6 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 990 ---
2.6.2.7 It is possible to transmit information not intended for ERTMS/ETCS but for other systems 

--- Document Chunk 991 ---
over the ERTMS/ETCS transmission channels. This information is not used  by 

--- Document Chunk 992 ---
ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 993 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 994 ---

--- Document Chunk 1004 ---
2.6.3 ERTMS/ETCS Application Level 0 

--- Document Chunk 1005 ---
2.6.3.1 General description 

--- Document Chunk 1006 ---
2.6.3.1.1 Level 0 covers operation of ETCS equipped trains on lines not equipped with ETCS or 

--- Document Chunk 1007 ---
national systems or on lines where trackside ERTMS/ETCS infrastructure and/or national 

--- Document Chunk 1008 ---
systems may exist but operation under their supervision is currently not possible (e.g. 

--- Document Chunk 1009 ---
commissioning or on-board/trackside failed components). 

--- Document Chunk 1010 ---
2.6.3.1.2 In Level 0 it is authorized to operate trains without any train control system and therefore 

--- Document Chunk 1011 ---
line side optical signals or other means of signalling are used to give movement 

--- Document Chunk 1012 ---
authorities to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 1013 ---
2.6.3.1.3 ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment provides no supervision except of the  maximum 

--- Document Chunk 1014 ---
design speed of a train and maximum speed permitted in unfitted areas. 

--- Document Chunk 1015 ---
2.6.3.1.4 Train detection and train separation are performed by the trackside equipment of the 

--- Document Chunk 1016 ---
underlying signalling system (interlocking, track circuits etc.) and are outside the scope 

--- Document Chunk 1017 ---
of ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 1018 ---
2.6.3.1.5 Level 0 uses no track-train transmission except Eurobalises to announce/command level 

--- Document Chunk 1019 ---
transitions. Eurobalises therefore still have to be read. No balise data except certain 

--- Document Chunk 1020 ---
special commands are interpreted. 

--- Document Chunk 1021 ---
2.6.3.1.6 No supervisory information is indicated on the DMI except the train speed. Train data 

--- Document Chunk 1022 ---
has to be entered in order not to have to stop a train at a level transition to ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 1023 ---
equipped area and to supervise maximum train speed. 

--- Document Chunk 1024 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1025 ---
Figure 2: ERTMS/ETCS Application Level 0 

--- Document Chunk 1026 ---
2.6.3.2 Summary of characteristics of Application Level 0 

--- Document Chunk 1027 ---
2.6.3.2.1 Trackside equipment:  

--- Document Chunk 1028 ---
• No ERTMS/ETCS trackside equipment is used except for Eurobalises to announce 

--- Document Chunk 1029 ---
level transitions and other specific commands. 

--- Document Chunk 1030 ---
ETCS

--- Document Chunk 1031 ---
end of track segment

--- Document Chunk 1032 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 1033 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1034 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1035 ---
SUBSET-026-2

System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 1039 ---
Chapter 2 

--- Document Chunk 1040 ---
Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 1041 ---
Page 15/25 

--- Document Chunk 1042 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1043 ---
2.6.3.2.2 Main ERTMS/ETCS trackside functions: 

--- Document Chunk 1044 ---
• None. 

--- Document Chunk 1045 ---
2.6.3.2.3 On-board equipment: 

--- Document Chunk 1046 ---
• ERTMS/ETCS Onboard equipment with Eurobalise transmission. 

--- Document Chunk 1047 ---
2.6.3.2.4 Main ERTMS/ETCS on-board functions: 

--- Document Chunk 1048 ---
• Supervision of maximum train speed. 

--- Document Chunk 1049 ---
• Supervision of maximum speed permitted in an unfitted area. 

--- Document Chunk 1050 ---
• Reading of Eurobalises to detect level transitions and certain special commands. All 

--- Document Chunk 1051 ---
other messages are rejected. 

--- Document Chunk 1052 ---
• No cab signalling. 

--- Document Chunk 1053 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 1064 ---
2.6.4 ERTMS/ETCS Application Level NTC 

--- Document Chunk 1065 ---
2.6.4.1 General description 

--- Document Chunk 1066 ---
2.6.4.1.1 Level NTC is used to run ERTMS/ETCS equipped trains on lines equipped with national 

--- Document Chunk 1067 ---
train control and speed supervision systems. 

--- Document Chunk 1068 ---
2.6.4.1.2 Train control information generated trackside by the national train contro l system is 

--- Document Chunk 1069 ---
transmitted to the train via the communication channels of the underlying national 

--- Document Chunk 1070 ---
system. 

--- Document Chunk 1071 ---
2.6.4.1.3 Note: Lineside optical signals might be necessary or not, depending on the performance 

--- Document Chunk 1072 ---
and functionality of the underlying systems. 

--- Document Chunk 1073 ---
2.6.4.1.4 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 1074 ---
2.6.4.1.5 The achievable level of supervision is similar to the one provided by the underlying 

--- Document Chunk 1075 ---
national systems. 

--- Document Chunk 1076 ---
2.6.4.1.6 Train detection and train separation are performed by the trackside equipment of the 

--- Document Chunk 1077 ---
underlying signalling system (interlocking, track circuits etc.) a nd are outside the scope 

--- Document Chunk 1078 ---
of ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 1079 ---
2.6.4.1.7 Level NTC uses no ERTMS/ETCS track-train information except to announce/command 

--- Document Chunk 1080 ---
level transitions and specific commands related to balise transmission. Eurobalises 

--- Document Chunk 1081 ---
therefore still have to be read. 

--- Document Chunk 1082 ---
2.6.4.1.8 The information dis played to the driver depends on the functionality of the underlying 

--- Document Chunk 1083 ---
national system. The active national system is indicated to the driver as part of that 

--- Document Chunk 1084 ---
information. Full train data has to be entered in order not to have to stop a train at a level 

--- Document Chunk 1085 ---
transition position and to supervise maximum train speed. 

--- Document Chunk 1086 ---
2.6.4.1.9 A combination of national systems can be regarded as one NTC level. 

--- Document Chunk 1087 ---
2.6.4.1.10 Depending on the functionality and the configuration of the specific national system 

--- Document Chunk 1088 ---
installed onboard, the ERTMS/ETCS Onboard system may need to be interfaced to it, in 

--- Document Chunk 1089 ---
order to perform the transitions from/to the national system and/or in order to give access 

--- Document Chunk 1090 ---
to ERTMS/ETCS Onboard resources (e.g. DMI). This can be achieved through a device 

--- Document Chunk 1091 ---
called an STM (Specific Transmission Module) using a standardised interface. 

--- Document Chunk 1092 ---
2.6.4.1.11 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 1093 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1094 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 1095 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1096 ---

Optional, 

--- Document Chunk 1110 ---
depending on 

--- Document Chunk 1111 ---
national 

--- Document Chunk 1112 ---
system 

--- Document Chunk 1113 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1114 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1115 ---
Figure 3: ERTMS/ETCS Application Level NTC 

--- Document Chunk 1116 ---
2.6.4.2 Summary of characteristics of Application Level NTC 

--- Document Chunk 1117 ---
2.6.4.2.1 Trackside equipment:  

--- Document Chunk 1118 ---
• Level NTC uses the track -train transmission system from an underlying national 

--- Document Chunk 1119 ---
system, which is not part of ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 1120 ---
• For level transition purposes Eurobalises are used. 

--- Document Chunk 1121 ---
2.6.4.2.2 Main ERTMS/ETCS trackside functions: 

--- Document Chunk 1122 ---
• None. 

--- Document Chunk 1123 ---
2.6.4.2.3 On-board equipment:  

--- Document Chunk 1124 ---
• ERTMS/ETCS Onboard equipment with Eurobalise transmission. 

--- Document Chunk 1125 ---
• Onboard part of the national system. 

--- Document Chunk 1126 ---
2.6.4.2.4 Main ERTMS/ETCS on-board function: 

--- Document Chunk 1127 ---
• No train supervision, it is fully handed over to the national system.  

--- Document Chunk 1128 ---
• Reading of Eurobalises to detect level transitions and certain special commands. All 

--- Document Chunk 1129 ---
other messages are rejected. 

--- Document Chunk 1130 ---
• Management of the national system through  STM, in case the ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 1131 ---
board equipment is interfaced to the national system through an STM. 

--- Document Chunk 1132 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 1133 ---

--- Document Chunk 1142 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1143 ---
• No cab signalling. 

--- Document Chunk 1144 ---
2.6.5 ERTMS/ETCS Application Level 1 

--- Document Chunk 1145 ---
2.6.5.1 General description 

--- Document Chunk 1146 ---
2.6.5.1.1 ERTMS/ETCS Level 1 is a spot transmission based train control system to be used as 

--- Document Chunk 1147 ---
an overlay on an underlying signalling system. 

--- Document Chunk 1148 ---
2.6.5.1.2 Movement authorities are generated trackside and are transmitted to the train via  

--- Document Chunk 1149 ---
Eurobalises. 

--- Document Chunk 1150 ---
2.6.5.1.3 ERTMS/ETCS Level 1 provides a continuous speed supervision system, which also 

--- Document Chunk 1151 ---
protects against overrun of the authority. 

--- Document Chunk 1152 ---
2.6.5.1.4 Train detection and train separation are performed by the trackside equipment of the 

--- Document Chunk 1153 ---
underlying signalling system (interlocking, track circuits etc.) and are outside  the scope 

--- Document Chunk 1154 ---
of ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 1155 ---
2.6.5.1.5 Level 1 is based on Eurobalises as spot transmission devices. 

--- Document Chunk 1156 ---
2.6.5.1.6 The trackside equipment does not know the train to which it sends information. 

--- Document Chunk 1157 ---
2.6.5.1.7 If in level 1 a lineside signal clears, an approaching train can not receive this information 

--- Document Chunk 1158 ---
until it passes the Eurobalise group at that signal. The driver therefore has to observe 

--- Document Chunk 1159 ---
the lineside signal to know when to proceed. The train has then to be permitted to 

--- Document Chunk 1160 ---
approach the stopping location below a maximum permitted release speed. 

--- Document Chunk 1161 ---
2.6.5.1.8 Additional Eurobalises can be placed between distant and main signals to transmit infill 

--- Document Chunk 1162 ---
information, the train will receive new information before reaching the signal.  

--- Document Chunk 1163 ---
2.6.5.1.9 Note: Lineside signals are required in level 1 applications, except if semi-continuous infill 

--- Document Chunk 1164 ---
is provided. 

--- Document Chunk 1165 ---
2.6.5.1.10 Semi-continuous infill can be provided using Euroloop or radio infill. In this case, the on-

--- Document Chunk 1166 ---
board system will be able to show new information to the driver as soon as it is available 

--- Document Chunk 1167 ---
and even at standstill. 

--- Document Chunk 1168 ---
2.6.5.1.11 Euroloop or radio infill can improv e the safety of a level 1 system as they allow the 

--- Document Chunk 1169 ---
operation without release speed. 

--- Document Chunk 1170 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 1171 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1172 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1173 ---

2.6.5.2 Summary of characteristics of Application Level 1 

--- Document Chunk 1210 ---
2.6.5.2.1 Trackside equipment:  

--- Document Chunk 1211 ---
• Eurobalises for spot transmission from track to train. 

--- Document Chunk 1212 ---
• Eurobalises must be able to transmit variable information. 

--- Document Chunk 1213 ---
• Semi continuous infill transmission by using Euroloop or radio infill is optional. 

--- Document Chunk 1214 ---
2.6.5.2.2 Main ERTMS/ETCS trackside function: 

--- Document Chunk 1215 ---
• Determine movement authorities according to the underlying signalling system. 

--- Document Chunk 1216 ---
• Transmit movement authorities and track description data to the train. 

--- Document Chunk 1217 ---
2.6.5.2.3 On-board equipment: 

--- Document Chunk 1218 ---
• ERTMS/ETCS Onboard equipment with Eurobalise transmission and with: 

--- Document Chunk 1219 ---
• Euroloop transmission if infill by Euroloop is required. 

--- Document Chunk 1220 ---
• Radio infill transmission if infill by radio is required. 

--- Document Chunk 1221 ---
• The on-board part of the Radio Communication subsystem, if infill by radio is required 

--- Document Chunk 1222 ---
2.6.5.2.4 Main ERTMS/ETCS on-board function: 

--- Document Chunk 1223 ---
• Reception of movement authority and track description related to the transmitting 

--- Document Chunk 1224 ---
balise. 

--- Document Chunk 1225 ---
• Selection of the most restrictive value of the different speeds p ermitted at each 

--- Document Chunk 1226 ---
location ahead. 

--- Document Chunk 1227 ---
• Calculation of a dynamic speed profile taking into account the train running/braking 

--- Document Chunk 1228 ---
characteristics which are known on-board and the track description data. 

--- Document Chunk 1229 ---
• Comparison of the train speed with the permitted speed and commanding of the brake 

--- Document Chunk 1230 ---
application if necessary. 

--- Document Chunk 1231 ---
• Cab signalling to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 1232 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 1233 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1234 ---

SUBSET-026-2

--- Document Chunk 1243 ---
2.6.6 ERTMS/ETCS Application Level 2 

--- Document Chunk 1244 ---
2.6.6.1 General description 

--- Document Chunk 1245 ---
2.6.6.1.1 ERTMS/ETCS Level 2 is a radio based train control system which provides full cab 

--- Document Chunk 1246 ---
signalling and does not require lineside signals. 

--- Document Chunk 1247 ---
2.6.6.1.1.1 Note: Lineside signals can still be implemented in ERTMS/ETCS level 2. 

--- Document Chunk 1248 ---
2.6.6.1.2 Movement authorities are generated trackside and are transmitted to the train via 

--- Document Chunk 1249 ---
Euroradio. 

--- Document Chunk 1250 ---
2.6.6.1.3 ERTMS/ETCS Level 2 provides a continuous speed supervision system, which also 

--- Document Chunk 1251 ---
protects against overrun of the authority. 

--- Document Chunk 1252 ---
2.6.6.1.4 Train detection and train separation can be performed by the Radio Block Centre (in co-

--- Document Chunk 1253 ---
operation with the train which sends position reports and train integrity information) 

--- Document Chunk 1254 ---
and/or by other trackside equipment (interlocking, track circuits etc.), outside the scope 

--- Document Chunk 1255 ---
of ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 1256 ---
2.6.6.1.5 Level 2 is based on Euroradio for track to train communication and on Eurobalises as 

--- Document Chunk 1257 ---
spot transmission devices mainly for location referencing. 

--- Document Chunk 1258 ---
2.6.6.1.6 The trackside radio block centre which provides the information to the trains knows each 

--- Document Chunk 1259 ---
ERTMS/ETCS controlled train individually by the ERTMS/ETCS identity of its leading 

--- Document Chunk 1260 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 1261 ---
2.6.6.1.7 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 1262 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 1263 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1264 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1265 ---
SUBSET-026-2

ETCS

Eurobalise

train

integrity

--- Document Chunk 1286 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1287 ---
2.6.6.2 Summary of characteristics of Application Level 2 

--- Document Chunk 1288 ---
2.6.6.2.1 Trackside equipment: 

--- Document Chunk 1289 ---
• Radio block centre with Euroradio for bi-directional track-train communication. 

--- Document Chunk 1290 ---
• Eurobalises mainly for location referencing. 

--- Document Chunk 1291 ---
2.6.6.2.2 Main ERTMS/ETCS trackside function: 

--- Document Chunk 1292 ---
• Knowing each train equipped with and running under ERTMS/ETCS within an RBC 

--- Document Chunk 1293 ---
area by its ERTMS/ETCS identity. 

--- Document Chunk 1294 ---
• Following each ERTMS/ETCS controlled train’s location within an RBC area. 

--- Document Chunk 1295 ---
• Optionally, train detection and train separation. 

--- Document Chunk 1296 ---
• Determine movement authorities for each train individually. 

--- Document Chunk 1297 ---
• Transmit movement authorities and track description  to each train individually. 

--- Document Chunk 1298 ---
• Handing over of train control between different RBC’s at the RBC-RBC borders. 

--- Document Chunk 1299 ---
2.6.6.2.3 On-board equipment: 

--- Document Chunk 1300 ---
• ERTMS/ETCS Onboard equipment with Eurobalise and Euroradio transmissions. 

--- Document Chunk 1301 ---
• The on-board part of the Radio Communication subsystem(s) (FRMCS and/or GSM-

--- Document Chunk 1302 ---
R). 

--- Document Chunk 1303 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 1304 ---

SUBSET-026-2 

--- Document Chunk 1307 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 1308 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 1309 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 1310 ---
Chapter 2 

--- Document Chunk 1311 ---
Basic System Description 

--- Document Chunk 1312 ---
Page 23/25 

--- Document Chunk 1313 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1314 ---
2.6.6.2.4 Main ERTMS/ETCS on-board function: 

--- Document Chunk 1315 ---
• The train reads Eurobalises and sends its position relative to the detected balises to 

--- Document Chunk 1316 ---
the radio block centre. 

--- Document Chunk 1317 ---
• If the train is fitted with a Train Integrity Monitoring System (not part of ERTMS/ETCS) 

--- Document Chunk 1318 ---
or if the train integrity is confirmed by the driver, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board sends 

--- Document Chunk 1319 ---
the train integrity information to the Radio Block Centre. 

--- Document Chunk 1320 ---
• The train receives a movement aut hority and the track description via Euroradio 

--- Document Chunk 1321 ---
relating to a balise. 

--- Document Chunk 1322 ---
• Selection of the most restrictive value of the different speeds permitted at each 

--- Document Chunk 1323 ---
location ahead. 

--- Document Chunk 1324 ---
• Calculation of a dynamic speed profile taking into account the train running/braking 

--- Document Chunk 1325 ---
characteristics which are known on-board and the track description data. 

--- Document Chunk 1326 ---
• Comparison of the train speed with the permitted speed and commanding of the brake 

--- Document Chunk 1327 ---
application if necessary. 

--- Document Chunk 1328 ---
• Cab signalling to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 1329 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 1330 ---

--- Document Chunk 1352 ---
2.6.8 Level transitions 

--- Document Chunk 1353 ---
2.6.8.1 An ERTMS/ETCS equipment which is not isolated always operates in one of the above 

--- Document Chunk 1354 ---
described levels. All transitions between these levels are performed according to defined 

--- Document Chunk 1355 ---
functions and procedures. 

--- Document Chunk 1356 ---
2.6.8.2 Additional national functions and rules which might be used by a n individual railway to 

--- Document Chunk 1357 ---
for example prevent not equipped trains from entering a level 2 area are not specified 

--- Document Chunk 1358 ---
here and have to be implemented outside ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 1359 ---
2.6.8.3 The following table shows all possible transitions (marked with Grey): 

--- Document Chunk 1360 ---
to 

--- Document Chunk 1361 ---
from                  

--- Document Chunk 1362 ---
0 NTC 1 2 

--- Document Chunk 1363 ---
0     

--- Document Chunk 1364 ---
NTC  a)   

--- Document Chunk 1365 ---
1     

--- Document Chunk 1366 ---
2    b) 

--- Document Chunk 1367 ---
Table 1: Possible level transitions. 

--- Document Chunk 1368 ---
a) Transitions between level NTC and level NTC describe the switching from one 

--- Document Chunk 1369 ---
national system to another national system. 

--- Document Chunk 1370 ---
b) Transitions between level 2 and level 2 describe the handover between RBC’s. 

--- Document Chunk 1371 ---

--- Document Chunk 1900 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1901 ---
3.3 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 1902 ---
3.3.1 Scope and purpose 

--- Document Chunk 1903 ---
3.3.1.1 The chapter 3, Principles, specifies the system principles of ETCS/ERTMS. These 

--- Document Chunk 1904 ---
principles apply to on-board and trackside subsystems. 

--- Document Chunk 1905 ---
3.3.1.2 The principles define the operational and technical behaviour of the system in general 

--- Document Chunk 1906 ---
and functional terms. 

--- Document Chunk 1907 ---
3.3.1.3 The chapter is divided into subchapters. In each subchapter normally several 

--- Document Chunk 1908 ---
requirements are defined. Each requirement is identified with a unique identification 

--- Document Chunk 1909 ---
number. 

--- Document Chunk 1910 ---
3.3.1.4 Notes, Justifications and Examples are only informative and shall not be regarded as 

--- Document Chunk 1911 ---
requirements. 

--- Document Chunk 1912 ---
3.4 Balise configuration, linking and Euroloop 

--- Document Chunk 1913 ---
3.4.1 Balise Configurations – Balise Group Definition 

--- Document Chunk 1914 ---
3.4.1.1 A balise group consists of between one and eight balises sharing the same balise group 

--- Document Chunk 1915 ---
identity. 

--- Document Chunk 1916 ---
3.4.1.2 In every balise, the following information is at least stored: 

--- Document Chunk 1917 ---
a) The internal number (from 1 to 8) of the balise 

--- Document Chunk 1918 ---
b) The number of balises inside the group 

--- Document Chunk 1919 ---
c) The balise group identity. 

--- Document Chunk 1920 ---
3.4.1.3 The internal number of the balise describes the relative position of the balise in the group. 

--- Document Chunk 1921 ---
3.4.2 Balise Co-ordinate System 

--- Document Chunk 1922 ---
3.4.2.1.1 Every balise group has its own co-ordinate system. 

--- Document Chunk 1923 ---
3.4.2.1.2 The orientation of the co -ordinate system of a balise group is defined by the  nominal 

--- Document Chunk 1924 ---
direction (see 3.4.2.2.2) and is identified as balise group orientation. 

--- Document Chunk 1925 ---
3.4.2.2 Balise groups composed of two or more balises 

--- Document Chunk 1926 ---
3.4.2.2.1 The origin of the co-ordinate system for each balise group is given by the balise number 

--- Document Chunk 1927 ---
1 (called location reference) in the balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 1928 ---
3.4.2.2.1.1 Exception: If the balise number 1 of the group is duplicated, the balise number 2 shall be 

--- Document Chunk 1929 ---
the location reference in case, out of this pair of duplicated balises, the ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 1930 ---
on-board equipment has only received the telegram from the balise number 2. 

--- Document Chunk 1931 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 1932 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1933 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1934 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 1935 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 1936 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 1937 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 1938 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 1939 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 1940 ---
Page 11/252 

--- Document Chunk 1941 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1942 ---
3.4.2.2.2 The nominal/reverse direction of each balise group is defined by increasing /decreasing 

--- Document Chunk 1943 ---
internal balise numbers. 

--- Document Chunk 1944 ---
  

--- Document Chunk 1945 ---
Reverse direction   Nominal direction 

--- Document Chunk 1946 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1947 ---
1st 2nd 

--- Document Chunk 1948 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1949 ---
3rd 

--- Document Chunk 1950 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1951 ---
Location Reference Balise Group schematic 

--- Document Chunk 1952 ---
representation 

--- Document Chunk 1953 ---
Balise Group orientation 

--- Document Chunk 1954 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1955 ---
Figure 1: Orientation of the balise group 

--- Document Chunk 1956 ---
3.4.2.3 Balise groups composed of a single balise 

--- Document Chunk 1957 ---
3.4.2.3.1 Balise groups consisting of only one single balise are referred to as "single balise groups" 

--- Document Chunk 1958 ---
in the following. 

--- Document Chunk 1959 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 1960 ---
No inherent coordinate system 

--- Document Chunk 1961 ---

--- Document Chunk 1967 ---

--- Document Chunk 1968 ---
3.4.2.3.2.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 1969 ---
3.4.2.3.2.2 For balise groups consisting of a single balise, the information "direction with which the 

--- Document Chunk 1970 ---
linked balise group will be passed over" from a previous ly received linking information 

--- Document Chunk 1971 ---
shall assign a co-ordinate system to the balise.  

--- Document Chunk 1972 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 1999 ---
3.4.2.3.2.3 The reference for the linking information can be either a single balise group if a co -

--- Document Chunk 2000 ---
ordinate system has been assigned to it before, or a balise group consisting of two or 

--- Document Chunk 2001 ---
more balises (with "inherent" co-ordinate system) 

--- Document Chunk 2002 ---
3.4.2.3.3 Assignment of the co -ordinate system by means of a dialogue between the on -

--- Document Chunk 2003 ---
board and the RBC: 

--- Document Chunk 2004 ---
3.4.2.3.3.1 If the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment cannot evaluate the orientation of the last 

--- Document Chunk 2005 ---
balise group received, being a single balise group, i.e. no linking information is available 

--- Document Chunk 2006 ---
to identify the orientation of the co -ordinate system of this single balise group, the 

--- Document Chunk 2007 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall report its position by means of a position report 

--- Document Chunk 2008 ---
based on two balise groups reporting the train position in reference to the LRBG and the 

--- Document Chunk 2009 ---
“previous LRBG”, if any. 

--- Document Chunk 2010 ---
3.4.2.3.3.1.1 Note: Receiving this type of position report advises the RBC o f the need to assign a 

--- Document Chunk 2011 ---
co-ordinate system to this single balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 2012 ---
3.4.2.3.3.2 When a single balise group is received and the previous LRBG is known, the position 

--- Document Chunk 2013 ---
report based on two balise groups shall use as direction reference a move from the  

--- Document Chunk 2014 ---
“previous LRBG” towards this single balise group (being the new LRBG): directional 

--- Document Chunk 2015 ---
information in the position report pointing in the same direction as the direction reference 

--- Document Chunk 2016 ---
shall be reported as “nominal”, otherwise as “reverse”. 

--- Document Chunk 2017 ---
3.4.2.3.3.3 If the “previous LRBG “ is not known, the “previous LRBG” and all directional information 

--- Document Chunk 2018 ---
of the position report based on two balise groups shall be reported as “unknown”. 

--- Document Chunk 2019 ---
3.4.2.3.3.4 If a new single balise group (BG2), different from the current LRBG (BG1), becomes 

--- Document Chunk 2020 ---
LRBG while the running direction of the tra in is opposite to the running direction when 

--- Document Chunk 2021 ---
this current LRBG (BG1) was last passed, the “previous LRBG” and all directional 

--- Document Chunk 2022 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 2038 ---

--- Document Chunk 2039 ---
3.4.2.3.3.6 The assignment of a co-ordinate system received from the RBC shall identify the balise 

--- Document Chunk 2040 ---
group for which the assignment is given, and shall assign a balise group orientation 

--- Document Chunk 2041 ---
“nominal” or “reverse” to this balise group  relative to the on -board direction reference 

--- Document Chunk 2042 ---
reported in the position report based on two balise groups (see 3.4.2.3.3.2). 

--- Document Chunk 2043 ---
3.4.2.3.3.6.1 Note: From the sequence of reported balise groups,  the RBC can derive the balise 

--- Document Chunk 2044 ---
group orientation with which the balise group was passed.

3.4.2.3.3.7 For single balise groups reported as LRBG and stored according to 3.6.2.2.2c, awaiting 

--- Document Chunk 2069 ---

--- Document Chunk 2071 ---

--- Document Chunk 2073 ---

--- Document Chunk 2074 ---

--- Document Chunk 2075 ---

--- Document Chunk 2076 ---
to have been reported more than once and with different “previous LRBGs”. 

--- Document Chunk 2077 ---

--- Document Chunk 2078 ---
and with different “previous LRBG s”, the assignment of the co -ordinate system is 

--- Document Chunk 2079 ---
ambiguous.

--- Document Chunk 2125 ---
3.4.3 Balise Information Types and Usage 

--- Document Chunk 2126 ---
3.4.3.1 In level 1, a ll information to the on -board system is given from balise groups or 

--- Document Chunk 2127 ---
additionally from Euroloops or Radio Infill Units (see section 3.9). In level 2, balise groups 

--- Document Chunk 2128 ---
are mostly used for location information. 

--- Document Chunk 2129 ---
3.4.3.2 In level 1, t he balise information can be of the following type (please refer to section s 

--- Document Chunk 2130 ---
3.6.2.3 and 3.8.5): 

--- Document Chunk 2131 ---
a) Non-infill 

--- Document Chunk 2132 ---
b) Intentionally deleted 

--- Document Chunk 2133 ---
c) Infill. 

--- Document Chunk 2134 ---
3.4.3.2.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2135 ---
3.4.3.2.2 Note: Infill information is referring to the location reference of an announced balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 2136 ---
3.4.3.3 Some information shall be read also in sleeping mode and when no linking information 

--- Document Chunk 2137 ---
is available (see Chapter 4 Use of received informatio n). If such information is 

--- Document Chunk 2138 ---
transmitted by balises, and if the information is directional, balise groups consisting of at 

--- Document Chunk 2139 ---
least two balises shall be used. 

--- Document Chunk 2140 ---
3.4.4 Linking 

--- Document Chunk 2141 ---
3.4.4.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 2142 ---
3.4.4.1.1 Aim of linking:  

--- Document Chunk 2143 ---
• To determine whether a balise group has been missed or not received within the 

--- Document Chunk 2144 ---
expectation window (see section 3.4.4.4) and take the appropriate action.  

--- Document Chunk 2145 ---
• To assign a co-ordinate system to balise groups consisting of a single balise. 

--- Document Chunk 2146 ---
• To perform the relocation of location based information without any consideration of 

--- Document Chunk 2147 ---
the odometer inaccuracy (see section 3.6.4). 

--- Document Chunk 2148 ---
3.4.4.1.2 A balise group is linked when its linking information (see section 3.4.4.2) is k nown in 

--- Document Chunk 2149 ---
advance. 

--- Document Chunk 2150 ---
3.4.4.1.2.1 Note: In cases where a balise group contains repositioning information, the term linked 

--- Document Chunk 2151 ---
also applies since the balise group is announced, marked as linked and contains 

--- Document Chunk 2152 ---
repositioning information marked accordingly. 

--- Document Chunk 2153 ---
3.4.4.2 Content of linking information 

--- Document Chunk 2154 ---
3.4.4.2.1 Linking information shall be composed of: 

--- Document Chunk 2155 ---
a) The identity of the linked balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 2156 ---
b) Where the location reference of the group is. 

--- Document Chunk 2157 ---
c) The accuracy of this location. 

--- Document Chunk 2158 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2159 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2160 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2161 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 2162 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 2163 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 2164 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 2165 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 2166 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 2167 ---
Page 16/252 

--- Document Chunk 2168 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2169 ---
Note: If the reference balise is duplicated, it is the trackside responsibility to define 

--- Document Chunk 2170 ---
the location accuracy to cover at least the location of the two duplicated balises. 

--- Document Chunk 2171 ---
d) The direction with which the linked balise group will be passed over (nominal or 

--- Document Chunk 2172 ---
reverse). 

--- Document Chunk 2173 ---
e) The reaction required if a data consistency problem occurs with the linked balise 

--- Document Chunk 2174 ---
group. 

--- Document Chunk 2175 ---
3.4.4.2.1.1 "Linking consistency is checked" shall be interpreted as when: 

--- Document Chunk 2176 ---
a) linking information is stored on-board, AND 

--- Document Chunk 2177 ---
b) depending on the mode the linking consistency check is active, AND 

--- Document Chunk 2178 ---
c) the supervision of the expectation window of the furthest announced balise group has 

--- Document Chunk 2179 ---
not yet been stopped (see 3.4.4.4.6). 

--- Document Chunk 2180 ---
3.4.4.2.2 Instead of the identity of a linked balise group it shall be possible to identify a following 

--- Document Chunk 2181 ---
linked balise group as unknown but containing repositioning information. 

--- Document Chunk 2182 ---
3.4.4.2.2.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2183 ---
3.4.4.2.2.2 Note 1: Regarding the repositioning information, see chapter 3.8.5.3.5 and 3.8.5.2. 

--- Document Chunk 2184 ---
3.4.4.2.2.3 Note 2: In case the identity of the next balise group is not unambiguously known because 

--- Document Chunk 2185 ---
the route is not known by the trackside, this feature allows to link this balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 2186 ---
3.4.4.2.3 For each linked balise group, the trackside shall select one of the following reactions to 

--- Document Chunk 2187 ---
be used in case of data inconsistencies: 

--- Document Chunk 2188 ---
a) Train trip  (Trip mode, see Chapter 4) 

--- Document Chunk 2189 ---
b) Command service brake  

--- Document Chunk 2190 ---
c) No reaction 

--- Document Chunk 2191 ---
For further details see section 3.16.2. 

--- Document Chunk 2192 ---
3.4.4.3 Unlinked Balise Groups 

--- Document Chunk 2193 ---
3.4.4.3.1 A balise group, which contains information that must be considered even when the balise 

--- Document Chunk 2194 ---
group is not announced by linking, is called an unlinked balise group.  

--- Document Chunk 2195 ---
3.4.4.3.2 Unlinked balise groups shall consist at minimum of two balises.   

--- Document Chunk 2196 ---
3.4.4.3.3 Unlinked balise groups shall always contain the unlinked balise group qualifier. 

--- Document Chunk 2197 ---
3.4.4.4 Rules applicable to balise groups when linking consistency is checked 

--- Document Chunk 2198 ---
3.4.4.4.1 "Expected balise group" shall be interpreted as an announced balise group whose 

--- Document Chunk 2199 ---
expectation window is currently supervised by the on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 2200 ---
3.4.4.4.2 When the expected balise group is referred in the linking information with a balise group 

--- Document Chunk 2201 ---
with ID not set to “unknown” , the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall reject the 

--- Document Chunk 2202 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2203 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2204 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2205 ---

--- Document Chunk 2206 ---

--- Document Chunk 2207 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 2208 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 2209 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 2210 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 2211 ---
Page 17/252 

--- Document Chunk 2212 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2213 ---
message from any  balise group marked as linked and not included in the linking 

--- Document Chunk 2214 ---
information. 

--- Document Chunk 2215 ---
3.4.4.4.2.1 When the expected balise group is referred in the linking information with a balise group 

--- Document Chunk 2216 ---
with ID “unknown”, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall reject the message from 

--- Document Chunk 2217 ---
any balise group marked as linked unless: 

--- Document Chunk 2218 ---
a) the on-board equipment can determine the orientat ion of the linked balise group by 

--- Document Chunk 2219 ---
information from the balise group itself (therefore excluding for example single balise 

--- Document Chunk 2220 ---
groups), AND 

--- Document Chunk 2221 ---
b) the balise group contains repositioning information valid for the train orientation, AND 

--- Document Chunk 2222 ---
c) the balise group is crossed with the direction announced in the linking information. 

--- Document Chunk 2223 ---
3.4.4.4.2.2 Balise groups marked as unlinked shall be taken into account. 

--- Document Chunk 2224 ---
3.4.4.4.3 For each  balise group marked as linked and included in the linking information , the 

--- Document Chunk 2225 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall check whether  the balise giving the location 

--- Document Chunk 2226 ---
reference of the group was detected (see SUBSET-036 sections 4.2.4.1 and 4.2.4.2) 

--- Document Chunk 2227 ---
within its expectation window starting 

--- Document Chunk 2228 ---
• when the max safe antenna position has passed the first possible location of the 

--- Document Chunk 2229 ---
balise group  

--- Document Chunk 2230 ---
and ending 

--- Document Chunk 2231 ---
• when the min safe antenna position has passed the last possible location of the balise 

--- Document Chunk 2232 ---
group 

--- Document Chunk 2233 ---
3.4.4.4.3.1 The first possible location and the last possible location of the balise group are defined 

--- Document Chunk 2234 ---
by the linking distance and the location accuracy of the expected balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 2235 ---
3.4.4.4.3.2 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall reject the message from a balise group 

--- Document Chunk 2236 ---
whose location reference is detected outside its expectation window or whose location 

--- Document Chunk 2237 ---
reference is received while its expectation window is no longer supervised. 

--- Document Chunk 2238 ---
3.4.4.4.4 In case of a balise group containing repositioning information, the first possible location 

--- Document Chunk 2239 ---
shall be the reference location of the previously linked balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 2240 ---
3.4.4.4.5 The on -board equipment shall supervise only one expectation window at a time 

--- Document Chunk 2241 ---
according to the order given by linking information and starting with the first announced 

--- Document Chunk 2242 ---
balise group in advance of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 2243 ---
3.4.4.4.5.1 Upon reception of new linking information and after the replacement of previously stored 

--- Document Chunk 2244 ---
linking information (if any), the first announced balise group in advance of the train shall 

--- Document Chunk 2245 ---
be determined by the on -board equipment as the first one in the resulting linking 

--- Document Chunk 2246 ---
information stored on -board, whose end of expectation window has not yet been 

--- Document Chunk 2247 ---
reached. 

--- Document Chunk 2248 ---
3.4.4.4.6 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall stop supervising the expectation window 

--- Document Chunk 2249 ---
of a balise group and shall start supervising the expectation window of the next one 

--- Document Chunk 2250 ---
announced in the linking information (if any) when one of the following events occurs: 

--- Document Chunk 2251 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 2261 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2262 ---
a) the location reference of the  group is detected (see SUBSET -036 sections 4.2.4.1 

--- Document Chunk 2263 ---
and 4.2.4.2) inside its expectation window 

--- Document Chunk 2264 ---
b) a linking consistency error is found, see 3.16.2.3.1 

--- Document Chunk 2265 ---
c) a balise group message consistency error is found, see 3.16.2.4.1 

--- Document Chunk 2266 ---
3.4.4.4.6.1 Linking consistency error due to early reception of balise group expected later (see 

--- Document Chunk 2267 ---
3.16.2.3.1 c)): if the location reference  received is the one of the next balise group 

--- Document Chunk 2268 ---
announced in the linking information, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall check 

--- Document Chunk 2269 ---
its linking consistency and apply again clause 3.4.4.4.6, i.e. it will immediately expect the 

--- Document Chunk 2270 ---
further next balise group announced in the linking information. 

--- Document Chunk 2271 ---
3.4.4.4.6.2 Note: 3.4.4.4.6 a) implies that in case a balise group composed of more than one balise 

--- Document Chunk 2272 ---
is crossed in nominal direction there will be other balise telegram(s) from this group still 

--- Document Chunk 2273 ---
to be received once its expectation window is no longer supervised. Conversely, in case 

--- Document Chunk 2274 ---
a balise group composed  of more than one balise is crossed in reverse direction, the 

--- Document Chunk 2275 ---
telegram(s) of the first balise(s) of this group might be received before its expectation 

--- Document Chunk 2276 ---
window starts to be supervised. 

--- Document Chunk 2277 ---
3.4.4.4.7 In case the expected balise group is referred in the linking information with a balise group 

--- Document Chunk 2278 ---
with ID not set to “unknown”, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall reject the 

--- Document Chunk 2279 ---
message from this group and trip the train if the balise group is passed in the unexpected 

--- Document Chunk 2280 ---
direction. 

--- Document Chunk 2281 ---
3.4.4.5  Rules applicable to balise groups when linking consistency is not checked 

--- Document Chunk 2282 ---
3.4.4.5.1 All balise groups shall be taken into account. 

--- Document Chunk 2283 ---
3.4.5 Euroloop (level 1 only) 

--- Document Chunk 2284 ---
3.4.5.1  End Of Loop Marker (Euroloop announcement) 

--- Document Chunk 2285 ---
3.4.5.1.1 The End Of Loop Marker (EOLM) information is transmitted only by balise groups. 

--- Document Chunk 2286 ---
3.4.5.1.2 The balise group transmitting the EOLM information marks the beginning of a track area 

--- Document Chunk 2287 ---
where loop messages can be received. In bidirectional applications, it is possible to have 

--- Document Chunk 2288 ---
an EOLM at both sides of a loop. 

--- Document Chunk 2289 ---
3.4.5.1.3 The following information is included in the EOLM: 

--- Document Chunk 2290 ---
• Loop identity used to identify the loop. 

--- Document Chunk 2291 ---
• Key to select the spread spectrum key necessary to receive the loop messages. 

--- Document Chunk 2292 ---
• Distance to the loop giving the distance from the EOLM to the location from where 

--- Document Chunk 2293 ---
the loop is installed. 

--- Document Chunk 2294 ---
• Length of the loop. 

--- Document Chunk 2295 ---
• Indicator telling the on -board whe ther the orientation of the loop (i.e. its nominal 

--- Document Chunk 2296 ---
direction) is identical or opposite to the balise group orientation including the EOLM 

--- Document Chunk 2297 ---
information. 

--- Document Chunk 2298 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2299 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2300 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2301 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 2302 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 2303 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 2304 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 2305 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 2306 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 2307 ---
Page 19/252 

--- Document Chunk 2308 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2309 ---
3.4.5.1.4 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall manage only one EOLM information at a 

--- Document Chunk 2310 ---
time, therefore a new EOLM shall replace a previously stored one. 

--- Document Chunk 2311 ---
3.4.5.1.5 The loop area is defined as the track area from the reference location of the balise group 

--- Document Chunk 2312 ---
from which the EOLM information has been received to the location determined by the 

--- Document Chunk 2313 ---
distance to the loop plus the length of the loop. 

--- Document Chunk 2314 ---
3.4.5.1.6 After the min safe loop antenna position (calculated by subtracting the distance between 

--- Document Chunk 2315 ---
the active Euroloop antenna and the front end of the train from the min safe front end 

--- Document Chunk 2316 ---
position) has passed the start of the loop area, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 2317 ---
shall delete the EOLM information as soon as the loop antenna position is outside the 

--- Document Chunk 2318 ---
loop area, taking into account the min safe antenna position in case of movement in the 

--- Document Chunk 2319 ---
direction of train orientation and the max safe antenna position in cas e of movement 

--- Document Chunk 2320 ---
opposite to train orientation. 

--- Document Chunk 2321 ---
3.4.5.2 Rules related to Euroloop 

--- Document Chunk 2322 ---
3.4.5.2.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall only accept information coming from a 

--- Document Chunk 2323 ---
Euroloop if the loop identity referred in the loop message matches the loop identity 

--- Document Chunk 2324 ---
referred in the EOLM information stored on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 2325 ---
3.4.5.2.2 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall start accepting messages from the 

--- Document Chunk 2326 ---
Euroloop as soon as its corresponding EOLM information is received. 

--- Document Chunk 2327 ---
3.4.5.2.3 The Euroloop information can be of the following type: 

--- Document Chunk 2328 ---
a) Non-infill. 

--- Document Chunk 2329 ---
b) Infill. 

--- Document Chunk 2330 ---
3.5 Management of Radio Communication 

--- Document Chunk 2331 ---
3.5.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 2332 ---
3.5.1.1 Note: the following section refers to the behaviour of the user application interacting with 

--- Document Chunk 2333 ---
Euroradio protocols. How the messages are actually transported from the sender to the 

--- Document Chunk 2334 ---
receiver user application is not relevant for this description. 

--- Document Chunk 2335 ---
3.5.1.2 Only communication sessions between an ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment and a 

--- Document Chunk 2336 ---
trackside equipment (RBC or Radio Infill Unit) are considered here. 

--- Document Chunk 2337 ---
3.5.2 General 

--- Document Chunk 2338 ---
3.5.2.1 Each communication session managed by an entity allow s the exchange of data with 

--- Document Chunk 2339 ---
only one other entity. 

--- Document Chunk 2340 ---
3.5.2.2 Note: in the following sections reference is made to safe radio connections, whose 

--- Document Chunk 2341 ---
definition and management is contained in Euroradio specification. 

--- Document Chunk 2342 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 2353 ---
3.5.2.3 Note: The information Initiation of a Communication Session and Version not Compatible 

--- Document Chunk 2354 ---
(see sections 3.5.2.4 and 3.17) are the same in every system version. 

--- Document Chunk 2355 ---
3.5.2.4 If the GSM-R radio system is installed on-board, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 2356 ---
shall be able to manage simultaneous communication sessions established through 

--- Document Chunk 2357 ---
GSM-R with at least two different entities. 

--- Document Chunk 2358 ---
3.5.2.5 Only the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment can initiate the establishment or the 

--- Document Chunk 2359 ---
termination of a communication session. 

--- Document Chunk 2360 ---
3.5.2.6 The trackside has the following possibilities to order the initiation of establishment or 

--- Document Chunk 2361 ---
termination of a communication session: 

--- Document Chunk 2362 ---
3.5.2.6.1 The session management order for RBC that includes: 

--- Document Chunk 2363 ---
a) The identity of the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 2364 ---
b) The telephone number of the RBC (only if interfaced to GSM-R). 

--- Document Chunk 2365 ---
c) The action to be performed (establish/terminate the session). 

--- Document Chunk 2366 ---
d) Whether the action applies also to Sleeping units. 

--- Document Chunk 2367 ---
3.5.2.6.2 The RBC transition order that embeds an order to establish a communication session 

--- Document Chunk 2368 ---
with the Accepting RBC which includes: 

--- Document Chunk 2369 ---
a) The identity of the Accepting RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 2370 ---
b) The telephone number of the Accepting RBC (only if interfaced to GSM-R). 

--- Document Chunk 2371 ---
c) Whether the action to establish a communication session applies also to Sleeping 

--- Document Chunk 2372 ---
units. 

--- Document Chunk 2373 ---
3.5.2.6.3 The Radio infill area information that embeds a session management order for RIU which 

--- Document Chunk 2374 ---
includes: 

--- Document Chunk 2375 ---
a) The identity of the Radio Infill Unit. 

--- Document Chunk 2376 ---
b) The telephone number of the Radio Infill Unit. 

--- Document Chunk 2377 ---
c) The action to be performed (establish/terminate the session). 

--- Document Chunk 2378 ---
3.5.2.6.4 The session management order for neighbouring RIU that includes: 

--- Document Chunk 2379 ---
a) The identity of the Radio Infill Unit. 

--- Document Chunk 2380 ---
b) The telephone number of the Radio Infill Unit. 

--- Document Chunk 2381 ---
c) The action to be performed (establish/terminate the session).

--- Document Chunk 2397 ---
3.5.3.4 The on-board shall establish a communication session 

--- Document Chunk 2398 ---
a) At Start of Mission (only if level 2). 

--- Document Chunk 2399 ---
b) If ordered from trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 2400 ---
c) If a mode change, neither considered as an End of Mission  nor triggered from 

--- Document Chunk 2401 ---
condition g) below, has to be reported to the RBC (only if level 2) 

--- Document Chunk 2402 ---
d) If the driver has manually changed the level to 2 

--- Document Chunk 2403 ---
e) When the engine rear end reaches the end of an announced radio hole 

--- Document Chunk 2404 ---
f) When the previous communication session is considered as terminated due to loss of 

--- Document Chunk 2405 ---
safe radio connection (refer to 3.5.4.2.1) 

--- Document Chunk 2406 ---
g) When a Start of Mission procedure, during which no communication session could be 

--- Document Chunk 2407 ---
established, is completed in level 2 

--- Document Chunk 2408 ---
h) When outside the Start of Mission procedure, the driver has manually selected the 

--- Document Chunk 2409 ---
RBC contact information (only if level) 

--- Document Chunk 2410 ---
3.5.3.4.1 In respect of a), b), c) , d), e) and h) of 3.5.3.4, the on -board shall not establish a new 

--- Document Chunk 2411 ---
communication session with an RBC/RIU in case a communication session: 

--- Document Chunk 2412 ---
• is currently being established with this RBC/RIU or 

--- Document Chunk 2413 ---
• is already established with this RBC/RIU and no Termination of Communication 

--- Document Chunk 2414 ---
Session message has been sent to this RBC/RIU. 

--- Document Chunk 2415 ---
3.5.3.4.2 In respect of b), c), d), e) and h) of 3.5.3.4, in case a communication session is already 

--- Document Chunk 2416 ---
established with this RBC/RIU and a Termination of Communication Session message 

--- Document Chunk 2417 ---
has been sent to this RBC/RIU the on -board shall establish a new communication 

--- Document Chunk 2418 ---
session with this RBC/RI U as soon as the already established communication session 

--- Document Chunk 2419 ---
is terminated and the safe radio connection is released. 

--- Document Chunk 2420 ---
3.5.3.5 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2421 ---
3.5.3.5.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2422 ---
3.5.3.5.2 If the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment has to establish a communication session with 

--- Document Chunk 2423 ---
an RBC whilst in session with one or more other RBC(s), the existing communication 

--- Document Chunk 2424 ---
session(s) shall be terminated (see 3.5.5.2 for details) and the new one shall be 

--- Document Chunk 2425 ---
established. 

--- Document Chunk 2426 ---
3.5.3.5.2.1 Exception: an order to establish a communication session with an Accepting RBC, which 

--- Document Chunk 2427 ---
is embedded in the RBC transition order, shall not terminate the communication session 

--- Document Chunk 2428 ---
with the currently supervising RBC, unless the on-board equipment is only able to handle 

--- Document Chunk 2429 ---
one communication session through GSM-R and the situation is such that a s ession 

--- Document Chunk 2430 ---
must be established with another RBC (see 3.15.1.3.2.4 for details).
