--- Document Chunk 2444 ---
3.5.3.7 The establishment of a communication session shall be performed ac cording to the 

--- Document Chunk 2445 ---
following steps: 

--- Document Chunk 2446 ---
a) The on-board shall request the set-up of a safe radio connection with the trackside. If 

--- Document Chunk 2447 ---
this request is part of an ongoing Start of Mission procedure  or is related to the 

--- Document Chunk 2448 ---
establishment of a communication session due to condition 3.5.3.4 c ), it shall be 

--- Document Chunk 2449 ---
repeated until successful or a defined number of times (see Appendix A.3.1). 

--- Document Chunk 2450 ---
If this request is not part of an ongoing Start of Mission procedure  and is not related 

--- Document Chunk 2451 ---
to the establishment of a communication session due to condition 3.5.3.4 c) , it shall 

--- Document Chunk 2452 ---
be repeated until successful. 

--- Document Chunk 2453 ---
A request shall be repeated immediately after EURORADIO has indicated that setting 

--- Document Chunk 2454 ---
up the safe radio connection has failed. 

--- Document Chunk 2455 ---
b) As soon as the safe radio connection is set-up, the on-board shall send the message 

--- Document Chunk 2456 ---
Initiation of communication session to the trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 2457 ---
c) As soon as the trackside receives the information, it shall send the system version. 

--- Document Chunk 2458 ---
d) When the on-board receives the system version it shall consider the communication 

--- Document Chunk 2459 ---
session established and: 

--- Document Chunk 2460 ---
• If one of its supported system versions is compatible with the one sent by 

--- Document Chunk 2461 ---
trackside, it shall send a session established report, including its supported system 

--- Document Chunk 2462 ---
versions, to the trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 2463 ---
• If none of its supported system versions is compatible with the one sent by 

--- Document Chunk 2464 ---
trackside, it shall send a version independent message indicating “No compatible 

--- Document Chunk 2465 ---
version supported”. It shall inform the driver and shall terminate the 

--- Document Chunk 2466 ---
communication session. 

--- Document Chunk 2467 ---
e) When the trackside receives the session established report or the information that no 

--- Document Chunk 2468 ---
compatible system version is supported by the on -board, it shall consider the 

--- Document Chunk 2469 ---
communication session established. Upon reception of a session established report, 

--- Document Chunk 2470 ---
the trackside shall acknowledge the establishment of the communication session to 

--- Document Chunk 2471 ---
the on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 2472 ---

3.5.3.7.1 Regarding a), if both radio systems are installed on-board it shall request the set-up of a 

--- Document Chunk 2506 ---
safe radio connection according to the following (by priority order): 

--- Document Chunk 2507 ---
1) In case of order received from tracks ide, depending on whether the order relates 

--- Document Chunk 2508 ---
to an RBC interfaced with FRMCS only, OR 

--- Document Chunk 2509 ---
2) If the stored Radio Network type is FRMCS+GSM -R and if during the SoM the 

--- Document Chunk 2510 ---
driver has elected to perform the mission with only one radio system, by using 

--- Document Chunk 2511 ---
either the FRMCS o n-board equipment or a GSM -R Mobile Terminal, depending 

--- Document Chunk 2512 ---
on the radio system to which the registration was successful during the SoM, OR 

--- Document Chunk 2513 ---
3) According to the stored Radio Network information (Radio Network type and, if 

--- Document Chunk 2514 ---
relevant, GSM-R Radio Network ID). If the Radio Network type is FRMCS+GSM-

--- Document Chunk 2515 ---
R, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board shall use, if available, the preferred radio system 

--- Document Chunk 2516 ---
stored when establishing the previous communication session with the RBC (see 

--- Document Chunk 2517 ---
SUBSET-037-1 for details) 

--- Document Chunk 2518 ---
3.5.3.7.2 Regarding b), if both radio systems are installed on-board it shall store the radio system 

--- Document Chunk 2519 ---
through which the safe radio connection is successfully set up. 

--- Document Chunk 2520 ---
3.5.3.7.3 Exception to d): when the on -board does not receive the system version within a fixed 

--- Document Chunk 2521 ---
waiting time (see A.3.1) it shall request the release of the safe radio connection with the 

--- Document Chunk 2522 ---
trackside and shall restart the establishment of the communication session with step a). 

--- Document Chunk 2523 ---

3.5.3.7.4 Regarding e), in case the on-board has sent a session established report: when the on-

--- Document Chunk 2535 ---

--- Document Chunk 2536 ---
session within a fixed waiting time (see A.3.1), it shall again send a session established 

--- Document Chunk 2537 ---

--- Document Chunk 2538 ---
3.5.3.7.4.1 If, following the repetition of the session established report, the acknowledgement of 

--- Document Chunk 2539 ---
session establishment is still not received within the fixed waiting time, the on-board shall 

--- Document Chunk 2540 ---
terminate the communication session and re-establish a new one. 

--- Document Chunk 2541 ---
3.5.3.7.5 Exception to e): If the trackside receives  a "Termination of communication session" 

--- Document Chunk 2542 ---
message, instead of a session established report or the information that no compatible 

--- Document Chunk 2543 ---
system version is supported by the on -board, it shall abort the process of session 

--- Document Chunk 2544 ---
establishment and proceed with clause 3.5.5.2 b). 

--- Document Chunk 2545 ---
3.5.3.8 When a communication session is currently being established (i.e. at any time from the 

--- Document Chunk 2546 ---
first request the set-up of a safe radio connection to the reception of the system version 

--- Document Chunk 2547 ---
from trackside), the on-board shall no longer apply 3.5.3.7 a), 3.5.3.7 b) and 3.5.3.7 d) 

--- Document Chunk 2548 ---
(i.e. it aborts the process of establishing it) and shall release the safe radio connection 

--- Document Chunk 2549 ---
(if any) if at least one of the following conditions is met: 

--- Document Chunk 2550 ---
a) The driver closes the desk during Start of Mission 

--- Document Chunk 2551 ---
b) End of Mission is performed 

--- Document Chunk 2552 ---
c) An order to terminate the communication session is received from trackside 

--- Document Chunk 2553 ---
d) The train passes with its min safe rear end a level transition border from a level 2 area 

--- Document Chunk 2554 ---
to an area where level 2 operation is not supported 

--- Document Chunk 2555 ---
e) An order to establish a communication session with a different RBC is received from 

--- Document Chunk 2556 ---
trackside and the order does not request to contact an Accepting RBC 

--- Document Chunk 2557 ---
f) The train passes an RBC/RBC border with its min safe rear end 

--- Document Chunk 2558 ---
g) The engine front end passes the start of an announced radio hole 

--- Document Chunk 2559 ---
h) Regards RIUs only: Level 1 is left 

--- Document Chunk 2560 ---
i) The driver elects to modify the Radio Network type or the GSM-R Radio Network ID 

--- Document Chunk 2561 ---

3.5.4 Maintaining a communication session 

--- Document Chunk 2600 ---
3.5.4.1 When a communication session is established , in case of a loss of the safe radio 

--- Document Chunk 2601 ---
connection, i.e., if the disconnection has not been ordered (see 3.5.5.1), the involved 

--- Document Chunk 2602 ---
entities shall consider the communication session still established for a defined time. The 

--- Document Chunk 2603 ---
defined time shall start as soon as EURORADIO has indicated the loss of the safe radio 

--- Document Chunk 2604 ---
connection. 

--- Document Chunk 2605 ---
3.5.4.2 When EURORADIO indicates the loss of the safe radio connection, the ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 2606 ---
on-board equipment shall immediately try to s et-up a new safe radio connection  using 

--- Document Chunk 2607 ---
the radio system through which the safe radio connection was successfully set up 

--- Document Chunk 2608 ---
beforehand (see SUBSET-037-1 for details). 

--- Document Chunk 2609 ---
3.5.4.2.1 If the safe radio connection is not re -established after the defined time (as defined in 

--- Document Chunk 2610 ---
A.3.1), both, on -board equipment and trackside, shall consider the session as 

--- Document Chunk 2611 ---
terminated. 

--- Document Chunk 2612 ---
3.5.4.3 The attempts shall be repeated, until at least one of the following conditions is met: 

--- Document Chunk 2613 ---
• The safe radio connection is set-up. 

--- Document Chunk 2614 ---
• The session is considered as terminated. 

--- Document Chunk 2615 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2616 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2617 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2618 ---
SUBSET-026-3

--- Document Chunk 2622 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 2623 ---

--- Document Chunk 2624 ---
Page 26/252 

--- Document Chunk 2625 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2626 ---
• The train passes the location indicated in the RIU order “Terminate the 

--- Document Chunk 2627 ---
communication session” 

--- Document Chunk 2628 ---
3.5.4.3.1 Note: if the session is considered as terminated due to 3.5.4.2.1, the attempts will be 

--- Document Chunk 2629 ---
resumed immediately according to 3.5.3.4 f). 

--- Document Chunk 2630 ---
3.5.4.4 Exception to 3.5.4.2 and 3.5.4.3: the on -board equipment shall not try to set up a new 

--- Document Chunk 2631 ---
safe radio connection and shall stop any ongoing attempts if the engine, taking into 

--- Document Chunk 2632 ---
account its front and rear ends,  overlaps an announced radio hole (see 3.12.1.3). The 

--- Document Chunk 2633 ---
on-board equipment shall try to set it up again when the  engine rear/front end reaches 

--- Document Chunk 2634 ---
the end of the radio hole , depending on whether the train orientation is the same 

--- Document Chunk 2635 ---
as/opposite to the active cab. 

--- Document Chunk 2636 ---
3.5.4.5 In case a message has to be sent during the loss of the safe radio connection, this 

--- Document Chunk 2637 ---
message shall be considered as sent. 

--- Document Chunk 2638 ---
3.5.4.6 When the trackside receives a session established report inside an existing 

--- Document Chunk 2639 ---
communication session it shall acknowledge the establishment of the communication 

--- Document Chunk 2640 ---
session to the on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 2641 ---
3.5.4.7 When the on -board receives a system version message inside an existing 

--- Document Chunk 2642 ---
communication session it shall send a session established report. 

--- Document Chunk 2643 ---
3.5.4.7.1 Note: An RBC could repeat the system version message if it assumes that the message 

--- Document Chunk 2644 ---
was not received by the on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 2645 ---
3.5.5 Terminating a communication session 

--- Document Chunk 2646 ---
3.5.5.1 The termination of a communication session shall be initiated only by the on -board and 

--- Document Chunk 2647 ---
in the following cases: 

--- Document Chunk 2648 ---
a) If an order is received from trackside (RBC, RIU or balise groups) (see section 3.5.2 

--- Document Chunk 2649 ---
concerning the content of the order). 

--- Document Chunk 2650 ---
b) If a condition requiring the termination of the communication session is fulfilled without 

--- Document Chunk 2651 ---
any explicit trackside order. The situations in which such condition is met are detailed 

--- Document Chunk 2652 ---
in other sections of this specification. 

--- Document Chunk 2653 ---
c) Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2654 ---
d) Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2655 ---
e) Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2656 ---
f) Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2657 ---
3.5.5.2 In case a session is established, t he on -board equipment shall terminate the 

--- Document Chunk 2658 ---
communication session according to the following steps: 

--- Document Chunk 2659 ---
a) The on -board equipment shall send a Termination of communication session 

--- Document Chunk 2660 ---
message.  

--- Document Chunk 2661 ---

--- Document Chunk 2702 ---

--- Document Chunk 2727 ---
3.5.6 Managing the Radio Networks 

--- Document Chunk 2728 ---
3.5.6.1 ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall order the registration of its connected GSM-R 

--- Document Chunk 2729 ---
Mobile Terminal(s) to a GSM-R Radio Network: 

--- Document Chunk 2730 ---
a) At power-up 

--- Document Chunk 2731 ---
b) Following driver entry of a new GSM-R Radio Network identity 

--- Document Chunk 2732 ---
c) If ordered from the trackside 

--- Document Chunk 2733 ---
3.5.6.1.1 In order to manage the transitions between different Radio Networks, the trackside can 

--- Document Chunk 2734 ---
transmit Radio Network transition orders, which include: 

--- Document Chunk 2735 ---
a) The Radio Network type (FRMCS, FRMCS+GSM-R, or GSM-R) 

--- Document Chunk 2736 ---
b) Only if the Radio Network type is FRMCS+GSM -R or GSM -R, the GSM -R Radio 

--- Document Chunk 2737 ---
Network identity 

--- Document Chunk 2738 ---
3.5.6.1.2 Note 1: Unlike the GSM-R Radio Networks, the FRMCS Radio Network can be seen by 

--- Document Chunk 2739 ---
ETCS as one single entity without the need for ETCS to order the registration of its 

--- Document Chunk 2740 ---
connected FRMCS on-board equipment to the FRMCS Radio Network or to manage the 

--- Document Chunk 2741 ---
transitions between networks, which permits e.g. to not interrupt a r adio connection on 

--- Document Chunk 2742 ---
passing an international border where FRMCS is installed on both sides of the border. 

--- Document Chunk 2743 ---
3.5.6.1.3 Note 2:  As soon as it is powered -up, the FRMCS on -board equipment reports 

--- Document Chunk 2744 ---
continuously to the ETCS on -board equipment whether it is registered or not t o the 

--- Document Chunk 2745 ---
FRMCS radio network, i.e. that it is ready or not to establish a radio connection with an 

--- Document Chunk 2746 ---
RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 2747 ---
3.5.6.2 When powered-off, ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall memorize the last received 

--- Document Chunk 2748 ---
Radio Network type and GSM -R Radio Network identity if any (from trackside or from 

--- Document Chunk 2749 ---
driver) and shall use it (them) when powered-up again. 

--- Document Chunk 2750 ---
3.5.6.3 If no GSM-R Radio Network identity re ceived from trackside or from driver could have 

--- Document Chunk 2751 ---
been memorized by ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment (e.g. after a System Failure or 

--- Document Chunk 2752 ---
at very first power -up), this latter shall nevertheless order the registration of its Mobile 

--- Document Chunk 2753 ---
Terminal(s) to a default GSM-R Radio Network. 

--- Document Chunk 2754 ---
3.5.6.3.1 Note 1: the source used to retrieve the default GSM-R Radio Network identity (on-board 

--- Document Chunk 2755 ---
equipment permanent storage, Mobile Terminal itself, or other external source) is 

--- Document Chunk 2756 ---
implementation dependent.  

--- Document Chunk 2757 ---
3.5.6.3.2 Note 2: if ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment is powered-up in an area not covered by 

--- Document Chunk 2758 ---
the memorized or default GSM-R Radio Network, attempts to register to this Radio 

--- Document Chunk 2759 ---
Network will be repeated unconditionally by the Mobile Terminal(s) until either an attempt 

--- Document Chunk 2760 ---
is successful or a new GSM-R Radio Network identity is received from trackside or from 

--- Document Chunk 2761 ---
driver, preventing Mobile Term inal(s) from registering to any unwanted GSM-R Radio 

--- Document Chunk 2762 ---
Network. 

--- Document Chunk 2763 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2764 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2765 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2766 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 2767 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 2768 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 2769 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 2770 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 2771 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 2772 ---
Page 29/252 

--- Document Chunk 2773 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2774 ---
3.5.6.4 If no Radio Network type received from trackside or from driver could have been 

--- Document Chunk 2775 ---
memorized by ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment (e.g. after a System Failure or at very 

--- Document Chunk 2776 ---
first power-up), this latter shall use a default value configured on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 2777 ---
3.5.6.5 On reception of the Radio Network transition order, ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 2778 ---
shall store the Radio Network type and, if the Radio Network type included in the order 

--- Document Chunk 2779 ---
is FRMCS+GSM-R or GSM-R, it shall immediately order the Radio Network registration 

--- Document Chunk 2780 ---
of each GSM-R Mobile Terminal that fulfils the following conditions: 

--- Document Chunk 2781 ---
a) it is not yet registered to the ordered GSM-R Radio Network, AND 

--- Document Chunk 2782 ---
b) it is not used for an established communication session, AND 

--- Document Chunk 2783 ---
c) no safe radio connection is being set-up 

--- Document Chunk 2784 ---
3.5.6.6 If a GSM-R Mobile Terminal is not currently registered to the GSM-R Radio Network 

--- Document Chunk 2785 ---
ordered by trackside and if one of the conditions b) or c) is not fulfilled, ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 2786 ---
on-board equipment shall initiate the GSM-R Radio Network regist ration once 

--- Document Chunk 2787 ---
communication session is terminated and safe radio connection is released. 

--- Document Chunk 2788 ---
3.5.6.7 Any order to establish a communication session with  an RBC received from trackside 

--- Document Chunk 2789 ---
shall not lead to any request to set -up a safe radio connection  by ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 2790 ---
board equipment if: 

--- Document Chunk 2791 ---
a) the stored Radio Network type is FRMCS or is FRMCS+GSM-R while FRMCS is the 

--- Document Chunk 2792 ---
only radio system installed on-board and the FRMCS on-board is not registered to the 

--- Document Chunk 2793 ---
FRMCS Radio Network, OR 

--- Document Chunk 2794 ---
b) the stored Radio Network type is FRMCS+GSM -R while both radio systems are 

--- Document Chunk 2795 ---
installed on-board, and, unless the driver has elected to perform the mission with only 

--- Document Chunk 2796 ---
one radio system, either the FRMCS on-board is not registered to the FRMCS Radio 

--- Document Chunk 2797 ---
Network or no GSM-R Mobile Terminal is duly registered to a GSM-R Radio Network, 

--- Document Chunk 2798 ---
OR 

--- Document Chunk 2799 ---
c) the stored Radio Network type is FRMCS+GSM -R while both radio systems are 

--- Document Chunk 2800 ---
installed on-board, and, while the driver has elected to perform the mission with only 

--- Document Chunk 2801 ---
one radio system, the concerned on-board radio system is no longer registered to the 

--- Document Chunk 2802 ---
Radio Network, OR 

--- Document Chunk 2803 ---
d) the stored Radio Network type is GSM -R or is FRMCS+GSM-R while GSM-R is the 

--- Document Chunk 2804 ---
only radio system installed on-board and no GSM-R Mobile Terminal is duly registered 

--- Document Chunk 2805 ---
to a GSM-R Radio Network. 

--- Document Chunk 2806 ---
3.5.6.8 Any order to establish a communication session  with an RIU received from trackside 

--- Document Chunk 2807 ---
shall not lead to any request to set -up a safe radio connection by ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 2808 ---
board equipment if no GSM -R Mobile Terminal is duly registered to a GSM -R Radio 

--- Document Chunk 2809 ---
Network. 

--- Document Chunk 2810 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

3.5.7 Safe Radio Connection Indication 

--- Document Chunk 2822 ---
3.5.7.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall inform the driver about the status of the 

--- Document Chunk 2823 ---
safe radio connection. To that purpose, the following indication statuses of the safe radio 

--- Document Chunk 2824 ---
connection are defined: “No Connection”, “Connection Lost/Set-Up failed”, “Connection 

--- Document Chunk 2825 ---
Up”. 

--- Document Chunk 2826 ---
3.5.7.2 In addition, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall use a “connection status” timer 

--- Document Chunk 2827 ---
(see Appendix A.3.1), in order to manage properly the transitions to the indication status 

--- Document Chunk 2828 ---
“Connection Lost/Set-Up failed”. 

--- Document Chunk 2829 ---
3.5.7.2.1 Note: The purpose of the “connection status” timer is to avoid distracting the driver for 

--- Document Chunk 2830 ---
any short disturbance of the safe radio connection. 

--- Document Chunk 2831 ---
3.5.7.3 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall start the “connection status” timer as soon 

--- Document Chunk 2832 ---
as the first request to set-up a safe radio connection with the relevant RBC/RIU is sent: 

--- Document Chunk 2833 ---
a) regarding the session establishment, see items b), c), d), e) in 3.5.3.4. 

--- Document Chunk 2834 ---
b) regarding maintaining a communication session, see 3.5.4.2 and 3.5.4.4 

--- Document Chunk 2835 ---
3.5.7.4 If the “connection status” timer is ongoing, it shall be stopped if the requests to set-up a 

--- Document Chunk 2836 ---
safe radio connection are stopped with the relevant RBC/RIU. 

--- Document Chunk 2837 ---
3.5.7.5 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall execute the transitions between the 

--- Document Chunk 2838 ---
different indication statuses of the safe radio connection with the relevant RBC/RIU as 

--- Document Chunk 2839 ---
described in Table 1 according to the conditions in Table 2 (see section 4.6.1 for details 

--- Document Chunk 2840 ---
about the symbols).

3.5.7.6 For the case of an RBC/RBC transition, the safe radio connection indicated to the driver 

--- Document Chunk 2890 ---
shall switch from the indication status of the safe radio connection with the Handing over 

--- Document Chunk 2891 ---
RBC to the one with the Accepting RBC as soon as one of the following conditions is 

--- Document Chunk 2892 ---
met: 

--- Document Chunk 2893 ---
a) the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment sends a position report directly to the 

--- Document Chunk 2894 ---
Accepting RBC wi th its maximum safe front end having passed the border, see 

--- Document Chunk 2895 ---
3.15.1.3.5 (i.e. the Accepting RBC becomes the supervising RBC), 

--- Document Chunk 2896 ---
b) the safe radio connection is released with the Handing over RBC and the minimum 

--- Document Chunk 2897 ---
safe rear end of the train has passed the border. 

--- Document Chunk 2898 ---
3.5.7.6.1 Note: During an RBC/RBC handover procedure, an indication status transition table and 

--- Document Chunk 2899 ---
a connection status timer might have to be managed at the same time, for each RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 2900 ---
3.5.7.7 For the case of safe radio connection with RIU’s, the safe radio connection indicated to  

--- Document Chunk 2901 ---
the driver shall be the one related to the current infill area. 

--- Document Chunk 2902 ---
3.6 Location Principles, Train Position and Train Orientation 

--- Document Chunk 2903 ---
3.6.1 General 

--- Document Chunk 2904 ---
3.6.1.1 Two types of location based information are defined: 

--- Document Chunk 2905 ---
a) Information that refers only to a given location, referred to as Location data (e.g. level 

--- Document Chunk 2906 ---
transition orders, linking) 

--- Document Chunk 2907 ---
b) Information that remains valid for a certain distance, referred to as Profile data (e.g. 

--- Document Chunk 2908 ---
SSP, gradient).  

--- Document Chunk 2909 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2910 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2911 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2912 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 2913 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 2914 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 2915 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 2916 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 2917 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 2918 ---
Page 32/252 

--- Document Chunk 2919 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2920 ---
3.6.1.2 Note: Determination of the Train Position  is always longitudinal along the route, even 

--- Document Chunk 2921 ---
though the route might be set through a complex track layout. 

--- Document Chunk 2922 ---
1       2     3

--- Document Chunk 2923 ---
4         5      6

--- Document Chunk 2924 ---
7

--- Document Chunk 2925 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2926 ---
Figure 6: Actual route of the train 

--- Document Chunk 2927 ---
1 5 7

--- Document Chunk 2928 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2929 ---
Figure 7: Route known by the train 

--- Document Chunk 2930 ---
3.6.1.3 The Train Position information defines the position of the train front in relation to a 

--- Document Chunk 2931 ---
reference balise group, which is called LRBG (the Last Relevant Balise Group) in case 

--- Document Chunk 2932 ---
the balise group is marked as linked and may be used for reporting the train position to 

--- Document Chunk 2933 ---
the RBC (i.e. the balise group is LRBG compliant, see 3.6.2.2.2 a)), and/or in relation to 

--- Document Chunk 2934 ---
other reference balise group s, which are called ORBGs (Other Reference Balise 

--- Document Chunk 2935 ---
Groups). 

--- Document Chunk 2936 ---
It includes for each of the reference balise groups (LRBG/ORBGs): 

--- Document Chunk 2937 ---
• The estimated train front end position, defined by the estimated distance between the 

--- Document Chunk 2938 ---
LRBG/ORBG and the front end of the train 

--- Document Chunk 2939 ---
• The train position confidence interval (see 3.6.4.1) 

--- Document Chunk 2940 ---
• Directional train position information in reference to the balise group orientation (see 

--- Document Chunk 2941 ---
3.4.2, also Figure 14) of the LRBG/ORBG, regarding: 

--- Document Chunk 2942 ---
− the position of the train front end (nominal or reverse side of the 

--- Document Chunk 2943 ---
LRBG/ORBG) 

--- Document Chunk 2944 ---
− the train orientation  

--- Document Chunk 2945 ---
− the train running direction 

--- Document Chunk 2946 ---
The ORBGs are at least the seven previous LRBGs last reported to the RBC, which 

--- Document Chunk 2947 ---
may alternatively be used by trackside for referencing location dependent information 

--- Document Chunk 2948 ---
(see 3.6.2.2.2 c)), the balise groups used as reference by information stored in any 

--- Document Chunk 2949 ---
of the transition buffers (see section 4.8), and either the last passed balise group 

--- Document Chunk 2950 ---
marked as unlinked or the last two passed balise groups marked as unlinked if there 

--- Document Chunk 2951 ---
is no balise group marked as linked in between. 

--- Document Chunk 2952 ---
3.6.1.3.1 Note: the train position information in relation to an ORBG is necessary to relocate all 

--- Document Chunk 2953 ---
location based information to the Single On-board Location Reference (SOLR), in case 

--- Document Chunk 2954 ---
no linking distance can be used (see section 3.6.4.2). 

--- Document Chunk 2955 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 2956 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2957 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2958 ---

--- Document Chunk 2962 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 2963 ---

--- Document Chunk 2964 ---
Page 33/252 

--- Document Chunk 2965 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 2966 ---
3.6.1.3.2 The status of the Train Position information (see 3.6.1.3) is defined as unknown in case 

--- Document Chunk 2967 ---
neither a train position in relation to an LRBG nor in relation to an ORBG is stored on-

--- Document Chunk 2968 ---
board. 

--- Document Chunk 2969 ---
3.6.1.3.3 Note: After the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment has been powered-off, a stored train 

--- Document Chunk 2970 ---
position remains in status “invalid” until it is either revalidated (status becomes “valid”) or 

--- Document Chunk 2971 ---
deleted (status becomes “unknown”). 

--- Document Chunk 2972 ---
3.6.1.3.4 The front end of the train refers to the front end of the engine with regards to the train 

--- Document Chunk 2973 ---
orientation. Exception: In Stand-By mode while no valid Train Data is available but the 

--- Document Chunk 2974 ---
safe consist length information is available, in Supervised Manoeuvre requests, and from 

--- Document Chunk 2975 ---
the time the first Supervised Manoeuvre authorisation is received to the time the mission 

--- Document Chunk 2976 ---
is either ended or continued in Non Leading mode, the estimated front end of the train 

--- Document Chunk 2977 ---
takes into account the nominal consist length in front of/in rear of the engine depending 

--- Document Chunk 2978 ---
on whether the train orientation is the same as/opposite to the active cab. 

--- Document Chunk 2979 ---
3.6.1.4 When the train position is unknown or invalid, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 2980 ---
shall consider that a valid train position is stored on -board as soon as an LRBG or an 

--- Document Chunk 2981 ---
ORBG has been passed and any previously stored invalid train position shall be deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2982 ---
3.6.1.4.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 2983 ---
3.6.1.5 If there is an active cab, this one defines the orientation of the train, i.e. the side of the 

--- Document Chunk 2984 ---
active cab shall be considered as determining the front of the train. If no cab is active, 

--- Document Chunk 2985 ---
the train orientation shall be defined by the last active cab. 

--- Document Chunk 2986 ---
3.6.1.5.1 Exception: from the time the first Supervised Manoeuvre authorisation is received to the 

--- Document Chunk 2987 ---
time the mission is either ended or continued in Non Leading mode, the train orientation 

--- Document Chunk 2988 ---
shall be determined by the direction of the Movement Authority in the last received 

--- Document Chunk 2989 ---
Supervised Manoeuvre authorisation, regardless of the position of th e engine in the 

--- Document Chunk 2990 ---
shunting consist and of which of its cab(s) is active. 

--- Document Chunk 2991 ---
3.6.1.5.2 Note: The train orientation cannot be affected by the direction controller position. 

--- Document Chunk 2992 ---
3.6.1.6 The estimated front end shall be used when supervising location based information, 

--- Document Chunk 2993 ---
unless stated otherwise. 

--- Document Chunk 2994 ---
3.6.1.7 The min safe rear end position shall be calculated by subtracting from the min safe front 

--- Document Chunk 2995 ---
end position, the train length stored as valid Train Data or if no valid Train Data is 

--- Document Chunk 2996 ---
available but the safe consist length information is available: 

--- Document Chunk 2997 ---
• the min safe consist length in front of the engine and the max safe consist length in 

--- Document Chunk 2998 ---
rear of the engine, if the train orientation is the same as the active cab, or 

--- Document Chunk 2999 ---
• the min safe consist length in rear of the engine and the max safe consist length in 

--- Document Chunk 3000 ---
front of the engine, if the train orientation is opposite to the active cab. 

--- Document Chunk 3001 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

3.6.2 Location reference of Data Transmitted to the On-Board Equipment 

--- Document Chunk 3013 ---
3.6.2.1 Data Transmitted by Balises 

--- Document Chunk 3014 ---
3.6.2.1.1 All location and profile data transmitted by a balise shall refer to the location reference 

--- Document Chunk 3015 ---
and orientation of the balise group to which the balise belongs. 

--- Document Chunk 3016 ---
3.6.2.1.2 Exception: Regarding infill information the section 3.6.2.3.1 shall apply. 

--- Document Chunk 3017 ---
3.6.2.2 Data Transmitted by Radio from RBC 

--- Document Chunk 3018 ---
3.6.2.2.1 All location and profile data transmitted from the RBC shall refer to the location reference 

--- Document Chunk 3019 ---
and orientation of the LRBG given in the same message. 

--- Document Chunk 3020 ---
3.6.2.2.2 For the LRBG the following requirements have to be met: 

--- Document Chunk 3021 ---
a) The on-board equipment shall use as a reference for reporting the train position to the 

--- Document Chunk 3022 ---
RBC the last passed LRBG compliant balise group that fulfils the conditions of the 

--- Document Chunk 3023 ---
clause 3.6.5.1.8. 

--- Document Chunk 3024 ---
This balise group is termed as LRBGONB in the following. 

--- Document Chunk 3025 ---
Only  

--- Document Chunk 3026 ---
• balise groups marked as linked and contained in the previously received linking 

--- Document Chunk 3027 ---
information, if linking consistency is checked on-board 

--- Document Chunk 3028 ---
 or  

--- Document Chunk 3029 ---
• balise groups not marked as unlinked, if linking consistency was not checked when 

--- Document Chunk 3030 ---
such a balise group was passed 

--- Document Chunk 3031 ---
shall be regarded as LRBG compliant balise groups. 

--- Document Chunk 3032 ---
b) The RBC shall use a balise group which was reported by the on-board equipment as 

--- Document Chunk 3033 ---
a reference (in the following termed as LRBGRBC). At a certain moment LRBGRBC and 

--- Document Chunk 3034 ---
LRBGONB can be different. 

--- Document Chunk 3035 ---
c) The on-board equipment shall be able to accept information referring to one of at least 

--- Document Chunk 3036 ---
eight LRBGONB last reported to the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 3037 ---
3.6.2.2.2.1 Exception to a): When the train position is unknown, or when position data has been 

--- Document Chunk 3038 ---
deleted during SoM procedure , or when the train position is valid or invalid but only 

--- Document Chunk 3039 ---
referred to a balise group marked as unlinked , the on-board equipment shall use an 

--- Document Chunk 3040 ---
LRBG identifier set to "unknown" until the onboard has passed an LRBG compliant balise 

--- Document Chunk 3041 ---
group that fulfils the conditions of the clause 3.6.5.1.8. 

--- Document Chunk 3042 ---
3.6.2.2.2.2 Exception to b): When the RBC has received from the onboard an unknown position (as 

--- Document Chunk 3043 ---
per 3.6.2.2.2.1)  or during SoM procedure an invalid position which it  is not able to 

--- Document Chunk 3044 ---
confirm, the RBC shall use an LRBG identifier set to "unknown" until it receives a position 

--- Document Chunk 3045 ---
report from the onboard having pass ed an LRBG compliant balise group that fulfils the 

--- Document Chunk 3046 ---
conditions of the clause 3.6.5.1.8. 

--- Document Chunk 3047 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

3.6.3 Validity direction of transmitted information 

--- Document Chunk 3148 ---
3.6.3.1 General 

--- Document Chunk 3149 ---
3.6.3.1.1 The direction for which transmitted information is valid shall refer to: 

--- Document Chunk 3150 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 3151 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3152 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3153 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 3154 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 3155 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 3156 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 3157 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 3158 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 3159 ---
Page 37/252 

--- Document Chunk 3160 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3161 ---
a) the LRBG orientation for information sent by radio 

--- Document Chunk 3162 ---
b) the balise group orientation for information sent by this balise group 

--- Document Chunk 3163 ---
c) the loop orientation (which refers itself to the orientation of the balise group 

--- Document Chunk 3164 ---
transmitting the EOLM information, see 3.4.5.1.3) for information sent by this loop 

--- Document Chunk 3165 ---
3.6.3.1.2 Data transmitted to the on-board equipment shall be identified as being valid for 

--- Document Chunk 3166 ---
a) both directions 

--- Document Chunk 3167 ---
b) the nominal direction 

--- Document Chunk 3168 ---
c) the reverse direction 

--- Document Chunk 3169 ---
of the referenced balise group (for information sent by balise or radio) or of the loop (for 

--- Document Chunk 3170 ---
information sent by loop). 

--- Document Chunk 3171 ---
3.6.3.1.2.1 Deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 3172 ---
3.6.3.1.3 When receiving information from any transmission medium, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board 

--- Document Chunk 3173 ---
equipment shall only take into account information valid for the train orientation. Other 

--- Document Chunk 3174 ---
information shall be ignored. 

--- Document Chunk 3175 ---
3.6.3.1.3.1 Exception 1: for SL, PS and SH engines, balise group crossing direction shall be 

--- Document Chunk 3176 ---
considered. 

--- Document Chunk 3177 ---
3.6.3.1.3.2 Exception 2: information in a Supervised Manoeuvre authorisation shall be taken into 

--- Document Chunk 3178 ---
account also when its validity direction is opposite to that of the current train orientation 

--- Document Chunk 3179 ---
3.6.3.1.4 If the train orientation cannot be referred to a direction of the trackside device to which 

--- Document Chunk 3180 ---
the transmitted information refers  (or for SL, PS and SH engines if the balise group 

--- Document Chunk 3181 ---
crossing direction is unknown), data received from any transmission medium valid for 

--- Document Chunk 3182 ---
one direction only (nominal or reverse) shall be rejected by the onboard equipment. Data 

--- Document Chunk 3183 ---
valid for both directions shall be evaluated (see section 4.8). 

--- Document Chunk 3184 ---
3.6.3.1.4.1 Exception: if not rejected due to balise group message consistency check (see 

--- Document Chunk 3185 ---
3.16.2.4.4.1 and 3.16.2.5.1.1), data to be forwarded to a National System (see section 

--- Document Chunk 3186 ---
3.15.6) valid for one direction only shall be accepted. Jus tification: the co -ordinate 

--- Document Chunk 3187 ---
system of the balise group might be known to the National System by other means 

--- Document Chunk 3188 ---
inherent to the National System itself. 

--- Document Chunk 3189 ---
3.6.3.1.4.2 Note: the clause 3.6.3.1. 4 applies for example if no co -ordinate system has been 

--- Document Chunk 3190 ---
assigned to a single balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 3191 ---
Figure 11: Intentionally deleted

--- Document Chunk 3226 ---
Figure 12: General Structure of location and profile data 

--- Document Chunk 3227 ---
3.6.3.2.2 With regard to Figure 12 the following applies to continuous profile data: 

--- Document Chunk 3228 ---
a) Value (n) shall be valid for distance (n+1)  

--- Document Chunk 3229 ---
b) For distance (1) the previously received data shall be used (in case of an SSP this 

--- Document Chunk 3230 ---
includes train length delay, refer to 3.11.3.1.3). 

--- Document Chunk 3231 ---
c) Distances shall be given as unsigned incremental values representing the distance 

--- Document Chunk 3232 ---
between value(n) and value(n-1). 

--- Document Chunk 3233 ---
d) The last value (n) transmitted shall be valid for an unlimited distance unless value(n) 

--- Document Chunk 3234 ---
represents a special "end of profile" value. 

--- Document Chunk 3235 ---
e) If distance (n+1) = 0 then the corresponding profile value n shall still be taken into 

--- Document Chunk 3236 ---
account. 

--- Document Chunk 3237 ---
3.6.3.2.3 With regard to Figure 12 the following shall apply to location data: 

--- Document Chunk 3238 ---
a) Distances shall be given as unsigned incremental values representing the distance 

--- Document Chunk 3239 ---
between value(n) and value(n-1). 

--- Document Chunk 3240 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 3241 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3242 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3243 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 3244 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 3245 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 3246 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 3247 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 3248 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 3249 ---
Page 39/252 

--- Document Chunk 3250 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3251 ---
b) For distance (1) the previously received data shall be used. 

--- Document Chunk 3252 ---
c) Each value (n) may represent a single value or a set of data. 

--- Document Chunk 3253 ---
3.6.3.2.4 According to Figure 12 the structure for non-continuous profile data shall allow to contain 

--- Document Chunk 3254 ---
multiple elements (value(n) for length(n)) inside the profile.  

--- Document Chunk 3255 ---
a) Distance to the start of each element (value(n) for length(n)) shall be given as 

--- Document Chunk 3256 ---
unsigned incremental values , each increment representing the distance between  

--- Document Chunk 3257 ---
starts of element (n) and element (n-1). 

--- Document Chunk 3258 ---
b) For distance (1) the previously received data (or initial data/default values, see section 

--- Document Chunk 3259 ---
3.7) shall be used. 

--- Document Chunk 3260 ---
c) Each value (n) may represent a single value or a set of data.  

--- Document Chunk 3261 ---
d) Note: There is no relationship between length of element (n-1) and distance (n), i.e., 

--- Document Chunk 3262 ---
elements may overlap. 

--- Document Chunk 3263 ---
3.6.3.2.5 It shall be possible for the RBC to shift the location reference, e.g., after a change of train 

--- Document Chunk 3264 ---
orientation or running direction. 

--- Document Chunk 3265 ---
3.6.3.2.5.1 Justification: Refer to Figure 13. To make it possible to shift the location reference if – 

--- Document Chunk 3266 ---
due to the location of the LRBG and the start location – distance (1) would become a 

--- Document Chunk 3267 ---
negative value. 

--- Document Chunk 3268 ---
LRBG

--- Document Chunk 3269 ---
direction  with regard

--- Document Chunk 3270 ---
to location reference

--- Document Chunk 3271 ---
 value(1)  value(2)

--- Document Chunk 3272 ---

ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

a) The distance (1) shall be given to the first balise group included in the linking 

--- Document Chunk 3294 ---
information 

--- Document Chunk 3295 ---
b) The distance (n) shall be given as th e distance between two consecutive balise

groups

3.6.4 Train Position Confidence Interval and Relocation 

--- Document Chunk 3299 ---
3.6.4.1 Train Position Confidence Interval 

--- Document Chunk 3300 ---
3.6.4.1.1 The confidence interval to the train position refers to the distance to the reference balise 

--- Document Chunk 3301 ---
group and takes into account 

--- Document Chunk 3302 ---
a) On-board over-reading amount and under -reading amount , which include among 

--- Document Chunk 3303 ---
other things the odometer accuracy and the error in detection of  the balise group 

--- Document Chunk 3304 ---
location reference. 

--- Document Chunk 3305 ---
b) The location accuracy of the reference balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 3306 ---
3.6.4.1.2 Note: The confidence interval increases in relation to the distance travelled from the 

--- Document Chunk 3307 ---
reference balise group depending on the accuracy of odometer equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 3308 ---
3.6.4.1.3 The value of the Locatio n Accuracy shall be determined by Linking information when it 

--- Document Chunk 3309 ---
becomes available, or, if it has not been previously determined by Linking information 

--- Document Chunk 3310 ---
when the balise group becomes LRBG or ORBG , by the corresponding National Value 

--- Document Chunk 3311 ---
or the corresponding Default Value if the National Value is not applicable. 

--- Document Chunk 3312 ---
3.6.4.1.4 Once the location accuracy of a balise group has been determined according to the 

--- Document Chunk 3313 ---
clause 3.6.4.1.3, it shall not be updated (e.g. neither upon reception of further Linking 

--- Document Chunk 3314 ---
information, nor when linking is no  longer checked, nor when new National Values 

--- Document Chunk 3315 ---
becomes applicable). 

--- Document Chunk 3316 ---
3.6.4.1.5 The confidence interval to the train front end position shall be delimited by: 

--- Document Chunk 3317 ---
a) The min(imum) safe front end position, which is in rear (in relation to the orientation 

--- Document Chunk 3318 ---
of the train) of the estimated train front end position at a distance calculated as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 3319 ---
𝐿𝑑𝑜𝑢𝑏𝑡𝑜𝑣𝑒𝑟 = 𝑄𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑐𝑐−𝑟𝑒𝑓𝐵𝐺 +overreading amount + 𝛾⋅𝐿𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑜𝑣𝑒𝑟 

--- Document Chunk 3320 ---
b) The max(imum) safe front end position, which is in advance (in relation to the 

--- Document Chunk 3321 ---
orientation of the train) of the estimated train front end position at a distance calculated 

--- Document Chunk 3322 ---
as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 3323 ---
 𝐿𝑑𝑜𝑢𝑏𝑡𝑢𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑟 =𝑄𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑐𝑐−𝑟𝑒𝑓𝐵𝐺 +underreading amount + 𝛾⋅𝐿𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑢𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑟 

--- Document Chunk 3324 ---
With 𝛾=1 only in Stand -By mode while no valid Train Data is available but the safe 

--- Document Chunk 3325 ---
consist length information is available, in Supervised Manoeuvre requests, and from the 

--- Document Chunk 3326 ---
time the first Supervised Manoeuvre authorisation is received to the time the mission is 

--- Document Chunk 3327 ---
either ended or continued in Non Leading mode, and with 𝐿𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑜𝑣𝑒𝑟 & 𝐿𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑢𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑟 

--- Document Chunk 3328 ---
determined as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 3329 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

• 𝐿𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑢𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑟 is the difference between the Train Data max safe consist length and 

--- Document Chunk 3341 ---
nominal consist length in front of/in rear of the engine, depending on whether 

--- Document Chunk 3342 ---

--- Document Chunk 3344 ---
min safe consist length in front of/in rear of the engine, depending on whether 

--- Document Chunk 3345 ---
the train orientation is the same as/opposite to the active cab respectively.

Otherwise 𝛾=0

--- Document Chunk 3349 ---
3.6.4.2 Relocation 

--- Document Chunk 3350 ---
3.6.4.2.1 The relocation consists in changing the reference location of all location based 

--- Document Chunk 3351 ---
information handled by the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment, so that as soon it is used 

--- Document Chunk 3352 ---
and at any further time it is referred to the Single On-board Location Reference (SOLR). 

--- Document Chunk 3353 ---
3.6.4.2.2 The Single On-board Location Reference (SOLR) shall be: 

--- Document Chunk 3354 ---
a) the last received balise group t hat is the reference of linking information or that is 

--- Document Chunk 3355 ---
announced in linking information (including if it is announced with a balise group with 

--- Document Chunk 3356 ---
ID “unknown” and it contains repositioning information), while the linking consistency 

--- Document Chunk 3357 ---
is checked (see 3.4.4.2.1.1), or 

--- Document Chunk 3358 ---
b) the last received balise group, while no linking consistency is checked. 

--- Document Chunk 3359 ---
3.6.4.2.2.1 Exception to 3.6.4.2.2 b): when exiting N o Power mode, the SOLR shall be set to the 

--- Document Chunk 3360 ---
stored LRBG if any. 

--- Document Chunk 3361 ---
3.6.4.2.2.2 Whenever linking information is received (e.g. when it is released from the transition 

--- Document Chunk 3362 ---
buffer), the clause 3.7.3.1 m) shall be applied before this clause 3.6.4.2.2. For all other 

--- Document Chunk 3363 ---
information, any relocation to the SOLR resulting from this clause 3.6.4.2.2 shall take 

--- Document Chunk 3364 ---
place before the corresponding item of the clause 3.7.3.1 is applied. 

--- Document Chunk 3365 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 3366 ---
Q_LOCACC(1) Q_LOCACC(1) 

--- Document Chunk 3367 ---
Q_LOCACC(1) under-reading 

--- Document Chunk 3368 ---
amount Q_LOCACC(1) over-reading

amount

3.6.4.2.2.3 Note: the SOLR is generally equal to the LRBG ONB. For some cases however, like the 

--- Document Chunk 3392 ---
transition to level 1/2 area, it might be possible that the linking information released from 

--- Document Chunk 3393 ---
the transition buffer provokes the change of SOLR to a former LRBG in case this 

--- Document Chunk 3394 ---
information does not announce every balise group in rear of the border (see Figure 13e). 

--- Document Chunk 3395 ---
3.6.4.2.3 Before it can be relocated, all location based information received from trackside shall 

--- Document Chunk 3396 ---
be first processed by the on -board equipment into a series of indivi dual location items 

--- Document Chunk 3397 ---
each of them being referred to an individual distance to the reference balise group of the 

--- Document Chunk 3398 ---
location based information, this distance being counted positive/negative depending on 

--- Document Chunk 3399 ---
whether the location item is in advance of/in rear of the reference balise group with 

--- Document Chunk 3400 ---
regards to the train orientation. 

--- Document Chunk 3401 ---
3.6.4.2.4 For a given location based information (e.g. EOA), up to three individual location items 

--- Document Chunk 3402 ---
can be defined, as stipulated in Table 2a. Whenever a (or a part of a) clause of the ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 3403 ---
specifications is mentioned in this Table 2a, it shall be applied by the ERTMS/ETCS on-

--- Document Chunk 3404 ---
board equipment using the corresponding types of location item.

--- Document Chunk 3506 ---

--- Document Chunk 3507 ---

--- Document Chunk 3508 ---

--- Document Chunk 4307 ---
Table 2a: Correspondence between location items and 

--- Document Chunk 4308 ---
clauses in the ETCS specifications using them 

--- Document Chunk 4309 ---
3.6.4.2.4.1 Note 1: an individual location based information can be classified as several types of 

--- Document Chunk 4310 ---
location items. For example, the EOA location is an "estimated" location item to define 

--- Document Chunk 4311 ---
SBD foot, a "min" location item to provoke entry into Trip mode and a "max" location item 

--- Document Chunk 4312 ---
if it defines the SvL. As a second example, a single TSR encompasses two locat ion 

--- Document Chunk 4313 ---
items, i.e. a "max" location item at its start location and a "min" location item at its end 

--- Document Chunk 4314 ---
location. Classification of TSR location item, as true for any Speed Restriction, is 

--- Document Chunk 4315 ---
indirectly deduced from the fact that V_MRSP is obtained with the min safe front end and 

--- Document Chunk 4316 ---
the max safe front end of the train as per clause 3.13.10.2.8. 

--- Document Chunk 4317 ---
3.6.4.2.4.2 Note 2: in general (but not necessarily for all the functions), an “estimated”/”min”/”max” 

--- Document Chunk 4318 ---
location item is used to apply a clause when this latter involves a comparison against the 

--- Document Chunk 4319 ---
estimated front end position/min safe rear end position or the min safe antenna position/ 

--- Document Chunk 4320 ---
max safe front end position or the max safe antenna position. 

--- Document Chunk 4321 ---
3.6.4.2.4.3 Note 3: as long as linking distance(s) can be used to perform the relocation, several 

--- Document Chunk 4322 ---
items associated to a given location based information will be referred with the same 

--- Document Chunk 4323 ---
distance to the SOLR by the on -board. Otherwise, these location items (e.g. “min”, 

--- Document Chunk 4324 ---
“estimated” and “max” MA section ends) will be referred to the SOLR with different 

--- Document Chunk 4325 ---
distances, after a relocation as per clause 3.6.4.2.5 b) or c) has taken place. 

--- Document Chunk 4326 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4327 ---

--- Document Chunk 4337 ---
3.6.4.2.5 When a balise group becomes the SOLR or when evaluating (see section 4.8) location 

--- Document Chunk 4338 ---
based trackside information, which is referred to a balise group different from the SOLR, 

--- Document Chunk 4339 ---
every location item shall be relocated to the SOLR by subtracting from the distance to its 

--- Document Chunk 4340 ---
former reference balise group (FRBG): 

--- Document Chunk 4341 ---
a) the distance between the FRBG and the SOLR, retrieved from linking information if it 

--- Document Chunk 4342 ---
is available and known (i.e. no linking distance to a repositioning balise group being 

--- Document Chunk 4343 ---
encountered between these balise groups) and, if any, the last relocation of this 

--- Document Chunk 4344 ---
location item has not been performed as per clause 3.6.4.2.5 c), OR 

--- Document Chunk 4345 ---
b) if the last relocation of this location item has been performed as per clause 3.6.4.2.5 

--- Document Chunk 4346 ---
c) towards a BG not received earlier than the reference BG of this location item, the 

--- Document Chunk 4347 ---
distance between the FRBG and the SOLR retrieved from link ing information if it is 

--- Document Chunk 4348 ---
available and known (i.e. no linking distance to a repositioning balise group being 

--- Document Chunk 4349 ---
encountered between these balise groups): 

--- Document Chunk 4350 ---
• as such, for "estimated" location items, 

--- Document Chunk 4351 ---
• diminished by twice the location accuracy of the FRBG, for "min" location items, 

--- Document Chunk 4352 ---
• augmented by twice the location accurac y of the FRBG, for "max" location 

--- Document Chunk 4353 ---
items, OR 

--- Document Chunk 4354 ---
c) in all other cases, the estimated , min or max  travelled distance between the FRBG 

--- Document Chunk 4355 ---
and the SOLR, computed as per clauses 3.6.1.3 and 3.6.4.1. 5 from train fro nt end 

--- Document Chunk 4356 ---
positions in reference to FRBG and to SOLR, as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 4357 ---
• (estimated front end position against FRBG – estimated front end position 

--- Document Chunk 4358 ---
against SOLR) for "estimated" location items, 

--- Document Chunk 4359 ---
• (min safe front end position against FRBG – min safe front end position against 

--- Document Chunk 4360 ---
SOLR) for "min" location items, 

--- Document Chunk 4361 ---
• (max safe front end position against FRBG – max safe front end position against 

--- Document Chunk 4362 ---
SOLR) for "max" location items. 

--- Document Chunk 4363 ---
3.6.4.2.5.1 Note 1: For infill information or when evaluating information from a balise group marked 

--- Document Chunk 4364 ---
as unlinked while linking consistency is checked, the distances used for relocation will 

--- Document Chunk 4365 ---
always be negative and will result in an increase of the supervised distances to the 

--- Document Chunk 4366 ---
location items (because they are relocated back to the SOLR). 

--- Document Chunk 4367 ---
3.6.4.2.5.2 Note 2: The FRBG can be the former S OLR, a balise group that does not become the 

--- Document Chunk 4368 ---
SOLR (e.g. an unlinked balise group while linking consistency is checked), a balise group 

--- Document Chunk 4369 ---
that has transmitted information that has been stored in the transition buffer , the LRBG 

--- Document Chunk 4370 ---
used in an RBC message or an infill location reference. 

--- Document Chunk 4371 ---
3.6.4.2.5.3 Note 3: All reference balise groups that are used in clause 3.6.4.2.5 are listed in Train 

--- Document Chunk 4372 ---
Position defined in 3.6.1.3. Furthermore, the list of the location items that was relocated 

--- Document Chunk 4373 ---
as per clause 3.6.4.2.5 c) needs also to be memorised to apply this clause 3.6.4.2.5. 

--- Document Chunk 4374 ---
3.6.4.2.5.4 Note 4: By principle, the relocation from former SOLR to new SOLR done by clause 

--- Document Chunk 4375 ---
3.6.4.2.5 c) has no effect on the supervision of the location items, because the same 

--- Document Chunk 4376 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 4386 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4387 ---
change of distances within the Train Position is applied inversely to the distances of the 

--- Document Chunk 4388 ---
location items. 

--- Document Chunk 4389 ---
3.6.4.2.5.5 Note 5: The supervision of distances on -board will always be safe using these rules, 

--- Document Chunk 4390 ---
together with the SUBSET -040 §4.6.1.1 rule as prerequisite. If the trackside wants to 

--- Document Chunk 4391 ---
increase the performance, it is  its responsibility to provide linking in due course or to 

--- Document Chunk 4392 ---
repeat the location based information in reference to further balise groups. 

--- Document Chunk 4393 ---
3.6.4.2.6 Regarding the continuous profiles (i.e. SSP and gradient): if a relocation as per clause 

--- Document Chunk 4394 ---
3.6.4.2.5 b) or c) results in at least one change of value being relocated in rear of one or 

--- Document Chunk 4395 ---
more preceding change(s) of  value, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 4396 ---
recompose the continuous profile according to the following steps: 

--- Document Chunk 4397 ---
• Step 1: For each concerned set of consecutive changes of value, the on-board shall 

--- Document Chunk 4398 ---
consider the profile as if it would have been received from trackside with, by exception 

--- Document Chunk 4399 ---
to 3.6.3.2.2 c), an incremental distance being negative from the furthest in advance 

--- Document Chunk 4400 ---
concerned change of value to the furthest in rear concerned change of value; 

--- Document Chunk 4401 ---
• Step 2: From the end location to the start location of each “reverted” element(s) 

--- Document Chunk 4402 ---
delimited by a negative incremental distance, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 4403 ---
shall retain the lowest parts of the overlapping elements obtained from step 1; 

--- Document Chunk 4404 ---
• Step 3: The clause 3.6.4.2.3 shall be applied to the profile obtained from step 2, 

--- Document Chunk 4405 ---
resulting in a continuous profile with all discontinuities ordered by increasing individual 

--- Document Chunk 4406 ---
distances referred to the SOLR, as if this profile would have been re ceived by 

--- Document Chunk 4407 ---
trackside being compliant with 3.6. 3.2.2 (i.e. with only unsigned incremental 

--- Document Chunk 4408 ---
distances). 

--- Document Chunk 4409 ---
3.6.4.2.6.1 Note: the recomposed profile obtained from the clause 3.6.4.2.6 may include less 

--- Document Chunk 4410 ---
elements than the profile before relocation, possibly with the original change(s) to higher 

--- Document Chunk 4411 ---
value no longer present depending on the respective speed/gradient values of the 

--- Document Chunk 4412 ---
concerned overlapping elements considered in steps 1 and 2.

When the on-board performs the transition to level 2, the location items of the MA 

--- Document Chunk 4481 ---
stored on-board (referred to balise group 0) are relocated prior to its evaluation: 

--- Document Chunk 4482 ---
• If balise group 1 is still the LRBG/SOLR, the first MA Section end is relocated by 

--- Document Chunk 4483 ---
subtracting D_LINK (1) from MA Section (1) length, to obtain the distance from the 

--- Document Chunk 4484 ---
SOLR to the MA section end (1’) 

--- Document Chunk 4485 ---
• If balise group 2 is already the LRBG/SOLR, the first MA Section end is relocated 

--- Document Chunk 4486 ---
by subtracting (D_LINK (1) + D_LINK (2)) from MA Section (1) length, to obtain the 

--- Document Chunk 4487 ---
distance from the SOLR to the MA section end (1”) 

--- Document Chunk 4488 ---
• The same goes for the second MA Section end, i.e. the distance from the SOLR 

--- Document Chunk 4489 ---
to the MA section end (2’) or (2’’) are obtained by substracting D_LINK (1) or 

--- Document Chunk 4490 ---
(D_LINK (1) + D_LINK (2)) from (MA Section (1) length + MA Section (2) length ) 

--- Document Chunk 4491 ---

--- Document Chunk 4523 ---
• 1st relocation: When the ERTMS/ETCS on-board reads UBG1, it does not become the SOLR, 

--- Document Chunk 4524 ---
so that the location items of the TSR within the message it provides are relocated by clause 

--- Document Chunk 4525 ---
3.6.4.2.5c on BG1 (which was received earlier) which is the SOLR at that time: 

--- Document Chunk 4526 ---
➢ the absolute value of the difference between the max safe front end positions against 

--- Document Chunk 4527 ---
BG1 and against UBG1 is added (substraction of a negative difference) to D_TSR 

--- Document Chunk 4528 ---
("max" location item). 

--- Document Chunk 4529 ---
➢ the absolute value of the difference between the min safe front end positions against 

--- Document Chunk 4530 ---
BG1 and against UBG1 is added (substraction of a negative difference) to (D_TSR + 

--- Document Chunk 4531 ---
L_TSR) ("min" location item). 

--- Document Chunk 4532 ---
The start & end locations of the TSR are handled independently ; the original L_TSR is not 

--- Document Chunk 4533 ---
used as a separate variable by the relocation process. 

--- Document Chunk 4534 ---
• 2nd relocation: When the ERTMS/ETCS on-board reads BG2, it becomes the new SOLR, so 

--- Document Chunk 4535 ---
that the TSR location items are relocated on it: despite linking distance is available between 

--- Document Chunk 4536 ---
BG1 and BG2, the relocation of the TSR location items is neither performed by clause 

--- Document Chunk 4537 ---
3.6.4.2.5a nor by clause 3.6.4.2.5b, as the last relocation of the TSR location items has been 

--- Document Chunk 4538 ---
performed by clause 3.6.4.2.5c to a balise group, which was received earlier than the former 

--- Document Chunk 4539 ---
reference balise group of the TSR location items, so: 

--- Document Chunk 4540 ---
➢ the absolute value of the difference between the max safe front end positions against 

--- Document Chunk 4541 ---
BG1 and against BG2 is subtracted from D_TSR ("max" location item). 

--- Document Chunk 4542 ---
➢ the absolute value of the difference between the min safe front end positions against 

--- Document Chunk 4543 ---
BG1 and against BG2 is subtracted from (D_TSR + L_TSR) ("min" location item). 

--- Document Chunk 4544 ---
Each location item has to be handled independently. This example only covers the TSR 

--- Document Chunk 4545 ---
location items. 

--- Document Chunk 4546 ---
• 3rd relocation: When the ERTMS/ETCS on-board reads BG3, it becomes the new SOLR, so 

--- Document Chunk 4547 ---
that the TSR location items are relocated on it: linking distance is available between BG2 and 

--- Document Chunk 4548 ---
BG3 and it is used for the relocation of the TSR location items, as the last relocation of the TSR 

--- Document Chunk 4549 ---
location items has been performed by clause 3.6.4.2.5c but not towards a balise group received 

--- Document Chunk 4550 ---
earlier than the former reference balise group of the TSR location items, so: 

--- Document Chunk 4551 ---
➢ the linking distance between BG2 and BG3, retrieved from linking information and 

--- Document Chunk 4552 ---
augmented by twice the location accuracy of BG2, is subtracted from D_TSR. 

--- Document Chunk 4553 ---
➢ the linking distance between BG2 and BG3, retrieved from linking information and 

--- Document Chunk 4554 ---
diminished by twice the location accuracy of BG2, is subtracted from (D_TSR + L_TSR). 

--- Document Chunk 4555 ---
• 4th relocation: When the ERTMS/ETCS on-board reads BG4, it becomes the new SOLR, so 

--- Document Chunk 4556 ---
that the TSR location items are relocated on it: linking distance is available between BG3 and 

--- Document Chunk 4557 ---
BG4 and it is used as such for the relocation of the TSR location items, as the last relocation of 

--- Document Chunk 4558 ---
the TSR location items has not been performed by clause 3.6.4.2.5c, so: 

--- Document Chunk 4559 ---
➢ the linking distance between BG3 and BG4, retrieved from linking information, is 

--- Document Chunk 4560 ---
subtracted from D_TSR. 

--- Document Chunk 4561 ---
➢ the linking distance between BG3 and BG4, retrieved from linking information, is 

--- Document Chunk 4562 ---
subtracted from (D_TSR + L_TSR). 

--- Document Chunk 4563 ---

3.6.5 Position Reporting to the RBC 

--- Document Chunk 4634 ---
3.6.5.1 General 

--- Document Chunk 4635 ---
3.6.5.1.1 The position refers to the front end of the train , as per clause 3.6.1.3.4. 

--- Document Chunk 4636 ---
3.6.5.1.1.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 4637 ---
3.6.5.1.2 The position report shall contain at least the following position and direction data 

--- Document Chunk 4638 ---
a) The distance between the LRBG and the estimated front end of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 4639 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4640 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4641 ---

--- Document Chunk 4646 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 4647 ---

--- Document Chunk 4648 ---
Page 60/252 

--- Document Chunk 4649 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4650 ---
b) The train position confidence interval in relation to the LRBG, given as  the distance 

--- Document Chunk 4651 ---
from the estimated front end position to the min safe front end position and t he 

--- Document Chunk 4652 ---
distance from the estimated front end position to the max safe front end position. 

--- Document Chunk 4653 ---
c) The identity of the location reference, the LRBG. 

--- Document Chunk 4654 ---
d) The orientation of the train in relation to the LRBG orientation.  

--- Document Chunk 4655 ---
Note: Driver selected running direction is only handled by the on-board system. 

--- Document Chunk 4656 ---
e) The position of the front end of the train in relation to the LRBG (nominal or reverse 

--- Document Chunk 4657 ---
side of the LRBG). 

--- Document Chunk 4658 ---
f) Whether the train is at standstill or, if it is not at standstill, its estimated speed 

--- Document Chunk 4659 ---
g) Train integrity information. 

--- Document Chunk 4660 ---
h) Direction of train movement in relation to the LRBG orientation 

--- Document Chunk 4661 ---
i) Optionally, the previous LRBG. In case of an LRBG being a single balise group with 

--- Document Chunk 4662 ---
no co-ordinate system assigned, directional information referred to in items d), e) and 

--- Document Chunk 4663 ---
h) is defined in reference to the pair of LRBG and previous LRBG (see 3.4.2.3.3).

--- Document Chunk 4710 ---
3.6.5.1.3 Note: A balise group marked as unlinked is never used for position reporting to the RBC, 

--- Document Chunk 4711 ---
since its location, or the balise group itself, may not be known to the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 4712 ---
3.6.5.1.4 The on-board equipment shall send position reports as requested by the RBC in  the 

--- Document Chunk 4713 ---
position report parameters. In addition, it shall also send a position report if at least one 

--- Document Chunk 4714 ---
of the events listed hereafter occurs: 

--- Document Chunk 4715 ---
a) The train reaches standstill. 

--- Document Chunk 4716 ---
b) The mode changes. 

--- Document Chunk 4717 ---
c) The driver confirms train integrity. 

--- Document Chunk 4718 ---
d) A loss of train integrity is detected. 

--- Document Chunk 4719 ---
e) The train passes an RBC/RBC border with its min safe rear end. 

--- Document Chunk 4720 ---
f) The train passe s with its min safe rear end a level transition border which led to a 

--- Document Chunk 4721 ---
transition from level 2 to level 0, NTC or 1. 

--- Document Chunk 4722 ---
g) The level changes. 

--- Document Chunk 4723 ---
h) A communication session is successfully established. 

--- Document Chunk 4724 ---
i) The train leaves standstill. 

--- Document Chunk 4725 ---
j) The train passes  an LRBG compliant balise group (see 3.6.2.2.2  a)), if no position 

--- Document Chunk 4726 ---
report parameters are stored on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 4727 ---
k) The train passes an RBC/RBC border with its max safe front end. 

--- Document Chunk 4728 ---
l) An error as defined in 3.16.4 is detected. 

--- Document Chunk 4729 ---
3.6.5.1.4.1 If the position report results from one or more events listed in 3.6.5.1.4, its content shall 

--- Document Chunk 4730 ---
reflect the consequences of these events. 

--- Document Chunk 4731 ---
3.6.5.1.5 For the position report parameters requested by the RBC the following possibilities shall 

--- Document Chunk 4732 ---
be available, individually or in combination 

--- Document Chunk 4733 ---
a) Periodically in time. 

--- Document Chunk 4734 ---
b) Periodically in space. 

--- Document Chunk 4735 ---
c) When the max safe front end or min safe rear end of the train has passed a specified 

--- Document Chunk 4736 ---
location. 

--- Document Chunk 4737 ---
d) At every passage of an LRBG compliant balise group (see 3.6.2.2.2 a)). 

--- Document Chunk 4738 ---
e) Immediately. 

--- Document Chunk 4739 ---
3.6.5.1.5.1 Exception: it shall not be possible to combine d) and e). 

--- Document Chunk 4740 ---
3.6.5.1.6 Regarding 3.6.5.1.4 j) and 3.6.5.1.5 d): the position report triggered by the passage of 

--- Document Chunk 4741 ---
an LRBG compliant balise group shall be sent only once the content of th e message 

--- Document Chunk 4742 ---
from this balise group has been taken into account. 

--- Document Chunk 4743 ---
3.6.5.1.7 The given position report parameters shall be valid until new parameters are given from 

--- Document Chunk 4744 ---
the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 4745 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 4756 ---
3.6.5.1.8 After an LRBG compliant balise group is passed, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 4757 ---
shall be allowed to report the train position with this balise group as reference only once 

--- Document Chunk 4758 ---
the content of the message from this balise group and the content of the messages from 

--- Document Chunk 4759 ---
all the previous LRBG compliant balise groups (if any) have been taken into account. 

--- Document Chunk 4760 ---
3.6.5.1.8.1 Justification: The mode and level reported in a position report must be consistent with 

--- Document Chunk 4761 ---
the content of the message of the LRBG used in this position report (e.g. if the reported 

--- Document Chunk 4762 ---
train position is within an OS/SH/LS area provided by a Mode Profile given by the LRBG 

--- Document Chunk 4763 ---
used in this position report, the reported mode will be the one requested by the Mode 

--- Document Chunk 4764 ---
Profile). 

--- Document Chunk 4765 ---
3.6.5.2 Report of train integrity information 

--- Document Chunk 4766 ---
3.6.5.2.1 The confirmation of train integrity may be given by external source or by driver. For the 

--- Document Chunk 4767 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment, the confirmation of train integrity means that the 

--- Document Chunk 4768 ---
train length stored as valid Train Data or the safe consist length at the time the train was 

--- Document Chunk 4769 ---
last known to be integer can be used for reporting the train position to  the RBC, which 

--- Document Chunk 4770 ---
will allow the trackside to use the information about the confirmed train rear end position. 

--- Document Chunk 4771 ---
3.6.5.2.2 Driver input of train integrity confirmation shall only be permitted at standstill. 

--- Document Chunk 4772 ---
3.6.5.2.3 The train integrity information reported to the RBC shall consist of: 

--- Document Chunk 4773 ---
a) Train integrity status information 

--- Document Chunk 4774 ---
• No train integrity information 

--- Document Chunk 4775 ---
• Train integrity confirmed by external source 

--- Document Chunk 4776 ---
• Train integrity confirmed by driver 

--- Document Chunk 4777 ---
• Train integrity lost 

--- Document Chunk 4778 ---
b) Confirmed train length information (only available when train integrity confirmation is 

--- Document Chunk 4779 ---
reported). 

--- Document Chunk 4780 ---
3.6.5.2.4 The confirmed train length information shall represent the distance between the min safe 

--- Document Chunk 4781 ---
rear end at the time the train was last known to be integer and the estimated position of 

--- Document Chunk 4782 ---
the train front  at the time when the train integrity inform ation is sent to the RBC (see 

--- Document Chunk 4783 ---
Figure 15). 

--- Document Chunk 4784 ---
3.6.5.2.4.1 Note: when a confirmation of integrity is received from an external source, this does not 

--- Document Chunk 4785 ---
necessarily mean that the train is complete at the moment that the confirmation is 

--- Document Chunk 4786 ---
received, but rather that the train was k nown to be complete at some time before the 

--- Document Chunk 4787 ---
confirmation of integrity was received. This time will depend on the properties of both the 

--- Document Chunk 4788 ---
external source and the interface to this source. 

--- Document Chunk 4789 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP
