--- Document Chunk 6392 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6393 ---
Refer to appendix A. 3.4 for the exhaustive list of location based information stored 

--- Document Chunk 6394 ---
on-board, which shall be deleted accordingly. 

--- Document Chunk 6395 ---
3.10.2.3 When receiving an unconditional emergency stop message the train shall be tripped 

--- Document Chunk 6396 ---
immediately. 

--- Document Chunk 6397 ---
3.10.2.4 New movement authority received after any accepted  emergency stop message and 

--- Document Chunk 6398 ---
before the emergency message has been revoked, shall be rejected. 

--- Document Chunk 6399 ---
3.10.2.5 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 6400 ---
3.10.2.6 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 6401 ---
3.10.3 Revocation of an Emergency Message 

--- Document Chunk 6402 ---
3.10.3.1 The revocation message shall refer to the identity of the concerned emergency message. 

--- Document Chunk 6403 ---
3.10.3.2 The revocation messages shall be acknowledged by the on-board equipment, according 

--- Document Chunk 6404 ---
to the general acknowledgement procedure (see section 3.16.3.5) 

--- Document Chunk 6405 ---
3.10.3.3 The revocation of an emergency message shall have no effect on the management of 

--- Document Chunk 6406 ---
other emergency messages possibly received. 

--- Document Chunk 6407 ---
3.10.3.4 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 6408 ---
3.11 Static Speed Restrictions and Gradients 

--- Document Chunk 6409 ---
3.11.1 Introduction  

--- Document Chunk 6410 ---
3.11.1.1 The permitted speed at which the train is allowed to travel shall be limited to different 

--- Document Chunk 6411 ---
kinds of Static Speed Restrictions. 

--- Document Chunk 6412 ---
3.11.1.2 A Static Speed Restriction shall be handled in the same way independent of ETCS level. 

--- Document Chunk 6413 ---
3.11.2 Definition of Static Speed Restriction 

--- Document Chunk 6414 ---
3.11.2.1 Static Speed Restrictions are imposed by the t rackside infrastructure, the train 

--- Document Chunk 6415 ---
characteristics, the signalling and the mode of the on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 6416 ---
3.11.2.2 There are eleven categories of Static Speed Restrictions:   

--- Document Chunk 6417 ---
a) Static Speed Profile (SSP) 

--- Document Chunk 6418 ---
b) Axle load Speed Profile (ASP) 

--- Document Chunk 6419 ---
c) Temporary Speed Restrictions (TSR) 

--- Document Chunk 6420 ---
d) Maximum Train Speed 

--- Document Chunk 6421 ---
e) Signalling related speed restriction (only level 1) 

--- Document Chunk 6422 ---
f) Mode related Speed Restriction. 

--- Document Chunk 6423 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6424 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6425 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6426 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6427 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 6428 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 6429 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6430 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6431 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6432 ---
Page 98/252 

--- Document Chunk 6433 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6434 ---
g) STM Max speed (for details refer to Subset-035) 

--- Document Chunk 6435 ---
h) STM System speed (for details refer to Subset-035) 

--- Document Chunk 6436 ---
i) Level Crossing speed restriction (LX SR) 

--- Document Chunk 6437 ---
j) Override function related Speed Restriction 

--- Document Chunk 6438 ---
k) Speed restriction to ensure a given permitted braking distance (PBD SR) (see 

--- Document Chunk 6439 ---
3.11.11) 

--- Document Chunk 6440 ---
3.11.2.3 The Static Speed Restriction categories are independent of each other. This means that 

--- Document Chunk 6441 ---
one speed restriction category cannot affect, nor be affected by, any other category of 

--- Document Chunk 6442 ---
Static Speed Restrictions.  

--- Document Chunk 6443 ---
v

--- Document Chunk 6444 ---
d

--- Document Chunk 6445 ---
Static Speed Profile

--- Document Chunk 6446 ---
Temporary Speed Restriction

--- Document Chunk 6447 ---
Maximum Train Speed

--- Document Chunk 6448 ---
Mode related Speed Restriction

--- Document Chunk 6449 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6450 ---
Figure 26: Example of Static Speed Restriction categories on a piece of track. 

--- Document Chunk 6451 ---
3.11.2.4 Depending on the type of Static Speed Restriction train l ength may have to be used to 

--- Document Chunk 6452 ---
ensure that the full length of the train has passed a Static Speed Restriction discontinuity 

--- Document Chunk 6453 ---
before a speed increase shall be taken into account.  

--- Document Chunk 6454 ---
3.11.2.5 Intentionally deleted.  

--- Document Chunk 6455 ---
3.11.2.6 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 6456 ---
3.11.3 Static Speed Profile (SSP) 

--- Document Chunk 6457 ---
3.11.3.1.1 The Static Speed Profile (SSP) is a description of the fixed speed restrictions of a given 

--- Document Chunk 6458 ---
piece of track. The speed restrictions can be related to e.g. maximum line speed, curves, 

--- Document Chunk 6459 ---
points, tunnel profiles, bridges. 

--- Document Chunk 6460 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6461 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6462 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6463 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6464 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 6465 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 6466 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6467 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6468 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6469 ---
Page 99/252 

--- Document Chunk 6470 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6471 ---
3.11.3.1.2 The Static Speed Profile is based on factors, which are both track and train dependent. 

--- Document Chunk 6472 ---
The relationship between track and train characteristics determines the individual Static 

--- Document Chunk 6473 ---
Speed Profile for each train.  

--- Document Chunk 6474 ---
3.11.3.1.3 It shall be possible for every element (distance between two discontinuities) of a static 

--- Document Chunk 6475 ---
speed profile to define, if a transition to a higher speed limit than the speed limit specified 

--- Document Chunk 6476 ---
for this element is permitted before the complete train has left the element. 

--- Document Chunk 6477 ---
3.11.3.2 Static Speed Profile Categories 

--- Document Chunk 6478 ---
3.11.3.2.1 It shall be possible to transmit several Static Speed Profile Categories; one Basic SSP 

--- Document Chunk 6479 ---
category and specific SSP categories related to the international train categories. 

--- Document Chunk 6480 ---
3.11.3.2.1.1 The specific SSP categories are decomposed into two types: 

--- Document Chunk 6481 ---
a) The “Cant Deficiency” SSP categories: the cant deficiency value assigned to o ne 

--- Document Chunk 6482 ---
category shall define the maximum speed, determined by suspension design, at which 

--- Document Chunk 6483 ---
a particular train can traverse a curve and thus can be used to set a specific speed 

--- Document Chunk 6484 ---
limit in a curve with regards to this category. 

--- Document Chunk 6485 ---
b) The “other specific” SSP categories: it groups all other specific SSP categories 

--- Document Chunk 6486 ---
corresponding to the other international train categories 

--- Document Chunk 6487 ---
3.11.3.2.1.2 Whenever the type of specific SSP category is not explicitly specified in the following 

--- Document Chunk 6488 ---
requirements, it shall be interpreted as being applicable for both  types of specific SSP 

--- Document Chunk 6489 ---
categories. 

--- Document Chunk 6490 ---
3.11.3.2.2 For each part of the Static Speed Profile, the ERTMS/ETCS trackside shall: 

--- Document Chunk 6491 ---
a) always give the Basic SSP, which shall be considered as the default “Cant Deficiency” 

--- Document Chunk 6492 ---
SSP 

--- Document Chunk 6493 ---
b) optionally give one or more specific SSPs 

--- Document Chunk 6494 ---
c) specify, for each “other specific” SSP, whether it replaces or not the “Cant Deficiency” 

--- Document Chunk 6495 ---
SSP as selected by the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment according to 3.11.3.2.3 

--- Document Chunk 6496 ---
3.11.3.2.3 For each part of the Static Speed Profile, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 6497 ---
select the SSP best suiting its “Cant Deficiency” train category, according to the following 

--- Document Chunk 6498 ---
order of preference: 

--- Document Chunk 6499 ---
a) if available, the “Cant Deficiency” SSP matching its “Cant Deficiency” train category, 

--- Document Chunk 6500 ---
OR 

--- Document Chunk 6501 ---
b) if available, the “Cant Deficiency” SSP with the highest Ca nt Deficiency value below 

--- Document Chunk 6502 ---
the value of its “Cant Deficiency” train category, OR 

--- Document Chunk 6503 ---
c) the Basic SSP 

--- Document Chunk 6504 ---
3.11.3.2.3.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 6505 ---
3.11.3.2.4 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 6506 ---
3.11.3.2.5 “Other Specific” SSP categories not relevant to the current train shall be ignored. 

--- Document Chunk 6507 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6508 ---

System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6514 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6515 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6516 ---
Page 100/252 

--- Document Chunk 6517 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6518 ---
3.11.3.2.6 For each part of the Static Spee d Profile, t he ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment in a 

--- Document Chunk 6519 ---
train belonging to at least one or more “other international” train categories shall use the 

--- Document Chunk 6520 ---
most restrictive speed amongst: 

--- Document Chunk 6521 ---
a) the ” Cant Deficiency” SSP as selected in 3.11.3.2.3, only if none of the “other specific” 

--- Document Chunk 6522 ---
SSP categories matching the train categories replaces the ” Cant Deficiency” SSP, 

--- Document Chunk 6523 ---
AND 

--- Document Chunk 6524 ---
b) all the “other specific” SSP categories matching the “other international” train 

--- Document Chunk 6525 ---
categories. 

--- Document Chunk 6526 ---
3.11.3.3 Train categories 

--- Document Chunk 6527 ---
3.11.3.3.1 A maximum of 31 train categories is defined to match the SSP categories. 16 “Cant 

--- Document Chunk 6528 ---
Deficiency” train categories and 15 “other international” train categories. 

--- Document Chunk 6529 ---
3.11.3.3.2 A train shall always belong to one and only one “Cant Deficiency” train category and may 

--- Document Chunk 6530 ---
optionally belong to one or more “other international” train categories. 

--- Document Chunk 6531 ---
3.11.3.3.3 The train category(ies) to which a train belongs is a part of its Train Data. 

--- Document Chunk 6532 ---
3.11.4 Axle load Speed Profile 

--- Document Chunk 6533 ---
3.11.4.1 It shall be possible to define an Axle load Speed Profile as a non-continuous profile. 

--- Document Chunk 6534 ---
3.11.4.2 For each section with a speed restriction due to axle load, it shall be possible to transmit  

--- Document Chunk 6535 ---
one or more axle load category speed restrictions. 

--- Document Chunk 6536 ---
3.11.4.2.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 6537 ---
3.11.4.3 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall only consider the speed restriction that is 

--- Document Chunk 6538 ---
associated with  the axle load category matching that of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 6539 ---
3.11.4.3.1 Note: As a consequence, it is the trackside responsibility to provide the axle load 

--- Document Chunk 6540 ---
category speed restrictions taking into account the different axle load categories of the 

--- Document Chunk 6541 ---
trains suitable to operate on the line. 

--- Document Chunk 6542 ---
3.11.4.4 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 6543 ---
3.11.4.5 The initial state for Axle load Speed Profile shall be “no restriction due to axle load”. 

--- Document Chunk 6544 ---
3.11.4.6 Whether a speed increase after the axle load speed restriction shall be delayed with train 

--- Document Chunk 6545 ---
length, shall be determined by the axle load sp eed profile information sent to the on -

--- Document Chunk 6546 ---
board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 6547 ---
3.11.5 Temporary Speed Restrictions 

--- Document Chunk 6548 ---
3.11.5.1 The temporary speed restriction is defined in order to enable a separate category of track 

--- Document Chunk 6549 ---
infrastructure speed restriction, which can be used for working areas etc. 

--- Document Chunk 6550 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6551 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6552 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6553 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6554 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 6555 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 6556 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6557 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6558 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6559 ---
Page 101/252 

--- Document Chunk 6560 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6561 ---
3.11.5.2 All Temporary Speed Restrictions are independent of each other. This means that an 

--- Document Chunk 6562 ---
individual Temporary Speed Restriction cannot affect, nor be affected by, any other 

--- Document Chunk 6563 ---
individual Temporary Speed Restriction. 

--- Document Chunk 6564 ---
3.11.5.3 Whether a speed increase after the temporary speed res triction shall be delayed with 

--- Document Chunk 6565 ---
train length, shall be determined by the temporary speed restriction information sent to 

--- Document Chunk 6566 ---
the on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 6567 ---
3.11.5.4 When two or more temporary speed restrictions overlap, the most restrictive speed of 

--- Document Chunk 6568 ---
the overlapping temporary speed restrictions shall be used in the area of overlap. 

--- Document Chunk 6569 ---
3.11.5.5 Each Temporary Speed Restriction shall have an identity to make it possible to revoke 

--- Document Chunk 6570 ---
the Temporary Speed Restriction using its identity. The speed restriction shall be 

--- Document Chunk 6571 ---
revoked immediately when revoca tion is received from trackside, without delay for the 

--- Document Chunk 6572 ---
train length. 

--- Document Chunk 6573 ---
3.11.5.6 It shall be possible to identify whether a Temporary Speed Restriction is possible to 

--- Document Chunk 6574 ---
revoke or not. 

--- Document Chunk 6575 ---
3.11.5.7 A new Temporary Speed Restriction shall not replace a previously received Temporary 

--- Document Chunk 6576 ---
Speed Restriction with another identity.  

--- Document Chunk 6577 ---
3.11.5.8 Temporary Speed Restrictions shall only be revoked on request from the trackside.  

--- Document Chunk 6578 ---
3.11.5.9 If the on-board equipment receives a new Temporary Speed Restriction (TSR) with the 

--- Document Chunk 6579 ---
same identity as an already received TSR, the new  Temporary Speed Restriction shall 

--- Document Chunk 6580 ---
replace the previous one, except when the Temporary Speed Restriction is identified as 

--- Document Chunk 6581 ---
non revocable in which case this shall be considered as an additional TSR. 

--- Document Chunk 6582 ---
3.11.5.10 In case the train has changed its orientation any Temporary  Speed Restriction shall be 

--- Document Chunk 6583 ---
deleted (operational requirement: will be executed due to the mode change). 

--- Document Chunk 6584 ---
3.11.5.11 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 6585 ---
3.11.5.12 It shall be possible for the RBC to order an ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment in Level 

--- Document Chunk 6586 ---
2 to reject revocable TSRs from balises. 

--- Document Chunk 6587 ---
3.11.5.13 When ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment has accepted an order to reject revocable 

--- Document Chunk 6588 ---
TSRs from balises, this inhibition shall be stored and shall be effective immediately, but 

--- Document Chunk 6589 ---
only for revocable TSRs received from balises thereafter.  

--- Document Chunk 6590 ---
3.11.5.14 The inhibition of re vocable TSRs from balises  shall be deleted if any of the following 

--- Document Chunk 6591 ---
occurs: 

--- Document Chunk 6592 ---
• the communication session established with the RBC that ordered the inhibition is 

--- Document Chunk 6593 ---
terminated, OR 

--- Document Chunk 6594 ---
• in case of RBC/RBC handover, the max safe front end of the train crosses the 

--- Document Chunk 6595 ---
RBC/RBC border. 

--- Document Chunk 6596 ---
3.11.5.15 Note: this inhibition may be useful in Level 1 / Level 2 mixed signalling applications when 

--- Document Chunk 6597 ---
the RBC has more precise information about restrictions than can be given from balises. 

--- Document Chunk 6598 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6599 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6600 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6601 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6602 ---

--- Document Chunk 6608 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6609 ---
The RBC may then order inhibition of revocable TSRs from balises an d instead send 

--- Document Chunk 6610 ---
more precise TSRs to the train. 

--- Document Chunk 6611 ---
3.11.6 Signalling related speed restrictions 

--- Document Chunk 6612 ---
3.11.6.1 In level 1, it shall be possible to send to the on-board equipment a speed restriction with 

--- Document Chunk 6613 ---
a value depending on the current state of signalling. 

--- Document Chunk 6614 ---
3.11.6.2 This speed value shall be taken into account by the on-board equipment as soon as it is 

--- Document Chunk 6615 ---
received on-board, with the exception of a signalling related speed restriction from an 

--- Document Chunk 6616 ---
infill device. In case of infill information the speed restriction shall be taken into account 

--- Document Chunk 6617 ---
from the location reference of the balise group at the next main signal. 

--- Document Chunk 6618 ---
3.11.6.3 The speed restriction shall be valid until a new signalling related speed restriction is 

--- Document Chunk 6619 ---
received. 

--- Document Chunk 6620 ---
3.11.6.3.1 If the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment switches from level 1 to level 2, the signalling 

--- Document Chunk 6621 ---
related speed restriction shall remain valid until a level 2 MA is accepted by the 

--- Document Chunk 6622 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 6623 ---
3.11.6.4 In case of a signal at danger the signalling related speed restriction shall have value  

--- Document Chunk 6624 ---
zero, which shall be evaluated by the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment not as a speed 

--- Document Chunk 6625 ---
limit but as a train trip order. 

--- Document Chunk 6626 ---
3.11.6.5 In case of infill information the signalling related speed restriction at zero shall be ignored. 

--- Document Chunk 6627 ---
3.11.6.5.1 Note: The infill information will also include an EOA at the next main signal that will be 

--- Document Chunk 6628 ---
supervised according to the normal rules. 

--- Document Chunk 6629 ---
3.11.7 Mode related speed restrictions 

--- Document Chunk 6630 ---
3.11.7.1 The value of the mode related speed restriction shall be determined by the corresponding 

--- Document Chunk 6631 ---
national value or the corresponding default values if the national values are not 

--- Document Chunk 6632 ---
applicable. 

--- Document Chunk 6633 ---
3.11.7.1.1  Exception 1: For the modes On-sight, Limited Supervision and Shunting the speed limit 

--- Document Chunk 6634 ---
can also be given from the trackside. The speed limit given from the trackside shall 

--- Document Chunk 6635 ---
prevail over the National value and the default value. 

--- Document Chunk 6636 ---
3.11.7.1.2 Exception 2: For the mode s Reversing and Supervised Manoeuvre there is no 

--- Document Chunk 6637 ---
National/Default value. The speed limit is always given from trackside.  

--- Document Chunk 6638 ---
3.11.7.1.3 Exception 3: For the mode Staff Responsible the speed limit can also be entered by the 

--- Document Chunk 6639 ---
driver. The speed limit given by the driver shall prevail over the National/Default value. 

--- Document Chunk 6640 ---
3.11.8 Train related speed restriction 

--- Document Chunk 6641 ---
3.11.8.1 It shall be possible to define the maximum train speed related to the actual performance 

--- Document Chunk 6642 ---
and configuration of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 6643 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6644 ---

3.11.9 LX speed restriction 

--- Document Chunk 6655 ---
3.11.9.1 It shall be possible to define a LX spe ed restriction when the train has to pass a non 

--- Document Chunk 6656 ---
protected Level Crossing. 

--- Document Chunk 6657 ---
3.11.10 Override function related Speed Restriction 

--- Document Chunk 6658 ---
3.11.10.1 While the “override” function is active, the override speed limit (national /default value) 

--- Document Chunk 6659 ---
shall be taken into account. 

--- Document Chunk 6660 ---
3.11.11 Speed restriction to ensure permitted braking distance 

--- Document Chunk 6661 ---
3.11.11.1 It shall be possible for trackside to request the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment to 

--- Document Chunk 6662 ---
calculate a speed restriction based on a permitted braking distance given by trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 6663 ---
3.11.11.2 The order shall be given by means of a non-continuous profile defining: 

--- Document Chunk 6664 ---
• The start and end location for the speed restriction 

--- Document Chunk 6665 ---
• The permitted braking distance (PBD) used to calculate the speed restriction value 

--- Document Chunk 6666 ---
• Whether the permitted braking distance is to be achieved with the Service Brake or 

--- Document Chunk 6667 ---
Emergency Brake 

--- Document Chunk 6668 ---
• A single gradient value applicable for the calculation 

--- Document Chunk 6669 ---
3.11.11.3 The speed restriction shall be calculated when the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 6670 ---
receives the permitted braking distance information from trackside, and shall be re -

--- Document Chunk 6671 ---
calculated only if any of the inputs taken into account for the calculation of the speed 

--- Document Chunk 6672 ---
restriction changes. 

--- Document Chunk 6673 ---
3.11.11.4 The calculation of the speed restriction by the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 6674 ---
take into account that: 

--- Document Chunk 6675 ---
• The single gradient value received from trackside shall be compensated in value 

--- Document Chunk 6676 ---
according to the rotating mass as defined in 3.13.4.3. 

--- Document Chunk 6677 ---
• The safe deceleration shall be computed as in 3.13.6.2.1 but without considering the 

--- Document Chunk 6678 ---
adhesion profiles , the track conditions related to brake inhibition and the track 

--- Document Chunk 6679 ---
conditions related to powerless section given by trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 6680 ---
• The expected deceleration shall be computed as in 3.13.6.3.1 but without considering 

--- Document Chunk 6681 ---
the track conditions related to brake inhibition and the track conditions related to 

--- Document Chunk 6682 ---
powerless section given by trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 6683 ---
• The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall calculate an Emergency Brake 

--- Document Chunk 6684 ---
Deceleration (EBD) curve based on the safe deceleration and that reaches zero 

--- Document Chunk 6685 ---
speed at a distance equal to the permitted braking distance. 

--- Document Chunk 6686 ---
• If the permitted braking distance is to be achiev ed with the service brake, the 

--- Document Chunk 6687 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall also calculate a Service Brake Deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 6688 ---
(SBD) curve based on the expected deceleration and that reaches zero speed at a 

--- Document Chunk 6689 ---
distance equal to the permitted braking distance. 

--- Document Chunk 6690 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6691 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6692 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6693 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6694 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 6695 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 6696 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6697 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6698 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6699 ---
Page 104/252 

--- Document Chunk 6700 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6701 ---
• The estimated acceleration shall be set to “zero”. 

--- Document Chunk 6702 ---
• If not inhibited by National Value, the compensation of the inaccuracy of the speed 

--- Document Chunk 6703 ---
measurement shall be set to a value calculated from the PBD speed, as defined in 

--- Document Chunk 6704 ---
SUBSET-041 § 5.3.1.2: V_delta0PBD = f 41(V_PBD + dV_EBI( V_PBD)) if the 

--- Document Chunk 6705 ---
permitted braking distance is to be achieved with the emergency brake; V_delta0PBD 

--- Document Chunk 6706 ---
= f41(V_PBD + dV_SBI(V_PBD)) if the permitted braking distance is to be achieved 

--- Document Chunk 6707 ---
with the service brake. 

--- Document Chunk 6708 ---
• The train will travel a distance from the last encoun tered balise of a group that 

--- Document Chunk 6709 ---
provides restrictive information until initiating the brake command. This travelled 

--- Document Chunk 6710 ---
distance shall be set to a value calculated from the PBD speed considering a 

--- Document Chunk 6711 ---
processing delay (T41) equal to SUBSET-041 § 5.2.1.1. 

--- Document Chunk 6712 ---
• Regardless o f how the service brake feedback is actually configured (see 

--- Document Chunk 6713 ---
3.13.2.2.7.2), T_bs1 and T_bs2 (see 3.13.9.3.3) shall be defined as if the service 

--- Document Chunk 6714 ---
brake feedback was not implemented. 

--- Document Chunk 6715 ---
• Regardless of how the traction cut-off interface is actually configured (see 3.13.2.2.8), 

--- Document Chunk 6716 ---
T_traction (see 3.13.9.3.2) shall be defined as if the traction cut -off was not 

--- Document Chunk 6717 ---
implemented. 

--- Document Chunk 6718 ---
3.11.11.4.1 Note: Knowing how the PBD speed restriction is computed by the ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 6719 ---
board equipment, it is the responsibility of the trackside to set the appropriate permitted 

--- Document Chunk 6720 ---
braking distance with regard to the risk of not initiating the brake command in due time 

--- Document Chunk 6721 ---
when encountering a further balise group providing restrictive information. In other 

--- Document Chunk 6722 ---
words, if deemed necessary, the trackside can include provisio ns based on the 

--- Document Chunk 6723 ---
characteristics of the balise group providing restrictive information e.g. distances 

--- Document Chunk 6724 ---
between balises in that group with regards to validity direction of transmitted information 

--- Document Chunk 6725 ---
and balise group orientation, accuracy of balise location. 

--- Document Chunk 6726 ---
3.11.11.4.2 Note: If the permitted braking distance is to be achieved with the service brake, it is the 

--- Document Chunk 6727 ---
responsibility of the trackside to also consider an estimation of the on-board over-reading 

--- Document Chunk 6728 ---
and under-reading amounts at the time the brake command is initiated in order to lower 

--- Document Chunk 6729 ---
the likelihood of the max safe front end of the train reaching the EBI supervision limit. 

--- Document Chunk 6730 ---
3.11.11.5 Note: Throughout the following formulas, all the distances marked with “d” (lower case) 

--- Document Chunk 6731 ---
are counted from a single arbitrary reference location. 

--- Document Chunk 6732 ---

--- Document Chunk 6733 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall seek the PBD speed restriction value (V_PBD) 

--- Document Chunk 6734 ---
which satisfies the two following inequalities. The resulting value shall then be rounded 

--- Document Chunk 6735 ---
down to the next lower multiple of 5km/h:

--- Document Chunk 6810 ---
3.11.11.11 The initial state for Speed Restrictions to Ensure Permitted Braking Distance shall be “no 

--- Document Chunk 6811 ---
speed restriction”. 

--- Document Chunk 6812 ---
3.11.12 Gradients 

--- Document Chunk 6813 ---
3.11.12.1 The gradient information for a given piece of track shall be transmitted to the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 6814 ---
equipment in form of a gradient profile. 

--- Document Chunk 6815 ---
3.11.12.2 The gradient profile shall be continuous, i.e., give a gradient value for each location within 

--- Document Chunk 6816 ---
the piece of track covered by the profile. 

--- Document Chunk 6817 ---
3.11.12.3 A gradient value shall be identified as a positive value for an uphill slope, and with a 

--- Document Chunk 6818 ---
negative value for a downhill slope. 

--- Document Chunk 6819 ---
3.11.12.4 The gradient profile shall contain the gradient information as a sequence of gradient 

--- Document Chunk 6820 ---
values, constant between two defined locations each, see Figure 27. 

--- Document Chunk 6821 ---
Gradient

--- Document Chunk 6822 ---
values

--- Document Chunk 6823 ---
Distance

--- Document Chunk 6824 ---
Track

--- Document Chunk 6825 ---
Height

--- Document Chunk 6826 ---
Distance

--- Document Chunk 6827 ---
Travelling direction

--- Document Chunk 6828 ---
A B

--- Document Chunk 6829 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6830 ---
Figure 27: Gradient profile

--- Document Chunk 6841 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6842 ---
3.11.12.4.1 Note: The figure above symbolises the engineering process to provide the values of 

--- Document Chunk 6843 ---
gradients. Following the track height, the track must be split in segments giving for each 

--- Document Chunk 6844 ---
segment a gradient value. 

--- Document Chunk 6845 ---
3.11.12.5 It shall be possible via balise groups to send to the on-board equipment a default gradient 

--- Document Chunk 6846 ---
for TSR, to be used for the parts of the track not covered by the gradient profile. 

--- Document Chunk 6847 ---
3.11.12.6 The Default Gradient for TSR stored on-board shall be valid until a new Default Gradient 

--- Document Chunk 6848 ---
for TSR is received. 

--- Document Chunk 6849 ---
3.12 Other Profiles 

--- Document Chunk 6850 ---
3.12.1 Track Conditions  

--- Document Chunk 6851 ---
3.12.1.1 The Track Condition function is used to inform the driver and/or the train of a condition 

--- Document Chunk 6852 ---
in front of the train.  

--- Document Chunk 6853 ---
3.12.1.2 A Track Condition shall be given as profile data (e.g. non -stopping area), i.e. start and 

--- Document Chunk 6854 ---
end of the data is given, or location data (e.g. change of traction system) i.e. start location 

--- Document Chunk 6855 ---
given, depending on the type of track condition.  

--- Document Chunk 6856 ---
3.12.1.2.1 The starting point of a profile type track condition shall be evaluated taking into account 

--- Document Chunk 6857 ---
the max safe front end of the train, the end of the profile taking into account the min safe 

--- Document Chunk 6858 ---
rear end of the train. Location type data shall be evaluated taking into account  the max 

--- Document Chunk 6859 ---
safe front of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 6860 ---
3.12.1.2.1.1 Note: The timing of output data to control train equipment (e.g. pantograph) is 

--- Document Chunk 6861 ---
application specific. 

--- Document Chunk 6862 ---
3.12.1.2.1.2 Exception 1: The starting point of a Big Metal Mass type track condition shall be 

--- Document Chunk 6863 ---
evaluated taking into account the max safe antenna position, the end of the profile taking 

--- Document Chunk 6864 ---
into account the min safe antenna position. 

--- Document Chunk 6865 ---
3.12.1.2.1.3 Exception 2: The end of the Powerless section and the end of the Station Platform 

--- Document Chunk 6866 ---
shall be evaluated taking into account the min safe front end of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 6867 ---
3.12.1.2.1.4 Exception 3: The start and end of a tunnel stopping area and of a sound horn track 

--- Document Chunk 6868 ---
condition shall be evaluated taking into account the estimated front end of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 6869 ---
3.12.1.2.1.5 Exception 4: The start and end of a radio hole shall be evaluated taking into account 

--- Document Chunk 6870 ---
the estimated position of the front /rear and rear/front ends of the engine respectively , 

--- Document Chunk 6871 ---
depending on whether the train orientation is the same as/opposite to the active cab. 

--- Document Chunk 6872 ---
3.12.1.2.1.5.1 Note: it is assumed that all the radio antennas are installed on the engine. 

--- Document Chunk 6873 ---
3.12.1.3 The types of track conditions to be covered by this function are: 

--- Document Chunk 6874 ---
• Powerless section, lower pantograph (initial state: no powerless section , i.e. 

--- Document Chunk 6875 ---
pantograph not to be lowered) 

--- Document Chunk 6876 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6877 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6878 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6879 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6880 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 6881 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 6882 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6883 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6884 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6885 ---
Page 108/252 

--- Document Chunk 6886 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6887 ---
• Powerless section, switch off main power switch (initial state: no powerless section, 

--- Document Chunk 6888 ---
i.e. main power switch not to be switched off) 

--- Document Chunk 6889 ---
• Air tightness (initial state: no request for air tightness) 

--- Document Chunk 6890 ---
• Sound horn (initial state: no request for sound horn) 

--- Document Chunk 6891 ---
• Non stopping area (initial state: stopping permitted) 

--- Document Chunk 6892 ---
• Tunnel stopping area (initial state: no tunnel stopping area) 

--- Document Chunk 6893 ---
• Change of traction system, switch traction system on-board, used for train capable 

--- Document Chunk 6894 ---
of handling several traction systems (initial state: no initial state – keep the current 

--- Document Chunk 6895 ---
setting) 

--- Document Chunk 6896 ---
• Change of allowed current consumption, limit current consumed by the train, used to 

--- Document Chunk 6897 ---
adapt the maximum current consumption of the train to the maximum current allowed 

--- Document Chunk 6898 ---
by the trackside (initial state: no initial state – keep the current setting) 

--- Document Chunk 6899 ---
• Big metal masses, ignore onboard integrity check alarms of balise transmission. 

--- Document Chunk 6900 ---
(initial state: alarms not ignored) 

--- Document Chunk 6901 ---
• Radio hole, stop supervision of the loss of safe radio connection (initial state: loss of 

--- Document Chunk 6902 ---
safe radio connection supervised) 

--- Document Chunk 6903 ---
• Switch off regenerative brake (initial state: regenerative brake on) 

--- Document Chunk 6904 ---
• Switch off eddy current brake for service brake (initial state: eddy current brake on 

--- Document Chunk 6905 ---
for service brake) 

--- Document Chunk 6906 ---
• Switch off eddy current brake for emergency brake ( initial state: eddy current brake 

--- Document Chunk 6907 ---
on for emergency brake) 

--- Document Chunk 6908 ---
• Switch off magnetic shoe brake (initial state: magnetic shoe brake on). 

--- Document Chunk 6909 ---
• Station platform, enable passenger doors with or without steps according to platform 

--- Document Chunk 6910 ---
location, side and height (initial state: no platform, i.e. passenger doors not enabled). 

--- Document Chunk 6911 ---
3.12.1.3.1 Note: In case of regenerative brake switch off or magnetic shoe brake switch off, the 

--- Document Chunk 6912 ---
deceleration of the emergency brake might be affected if the effect of these brakes was 

--- Document Chunk 6913 ---
included in the calculation of the deceleration value. 

--- Document Chunk 6914 ---
3.12.1.3.2 Note: In case of eddy current brake switch off the deceleration of the service brake or 

--- Document Chunk 6915 ---
emergency brake might be affected if the effect of these brakes was included in the 

--- Document Chunk 6916 ---
calculation of the deceleration value. 

--- Document Chunk 6917 ---
3.12.1.3.3 Note: in case of powerless section the deceleration of the service brake or emergency 

--- Document Chunk 6918 ---
brake might be affected if the effect of a regenerative brake not independent from the 

--- Document Chunk 6919 ---
presence of voltage in the catenary was included in the calculation of the decelera tion 

--- Document Chunk 6920 ---
value. 

--- Document Chunk 6921 ---
3.12.1.4 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 6922 ---
3.12.1.5 The following actions shall be performed once a track condition has been received: 

--- Document Chunk 6923 ---
a) Indicate on DMI (see chapter 5, procedure “Indication of track conditions”) , except 

--- Document Chunk 6924 ---
“Station platform”, “Change of allowed current consumption” and “Big metal masses”. 

--- Document Chunk 6925 ---

b) Send information with the remaining distance to an ERTMS/ETCS external function 

--- Document Chunk 6937 ---
(see chapter 5, procedure “Generation of track conditions related information to an 

--- Document Chunk 6938 ---
ERTMS/ETCS external function”) , with the exception of big meta l mass track 

--- Document Chunk 6939 ---
condition, sound horn track condition, non stopping area, tunnel stopping area  and 

--- Document Chunk 6940 ---
supervision of radio transmission which are handled inside the ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 6941 ---
board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 6942 ---
3.12.1.5.1 Note: Whether some information shall be filtered (not shown to the  driver or not sent to 

--- Document Chunk 6943 ---
an ERTMS/ETCS external function) is outside the scope of ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 6944 ---
3.12.1.5.2 Note: The ERTMS/ETCS external function must be able to handle new track condition 

--- Document Chunk 6945 ---
of the same type as previously received and covering the same distance. 

--- Document Chunk 6946 ---
3.12.1.6 The train is permitted to run without any track condition information given from the 

--- Document Chunk 6947 ---
trackside. The initial state shall then be used by the on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 6948 ---
3.12.2 Route Suitability  

--- Document Chunk 6949 ---
3.12.2.1 Route suitability data defines which values concerning loading gauge, traction system 

--- Document Chunk 6950 ---
and axle load category a train must meet to be allowed to enter the route. 

--- Document Chunk 6951 ---
3.12.2.2 It shall be possible for trackside to send  route suitability data as location data when 

--- Document Chunk 6952 ---
needed. 

--- Document Chunk 6953 ---
3.12.2.3 On reception of route suitability data, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 6954 ---
compare it with the corresponding Train Data stored on-board. Unsuitability exists if: 

--- Document Chunk 6955 ---
a) The loading gauge profile of the train is not included in the list of loading gauges 

--- Document Chunk 6956 ---
accepted by trackside 

--- Document Chunk 6957 ---
b) The list of traction systems accepted by the engine does not include the one received 

--- Document Chunk 6958 ---
from trackside 

--- Document Chunk 6959 ---
c) The axle load category of the train is not included in the list of permitted ones received 

--- Document Chunk 6960 ---
from trackside 

--- Document Chunk 6961 ---
3.12.2.3.1 Exception to 3.12.2.3 b): If the engine is able to run on a line not fitted with any traction 

--- Document Chunk 6962 ---
system, unsuitability never exists. 

--- Document Chunk 6963 ---
3.12.2.4 If at least one unsuitability exists, the closest location corresponding to the 

--- Document Chunk 6964 ---
unsuitability(ies) shall be considered as both temporary EOA and SvL, with no Release 

--- Document Chunk 6965 ---
Speed. The driver shall be informed about all unsuitabilities. 

--- Document Chunk 6966 ---
3.12.2.5 The temporary EOA and SvL are entities distinct from the EOA and SvL continuously 

--- Document Chunk 6967 ---
supervised by the on -board. Unless specified otherwise, all the instances of the terms 

--- Document Chunk 6968 ---
EOA or SvL used in this document do not refer to these temporary EOA/SvL. 

--- Document Chunk 6969 ---
3.12.2.5.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 6970 ---
3.12.2.6 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 6971 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

3.12.2.8 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 6984 ---
3.12.2.9 The Train Data concerning route suitability is part of the Train Data sent to the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 6985 ---
3.12.2.9.1 Note: This allows for route suitability supervision to be used in systems external to t he 

--- Document Chunk 6986 ---
ERTMS/ETCS system. 

--- Document Chunk 6987 ---
3.12.2.10 The train is permitted to run without any route suitability data given from the track. No 

--- Document Chunk 6988 ---
default values shall be used or supervised by the on-board equipment, i.e. the initial state 

--- Document Chunk 6989 ---
is that no restrictions related to route suitability exists. 

--- Document Chunk 6990 ---
3.12.3 Text Transmission 

--- Document Chunk 6991 ---
3.12.3.1 General Rules 

--- Document Chunk 6992 ---
3.12.3.1.1 It shall be possible to transmit information to be displayed to the driver from the trackside 

--- Document Chunk 6993 ---
to the on-board equipment in the form of text messages.  

--- Document Chunk 6994 ---
3.12.3.1.2 Text messages shall always be supplemented by conditions on when and where they 

--- Document Chunk 6995 ---
are to be displayed, and whether any acknowledgement is requested from the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 6996 ---
These parameters shall be transmitted individually for each message.  

--- Document Chunk 6997 ---
3.12.3.1.3 Text messages and the supplementary information shall always be transmitted in one 

--- Document Chunk 6998 ---
message.  

--- Document Chunk 6999 ---
3.12.3.1.4 It shall be possible to send  the text to be displayed in plain text or to send a number 

--- Document Chunk 7000 ---
selecting a fixed message. 

--- Document Chunk 7001 ---
3.12.3.1.4.1 Note: In case of plain text messages the trackside selects the language in which the 

--- Document Chunk 7002 ---
message is displayed. 

--- Document Chunk 7003 ---
3.12.3.1.5 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 7004 ---
3.12.3.1.6 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 7005 ---
3.12.3.1.7 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 7006 ---
3.12.3.1.8 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 7007 ---
3.12.3.1.9 The following data shall be included in a text message:  

--- Document Chunk 7008 ---
• Class of message (auxiliary or important information) 

--- Document Chunk 7009 ---
• Plain text message or fixed message number 

--- Document Chunk 7010 ---
• Condition for start of indication  

--- Document Chunk 7011 ---
• Condition for end of indication 

--- Document Chunk 7012 ---
• If driver acknowledgement is requested or not 

--- Document Chunk 7013 ---
3.12.3.1.10 The appearance of a message shall depend on the class  and on whether a driver 

--- Document Chunk 7014 ---
acknowledgement is requested. 

--- Document Chunk 7015 ---

--- Document Chunk 7037 ---
3.12.3.4 Conditions for Start/End of Indication 

--- Document Chunk 7038 ---
3.12.3.4.1 It shall be possible to specify individual sub-conditions for start/end condition of 

--- Document Chunk 7039 ---
indication. 

--- Document Chunk 7040 ---
3.12.3.4.2 The following sub-conditions can be used to define the start condition: 

--- Document Chunk 7041 ---
• Location (the train front end is in advance of this location) 

--- Document Chunk 7042 ---
• Mode (the on-board is in this mode) 

--- Document Chunk 7043 ---
• Level (the on-board is in this level) 

--- Document Chunk 7044 ---
3.12.3.4.3 The following sub-conditions can be used to define the end condition: 

--- Document Chunk 7045 ---
• Location (the train front end is in advance of this location) 

--- Document Chunk 7046 ---
• Time (the duration since the start condition is fulfilled elapses) 

--- Document Chunk 7047 ---
• Mode (a transition from this mode is executed) 

--- Document Chunk 7048 ---
• Level (a transition from this level is executed) 

--- Document Chunk 7049 ---
3.12.3.4.3.1 It shall be possible to define whether one or all of the sub-conditions used from the 

--- Document Chunk 7050 ---
list in 3.12.3.4.2/3.12.3.4.3 have to be fulfilled to define the start/end condition. This 

--- Document Chunk 7051 ---
definition shall apply to both the start and the end conditions. It shall apply to the start 

--- Document Chunk 7052 ---
condition checked by the on -board when at least two sub-conditions from the list in 

--- Document Chunk 7053 ---
3.12.3.4.2 are used by the trackside and it shall apply to the end condition checked by 

--- Document Chunk 7054 ---
the on-board when at least two sub-conditions from the list in 3.12.3.4.3 are used by the 

--- Document Chunk 7055 ---
trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 7056 ---
3.12.3.4.3.1.1 When at least two sub-conditions from the list in 3.12.3.4.2 are used and they all have 

--- Document Chunk 7057 ---
to be fulfilled, they shall be continuously evaluated until they are all fulfilled at the same 

--- Document Chunk 7058 ---
time. 

--- Document Chunk 7059 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 7060 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7061 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7062 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 7063 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 7064 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 7065 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 7066 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 7067 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 7068 ---
Page 112/252 

--- Document Chunk 7069 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7070 ---
3.12.3.4.3.1.2 When at least two sub-conditions from the list in 3.12.3.4.3 are used and they all have 

--- Document Chunk 7071 ---
to be fulfilled, they shall be evaluated independently from each other and a sub-condition 

--- Document Chunk 7072 ---
shall no longer be evaluated once it is fulfilled. 

--- Document Chunk 7073 ---
3.12.3.4.3.1.3 If none of the sub-conditions from the list in 3.12.3.4.2 is used, it shall be considered 

--- Document Chunk 7074 ---
as a start condition immediately fulfilled. 

--- Document Chunk 7075 ---
3.12.3.4.3.1.4 If none of the sub-conditions from the list in 3.12.3.4.3 is used, it shall be considered 

--- Document Chunk 7076 ---
as an end condition never fulfilled. 

--- Document Chunk 7077 ---
3.12.3.4.3.2 In case a confirmation of the text message is requested, it shall be possible to define 

--- Document Chunk 7078 ---
whether the driver acknowledgement is considered: 

--- Document Chunk 7079 ---
a) As always ending the text display, regardless of the end condition defined in 

--- Document Chunk 7080 ---
3.12.3.4.3.1 

--- Document Chunk 7081 ---
b) As a necessary condition to end the text display, in addition to the end condition 

--- Document Chunk 7082 ---
defined in 3.12.3.4.3.1. 

--- Document Chunk 7083 ---
3.12.3.4.4 The end condition shall be evaluated as soon as the start condition is fulfilled. No display 

--- Document Chunk 7084 ---
shall take place if the end condition is immediately fulfilled , regardless if a confirmation 

--- Document Chunk 7085 ---
of the text message is requested. 

--- Document Chunk 7086 ---
3.12.3.4.5 Once the text message is displayed and the end condition is fulfilled, the start condition 

--- Document Chunk 7087 ---
shall not be re-evaluated. 

--- Document Chunk 7088 ---
3.12.3.4.6 When the sub-condition "location" is used for the end condition, the length on which the 

--- Document Chunk 7089 ---
text is displayed shall refer to the location used for the start condition, independently from 

--- Document Chunk 7090 ---
other start sub-conditions. 

--- Document Chunk 7091 ---
3.12.3.4.7 In case a  confirmation of the text message is requested, i t shall be possible to define 

--- Document Chunk 7092 ---
whether the service brake or emergency brake application shall be commanded if the 

--- Document Chunk 7093 ---
driver does not acknowledge before the end condition is fulfilled. 

--- Document Chunk 7094 ---
3.12.3.4.7.1 If the driver does not ackn owledge before the end condition is fulfilled, the text 

--- Document Chunk 7095 ---
message shall remain displayed until acknowledged by driver. 

--- Document Chunk 7096 ---
3.12.3.4.7.2 If the driver acknowledges before the end condition is fulfilled, the on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 7097 ---
shall consider the driver acknowledgement as requested by trackside (see 3.12.3.4.3.2). 

--- Document Chunk 7098 ---
3.12.3.4.8 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 7099 ---
3.12.3.5 Report of driver acknowledgement to RBC 

--- Document Chunk 7100 ---
3.12.3.5.1 If trackside requests a report of driver acknowledgement, then it shall include: 

--- Document Chunk 7101 ---
• a text message identifier 

--- Document Chunk 7102 ---
• the identity of the RBC to which the driver acknowledgement report is to be sent. 

--- Document Chunk 7103 ---

--- Document Chunk 7113 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7114 ---
3.12.3.5.2 When the driver has acknowledged a text message with a request to report driver 

--- Document Chunk 7115 ---
acknowledgement, the driver acknowledgement  report, including the text message 

--- Document Chunk 7116 ---
identifier, shall be sent to the RBC referenced in the request. 

--- Document Chunk 7117 ---
3.12.3.5.3 A new text message with request for report of driver acknowledgement shall be rejected 

--- Document Chunk 7118 ---
by the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment if it has the same text message identifier as 

--- Document Chunk 7119 ---
a previously received text message, which the driver has not yet acknowledged. 

--- Document Chunk 7120 ---
3.12.4 Mode profile 

--- Document Chunk 7121 ---
3.12.4.1 It shall be possible for trackside to send a Mode Profile. The Mode Profile can request 

--- Document Chunk 7122 ---
On Sight mode, Limited Supervision mode and Shunting mode. 

--- Document Chunk 7123 ---
3.12.4.2 For OS and LS mode the mode profile define s the entry and the length of the On 

--- Document Chunk 7124 ---
Sight/Limited Supervision area. For SH mode the mode profile only defines the entry 

--- Document Chunk 7125 ---
location to SH mode, any length given shall be ignored by the on-board.  

--- Document Chunk 7126 ---
3.12.4.3 On reception of a new MA (with or without Mode Profile) the on-board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 7127 ---
delete the currently supervised Mode Profile. 

--- Document Chunk 7128 ---
3.12.4.3.1 Exception: When receiving a new MA by infill, 

--- Document Chunk 7129 ---
a) any currently supervised OS/LS Mode Profile shall be deleted only beyond the 

--- Document Chunk 7130 ---
reference location of the infill information; 

--- Document Chunk 7131 ---
b) in case the infill location reference is in rear of or at the start location of a currently 

--- Document Chunk 7132 ---
supervised SH Mode Profile, this currently supervised SH Mode Profile shall be 

--- Document Chunk 7133 ---
deleted; 

--- Document Chunk 7134 ---
c) in case the infill location reference is in advance of the start location of a currently 

--- Document Chunk 7135 ---
supervised SH Mode Profile, any Mode Profile and, if any, a list of balise groups for 

--- Document Chunk 7136 ---
SH area included in this infill MA shall be ignored by the on -board equipment. No 

--- Document Chunk 7137 ---
deletion of this currently supervised SH Mode Profile shall take place in this case. 

--- Document Chunk 7138 ---
3.12.4.4 In case the SH Mode Profile is deleted for another reason than entering SH mode, the 

--- Document Chunk 7139 ---
corresponding list of balise groups for SH area shall be deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 7140 ---
3.12.4.5 The beginning of the Mode Profile relates to the max safe front end of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 7141 ---
3.12.4.6 The end of the mode profile relates to the min safe front end of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 7142 ---
3.12.4.7 Until the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment has switched to the concerned mode, it 

--- Document Chunk 7143 ---
shall consider the beginning of the Mode Profile as a temporary EOA. The ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 7144 ---
on-board equipment shall only for the cases below  consider a temporary SvL with no 

--- Document Chunk 7145 ---
release speed that is at a location: 

--- Document Chunk 7146 ---
a) At the beginning of the Mode Profile if it is required by the Mode Profile. 

--- Document Chunk 7147 ---
b) That is determined in accordance with 3.8.4.5  as if no LOA had been given, if it is 

--- Document Chunk 7148 ---
required that no temporary SvL is to be considered with respect to the Mode Profile 

--- Document Chunk 7149 ---
and the MA defines an LOA located in advance of or at the start of the Mode Profile. 

--- Document Chunk 7150 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 7151 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7152 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7153 ---
SUBSET-026-3

--- Document Chunk 7157 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 7158 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 7159 ---
Page 114/252 

--- Document Chunk 7160 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7161 ---
c) At the beginning of the Mode Profile, if it is required that no temporary SvL is to be 

--- Document Chunk 7162 ---
considered with respect t o the Mode Profile and the MA defines an LOA located in 

--- Document Chunk 7163 ---
rear of the start of the Mode Profile. 

--- Document Chunk 7164 ---
3.12.4.7.1 Note: No temporary SvL results from the Mode Profile if it requires that no temporary SvL 

--- Document Chunk 7165 ---
is to be considered with respect to it and the MA defines an EOA. 

--- Document Chunk 7166 ---
3.12.4.8 See clause 3.12.2.5. 

--- Document Chunk 7167 ---
3.12.5 Level Crossings 

--- Document Chunk 7168 ---
3.12.5.1 It shall be possible for trackside to inform the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment about 

--- Document Chunk 7169 ---
the conditions under which a Level Crossing (LX) must be passed. 

--- Document Chunk 7170 ---
3.12.5.2 Each Level Crossing shall have an identity, so that all LX information is independent of 

--- Document Chunk 7171 ---
each other. This means that an individual LX information cannot affect, nor be affected 

--- Document Chunk 7172 ---
by, any other individual LX information. 

--- Document Chunk 7173 ---
3.12.5.3 If the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment receives a new LX information with the same 

--- Document Chunk 7174 ---
identity as an already received LX information, the new LX information shall replace the 

--- Document Chunk 7175 ---
previous one. 

--- Document Chunk 7176 ---
3.12.5.4 Level Crossing information shall be given as profile data, corresponding to the LX  start 

--- Document Chunk 7177 ---
location and the length of the LX area. 

--- Document Chunk 7178 ---
3.12.5.5 Level Crossing information shall indicate whether the LX is protected or not. 

--- Document Chunk 7179 ---
3.12.5.6 In case the LX is not protected, ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall be informed: 

--- Document Chunk 7180 ---
a) at which speed the LX is allowed to be passed 

--- Document Chunk 7181 ---
b) whether the stopping of the train in rear of the LX start location is required or not 

--- Document Chunk 7182 ---
3.12.5.7 In case stopping in rear of the non protected LX is required, a stopping area in rear of 

--- Document Chunk 7183 ---
the LX start location shall be defined. 

--- Document Chunk 7184 ---
3.12.5.8 In case the LX is not protected , the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall consider 

--- Document Chunk 7185 ---
the LX start location as both temporary EOA and SvL, with no release speed. See section 

--- Document Chunk 7186 ---
5.16 for other detailed requirements. 

--- Document Chunk 7187 ---
3.12.5.9 See clause 3.12.2.5. 

--- Document Chunk 7188 ---
3.13 Speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 7189 ---
3.13.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 7190 ---
3.13.1.1 The speed and distance monitoring is the supervision of the speed of the train versus its 

--- Document Chunk 7191 ---
position, in order to assure that the train remains within the given speed and distance 

--- Document Chunk 7192 ---
limits. 

--- Document Chunk 7193 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 7194 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7195 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7196 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 7197 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 7198 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 7199 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 7200 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 7201 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 7202 ---
Page 115/252 

--- Document Chunk 7203 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7204 ---
3.13.1.1.1 Note: The speed and distance monitoring of the on-board can only assure this when the 

--- Document Chunk 7205 ---
following necessary conditions are fulfilled: 

--- Document Chunk 7206 ---
• Brake system of the train functions as specified 

--- Document Chunk 7207 ---
• wheel/rail adhesion is sufficient for the required safe deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 7208 ---
• Brake characteristics (and other Train related inputs) are correctly entered into the 

--- Document Chunk 7209 ---
on-board 

--- Document Chunk 7210 ---
3.13.1.2 Note: The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment triggers brake commands and revokes 

--- Document Chunk 7211 ---
them, it may also receive status information if the brakes are applied or released. 

--- Document Chunk 7212 ---
However, it cannot be made responsible if brake control circuits outside the equipment 

--- Document Chunk 7213 ---
fail. Also the way the brakes are r eleased by the driver after a revocation of a brake 

--- Document Chunk 7214 ---
command is an implementation issue. 

--- Document Chunk 7215 ---
3.13.1.3 Figure 28 gives an overview of the main elements contributing to the speed and distance 

--- Document Chunk 7216 ---
monitoring. These elements (inputs, functions and outputs) are detailed in the following 

--- Document Chunk 7217 ---
chapters.

3.13.1.4 Throughout the following sections, all the distances marked with “d” (lower case), which 

--- Document Chunk 7364 ---
are referred in parameters, formulas and figures, are counted from the single reference 

--- Document Chunk 7365 ---

--- Document Chunk 7366 ---
3.13.1.5 When the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment applies at least one of the clauses 

--- Document Chunk 7367 ---
3.12.2.4, 3.12.4.7 and 3.12.5.8, all the instances of the terms EOA and SvL in this section 

--- Document Chunk 7368 ---
3.13 shall refer to the closest location amongst the temporary EOA(s) and the EOA and 

--- Document Chunk 7369 ---
to the closest location amongst the temporary SvL(s) and the SvL, respectively. 

--- Document Chunk 7370 ---
3.13.2 Inputs for speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 7371 ---
3.13.2.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 7372 ---
3.13.2.1.1 The traction / braking models, the brake position / brake percentage are used for the 

--- Document Chunk 7373 ---
definition of the kinematic behaviour of the train after a service brake command or an 

--- Document Chunk 7374 ---
emergency brake command has been initiated. 

--- Document Chunk 7375 ---
3.13.2.1.2 However, railway brakes have a statistical behaviour and braking distances vary within 

--- Document Chunk 7376 ---
the typical distribution for a given condition. Correction factors are therefore incorporated 

--- Document Chunk 7377 ---
for the speed and distance monitoring. 

--- Document Chunk 7378 ---
3.13.2.1.3 The correction factors will allow obtaining, from the nominal emergency braking 

--- Document Chunk 7379 ---
performance of the train, the minimum emergency braking performances that are 

--- Document Chunk 7380 ---
required for reference conditions set by trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 7381 ---
3.13.2.2 Train related inputs 

--- Document Chunk 7382 ---
3.13.2.2.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 7383 ---
3.13.2.2.1.1 The train related inputs to be considered for the speed and distance monitoring are: 

--- Document Chunk 7384 ---
a) Traction model 

--- Document Chunk 7385 ---
b) Braking models (brake reaction time, brake build up time and speed dependent 

--- Document Chunk 7386 ---
deceleration) or brake percentage 

--- Document Chunk 7387 ---
c) Brake position 

--- Document Chunk 7388 ---
d) Special brakes (interface configuration and status) 

--- Document Chunk 7389 ---
e) Service brake (interface configuration and application) 

--- Document Chunk 7390 ---
f) Traction cut-off interface 

--- Document Chunk 7391 ---
g) On-board correction factors 

--- Document Chunk 7392 ---
h) Nominal rotating mass 

--- Document Chunk 7393 ---
i) Train length 

--- Document Chunk 7394 ---
j) Fixed values related to speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 7395 ---
k)  Train related speed restriction (i.e. the maximum train speed) 

--- Document Chunk 7396 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 7397 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7398 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7399 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 7400 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 7401 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 7402 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 7403 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 7404 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 7405 ---
Page 117/252 

--- Document Chunk 7406 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7407 ---
3.13.2.2.1.2 These train related inputs are acquired as Train Data (see 3.18.3.2 items b) c) and 

--- Document Chunk 7408 ---
d)), except: 

--- Document Chunk 7409 ---
• the configuration of the special brakes, service brake and traction cut -off interfaces 

--- Document Chunk 7410 ---
which are not affected by the Train Data acquisition, 

--- Document Chunk 7411 ---
• the service brake application and the special brakes statuses which are continuously 

--- Document Chunk 7412 ---
acquired on the Train Interface, 

--- Document Chunk 7413 ---
• the fixed values. 

--- Document Chunk 7414 ---
3.13.2.2.1.3 The speed and distance monitoring shall use braking models acquired as Train Data, 

--- Document Chunk 7415 ---
unless the brake percentage is acquired as Train Data and the conversion model is 

--- Document Chunk 7416 ---
applicable (see 3.13.3.2 for its validity limits). 

--- Document Chunk 7417 ---
3.13.2.2.2 Traction model 

--- Document Chunk 7418 ---
3.13.2.2.2.1 The traction model shall be given as a step function as indicated in Figure 29. 

--- Document Chunk 7419 ---
Depending on whether the traction cut -off command is implemented or not (see 

--- Document Chunk 7420 ---
3.13.2.2.8.1), i t shall describe the nominal traction cut -off time (T_traction_cut_off) 

--- Document Chunk 7421 ---
counted from the moment when either the traction cut-off command or the emergency 

--- Document Chunk 7422 ---
brake command is respectively triggered by the on -board (t0) to the moment the 

--- Document Chunk 7423 ---
acceleration due to traction (A_traction) is zero (t1). The estimated acceleration value of 

--- Document Chunk 7424 ---
the train shall be considered during this time. 

--- Document Chunk 7425 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7426 ---
A_traction 

--- Document Chunk 7427 ---
Estimated 

--- Document Chunk 7428 ---
acceleration 

--- Document Chunk 7429 ---
t0 t1 time 

--- Document Chunk 7430 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7431 ---
Figure 29: Traction Model 

--- Document Chunk 7432 ---
3.13.2.2.2.2 Note: The current value of A_traction is not known directly by the on -board. It is 

--- Document Chunk 7433 ---
implicitly know n as a contribution to the estimated acceleration, together with the 

--- Document Chunk 7434 ---
acceleration due to gradient. 

--- Document Chunk 7435 ---
3.13.2.2.3 Braking Models 

--- Document Chunk 7436 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1 Speed Dependent Deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 7437 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.1 The deceleration due to braking shall be given as a step function of the speed. 

--- Document Chunk 7438 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.2 It shall be possible to define up to seven steps for each speed dependent deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 7439 ---
model. 

--- Document Chunk 7440 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.3 Note: An example with 4 steps is given in Figure 30. A_brake(V) is calculated as 

--- Document Chunk 7441 ---
follows: 

--- Document Chunk 7442 ---

• A_brake = AD_0  when 0 ≤ speed ≤ V1 

--- Document Chunk 7454 ---

--- Document Chunk 7455 ---
• A_brake = AD_2  when V2 < speed ≤ V3 

--- Document Chunk 7456 ---
• A_brake = AD_3  when V3 < speed

3.13.2.2.3.1.4 The last step o f A_brake(V) shall by definition be considered as open ended, i.e. it 

--- Document Chunk 7468 ---
has no upper speed limit. 

--- Document Chunk 7469 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.5 The model shall be applicable only after full build up of the braking effort (see a_full 

--- Document Chunk 7470 ---
in Figure 31) 

--- Document Chunk 7471 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.6 The model shall be used for the emergency brake nominal deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 7472 ---
(A_brake_emergency(V)), for the full service brake deceleration (A_brake_service(V)) 

--- Document Chunk 7473 ---
and for the normal service brake deceleration (A_brake_normal_service(V)). 

--- Document Chunk 7474 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.7 It shall be possible to define individual speed dependent deceleration models of 

--- Document Chunk 7475 ---
A_brake_emergency(V) and A_brake_service(V)  for each combination of use of 

--- Document Chunk 7476 ---
regenerative brake, eddy current brake and magnetic shoe brake. 

--- Document Chunk 7477 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.8 Note: Individual deceleration models may be equal, thereby avoiding the influence of 

--- Document Chunk 7478 ---
a specific brake on A_brake_emergency(V) or A_brake_service(V). However, the choice 

--- Document Chunk 7479 ---
to take into account or not the contribution of a specific brake for A_brake_emergency(V) 

--- Document Chunk 7480 ---
or A_brake_service(V) is only rolling stock dependent, not an ETCS implementation 

--- Document Chunk 7481 ---
issue. 

--- Document Chunk 7482 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.9 It shall be possible to define up to two sets of three models of 

--- Document Chunk 7483 ---
A_brake_normal_service(V): 

--- Document Chunk 7484 ---
a) one set applicable when the brake position is in “Freight train in G” 

--- Document Chunk 7485 ---
b) one set applicable when the brake position is in “Passenger train in P” or “Freight train 

--- Document Chunk 7486 ---
in P” 

--- Document Chunk 7487 ---

3.13.2.2.3.1.10 A set of A_brake_normal_service(V) shall be defined as a function of the full 

--- Document Chunk 7499 ---
service brake deceleration at zero speed, A_brake_service(V=0): 

--- Document Chunk 7500 ---
If A_brake_service(V = 0)  A_SB01 

--- Document Chunk 7501 ---
A_brake_normal_service(V) = A_brake_normal_service_0(V) 

--- Document Chunk 7502 ---
if A_SB01 < A_brake_service(V = 0)  A_SB12 

--- Document Chunk 7503 ---
A_brake_normal_service(V) = A_brake_normal_service_1(V) 

--- Document Chunk 7504 ---
if A_SB12 < A_brake_service (V = 0) 

--- Document Chunk 7505 ---
A_brake_normal_service(V) = A_brake_normal_service_2(V) 

--- Document Chunk 7506 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.11 Note: the two pivot values A_SB01 and A_SB12 are part of the 

--- Document Chunk 7507 ---
A_brake_normal_service model, i.e. they are train related input data for the speed and 

--- Document Chunk 7508 ---
distance monitoring function. 

--- Document Chunk 7509 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2 Brake reaction time and brake build up time 

--- Document Chunk 7510 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.1 The deceleration A_brake is not available immediately after the on-board commands 

--- Document Chunk 7511 ---
the brake. There is a time lag between brake command and the start of the brake force 

--- Document Chunk 7512 ---
build-up. There is also time needed to build up the full brake force. 

--- Document Chunk 7513 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.2 The models for the brake build up time shall be given both as a ramp function and as 

--- Document Chunk 7514 ---
a step function as explained in Figure 31. 

--- Document Chunk 7515 ---
 A_brake 

--- Document Chunk 7516 ---
95% 

--- Document Chunk 7517 ---
a_full 

--- Document Chunk 7518 ---
t3 t2 t1 t0 time 

--- Document Chunk 7519 ---
possible 

--- Document Chunk 7520 ---
real shape 

--- Document Chunk 7521 ---
ramp  

--- Document Chunk 7522 ---
step  

--- Document Chunk 7523 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7524 ---
Figure 31: Brake Build Up Time Models 

--- Document Chunk 7525 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.3 In Figure 31, the following time intervals are defined: 

--- Document Chunk 7526 ---
a) T_brake_react (t0…t1) is the interval between the command of the brake by the on -

--- Document Chunk 7527 ---
board and the moment the brake force starts to build up. 

--- Document Chunk 7528 ---
b) T_brake_increase (t1...t2) is the interval in which the brake force increases from the 

--- Document Chunk 7529 ---
zero to the moment when 95% of full brake effort is reached. 

--- Document Chunk 7530 ---
c) T_brake_build_up (t0...t3) is the equivalent brake build up time. 

--- Document Chunk 7531 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 7532 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7533 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7534 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 7535 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 7536 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 7537 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 7538 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 7539 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 7540 ---
Page 120/252 

--- Document Chunk 7541 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7542 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.4 The equivalent brake build up time (T_brake_build_up) is defined as 

--- Document Chunk 7543 ---
T_brake_build_up = T_brake_react + 0.5*T_brake_increase. 

--- Document Chunk 7544 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.5 This model for T_brake_build_up shall  be used for the emergency brake 

--- Document Chunk 7545 ---
(T_brake_emergency) and for the full service brake (T_brake_service). 

--- Document Chunk 7546 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.6 Note: The equivalent brake build up time is a safe approximation. In the beginning of 

--- Document Chunk 7547 ---
the build-up time the ramp and step models assume a deceleration smaller than the real 

--- Document Chunk 7548 ---
shape, in the later part this is compensated by a higher deceleration. The approximation 

--- Document Chunk 7549 ---
done with the 95% factor is compensated by the margin between the models and the 

--- Document Chunk 7550 ---
real shape existing in the beginning of the build-up time. 

--- Document Chunk 7551 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.7 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 7552 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.8 It shall be possible to define individual values of T_brake_emergency_react, 

--- Document Chunk 7553 ---
T_brake_emergency, T_brake_service_react and T_brake_service for each combination 

--- Document Chunk 7554 ---
of use of regenerative brake, eddy current brake, magnetic shoe brake and Ep brake. 

--- Document Chunk 7555 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.9 Note: Individual values of T_brake_emergency and T_brake_service may be equal, 

--- Document Chunk 7556 ---
thereby avoiding the influence of a specific brake. However, the choice to take into 

--- Document Chunk 7557 ---
account or not the contribution of a specific brake for T_brake_emergency and 

--- Document Chunk 7558 ---
T_brake_service is only rolling stock dependent, not an ETCS implementation issue. 

--- Document Chunk 7559 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.10 Note: In general, T_brake_emergency and T_brake_service are determined by the 

--- Document Chunk 7560 ---
pneumatic brake therefore avoiding to take into account of the influence of the 

--- Document Chunk 7561 ---
regenerative brake, eddy current brake or magnetic shoe brake. However, if the Electro-

--- Document Chunk 7562 ---
pneumatic brake system is used, it is possible that T_brake_emergency and 

--- Document Chunk 7563 ---
T_brake_service are determined by another special brake. 

--- Document Chunk 7564 ---
3.13.2.2.4 Brake Position 

--- Document Chunk 7565 ---
3.13.2.2.4.1 The brake position shall be set to one of the following three values: 

--- Document Chunk 7566 ---
a) Passenger train in P 

--- Document Chunk 7567 ---
b) Freight train in P 

--- Document Chunk 7568 ---
c) Freight train in G 

--- Document Chunk 7569 ---
3.13.2.2.4.2 Note: The brake position defines the behaviour of the brake for specific train types. 

--- Document Chunk 7570 ---
3.13.2.2.5 Brake Percentage 

--- Document Chunk 7571 ---
3.13.2.2.5.1 If the brake percentage is captured as T rain Data and the conversion model is 

--- Document Chunk 7572 ---
applicable (see  3.13.3.2), they are used to derive A_brake _emergency(V), 

--- Document Chunk 7573 ---
A_brake_service(V), T_brake_emergency and T_brake_service. 

--- Document Chunk 7574 ---
