--- Document Chunk 7669 ---
3.13.2.2.6.3 When the brake percentage is captured as Train Data and the conversion model is 

--- Document Chunk 7670 ---
applicable, A_brake_emergency(V), T_brake_emergency and A_brake_service(V) shall 

--- Document Chunk 7671 ---
not be influenced by the status of a special brake. However, the conversion model offers 

--- Document Chunk 7672 ---
the possibility that T_brake _service can be affected by the status of the regenerative 

--- Document Chunk 7673 ---
brake, eddy current brake or Ep brake (see A.3.9). 

--- Document Chunk 7674 ---
3.13.2.2.6.4 The on-board equipment shall be configured to define whether it is allowed to take 

--- Document Chunk 7675 ---
into account the  contribution of a special/additional brake, which is independent from 

--- Document Chunk 7676 ---
wheel/rail adhesion, for the selection of the maximum emergency brake deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 7677 ---
under reduced adhesion conditions (see 3.13.6.2.1.6). 

--- Document Chunk 7678 ---
3.13.2.2.6.5 Note: the choice to set to “allowed” the contribution of such special/additional brake 

--- Document Chunk 7679 ---
in the selection of the maximum emergency braking effort, is rolling stock dependent. 

--- Document Chunk 7680 ---
3.13.2.2.6.6 If it is allowed to take into account the contribution of a special/additional brake, which 

--- Document Chunk 7681 ---
is independent from wheel/rail adhesion, the speed and distance monitoring function 

--- Document Chunk 7682 ---
shall take into account the status “active” or “not active” of the special/additional brake 

--- Document Chunk 7683 ---
to select the appropriate National Value under reduced adhesion conditions (see 

--- Document Chunk 7684 ---
3.13.2.3.7.7). 

--- Document Chunk 7685 ---
3.13.2.2.7 Service brake 

--- Document Chunk 7686 ---
3.13.2.2.7.1 The on-board shall be configured to define whethe r the service brake command is 

--- Document Chunk 7687 ---
implemented or not, i.e. whether a service brake interface is implemented to command 

--- Document Chunk 7688 ---
a full service brake effort. 

--- Document Chunk 7689 ---
3.13.2.2.7.2 The on-board shall be configured to define whether the service brake feedback is 

--- Document Chunk 7690 ---
implemented or not, i.e. whether it is able to acquire from the service brake interface the 

--- Document Chunk 7691 ---
information that the service brake is currently applied. 

--- Document Chunk 7692 ---
3.13.2.2.7.3 If the service brake feedback is implemented and if not inhibited by National Value, 

--- Document Chunk 7693 ---
the speed and distance monitoring function shall take into account either the main brake 

--- Document Chunk 7694 ---
pipe pressure or the brake cylinder pressure to adjust in real time the expected brake 

--- Document Chunk 7695 ---
build up time (see 3.13.9.3.3.4 and Appendix A.3.10). 

--- Document Chunk 7696 ---
3.13.2.2.8 Traction cut-off interface 

--- Document Chunk 7697 ---
3.13.2.2.8.1 The on-board shall be configured to define whether the traction cut -off command is 

--- Document Chunk 7698 ---
implemented, i.e. whether the interface to the traction system is implemented or not. 

--- Document Chunk 7699 ---
3.13.2.2.9 On-board Correction Factors 

--- Document Chunk 7700 ---
3.13.2.2.9.1 Correction factors for the emergency deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 7701 ---
3.13.2.2.9.1.1 If the braking models are captured as Train Data, rolling stock correction factors shall 

--- Document Chunk 7702 ---
be defined in the ETCS on-board equipment. If the brake percentage is captured as Train 

--- Document Chunk 7703 ---
Data and the conversion model is used (see 3.13.3.2 for its validity limits), no rolling 

--- Document Chunk 7704 ---
stock correction factor shall apply. 

--- Document Chunk 7705 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 7706 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7707 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7708 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 7709 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 7710 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 7711 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 7712 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 7713 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 7714 ---
Page 124/252 

--- Document Chunk 7715 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7716 ---
3.13.2.2.9.1.2 For each defined individual speed dependent deceleration model of 

--- Document Chunk 7717 ---
A_brake_emergency(V) (i.e. corresponding to each combination of use of regenerative 

--- Document Chunk 7718 ---
brake, eddy current brake and magnetic shoe brake), one set of rolling stock correction 

--- Document Chunk 7719 ---
factors Kdry_rst(V, EBCL) and Kwet_rst(V) shall be defined in the on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 7720 ---
3.13.2.2.9.1.3 For a given confidence level on emergency brake safe deceleration (EBCL), the rolling 

--- Document Chunk 7721 ---
stock correction factor Kdry_rst(V) shall be given as a step function of speed, with the 

--- Document Chunk 7722 ---
same steps as the ones of A_brake_emergency(V). 

--- Document Chunk 7723 ---
3.13.2.2.9.1.4 The confidence level on emergency brake safe deceleration represents the probability 

--- Document Chunk 7724 ---
of the following individual event: the rolling stock emergency brake subsystem of the train 

--- Document Chunk 7725 ---
does ensure a deceleration at least equal to A_brake_emergency(V) * Kdry_rst(V), when 

--- Document Chunk 7726 ---
the emergency brake is commanded on dry rails. 

--- Document Chunk 7727 ---
3.13.2.2.9.1.5 The rolling stock correction factor Kwet_rst(V) shall be given as a step function of 

--- Document Chunk 7728 ---
speed, with the same steps as the ones of A_brake_emergency(V). It represents the loss 

--- Document Chunk 7729 ---
of deceleration with regards to emergency braking on dry rails, when the emergency 

--- Document Chunk 7730 ---
brake is commanded on wet rails, according to wheel/rail adhesion reference conditions. 

--- Document Chunk 7731 ---
3.13.2.2.9.2 Correction factor for gradient on normal service deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 7732 ---
3.13.2.2.9.2.1 The speed depen dent correction factors for gradient on the normal service brake, 

--- Document Chunk 7733 ---
Kn+(V) and Kn-(V), shall be given as step functions in the range from 0 to 10 m/s2. 

--- Document Chunk 7734 ---
3.13.2.2.9.2.2 It shall be possible to define up to five steps for Kn+(V) and for Kn-(V), respectively. 

--- Document Chunk 7735 ---
3.13.2.2.9.2.3 Note: An example with 4 steps is given in Figure 32. Kn is calculated as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 7736 ---
• Kn = Kn_0 when 0 ≤ speed ≤ V1 

--- Document Chunk 7737 ---
• Kn = Kn_1 when V1 < speed ≤ V2 

--- Document Chunk 7738 ---
• Kn = Kn_2 when V2 < speed ≤ V3 

--- Document Chunk 7739 ---
• Kn = Kn_3 when V3 < speed 

--- Document Chunk 7740 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7741 ---
V3 V2 V1 speed 

--- Document Chunk 7742 ---
Kn 

--- Document Chunk 7743 ---
Kn_1 

--- Document Chunk 7744 ---
Kn_0 

--- Document Chunk 7745 ---
Kn_2 

--- Document Chunk 7746 ---
Kn_3 

--- Document Chunk 7747 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7748 ---
Figure 32  Speed dependent correction factor for normal service brake (Kn) 

--- Document Chunk 7749 ---
3.13.2.2.9.2.4 Kn+(V) shall be applicable for positive gradients. 

--- Document Chunk 7750 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 7751 ---

3.13.2.2.9.2.5 Kn-(V) shall be applicable for negative gradients. 

--- Document Chunk 7762 ---
3.13.2.2.9.2.6 The last step of the Kn+(V) or Kn-(V) shall by definition be considered as open ended, 

--- Document Chunk 7763 ---
i.e. it has no upper speed limit. 

--- Document Chunk 7764 ---
3.13.2.2.10 Nominal Rotating mass 

--- Document Chunk 7765 ---
3.13.2.2.10.1 It shall be possible to define the nominal rotating mass to be used for compensating 

--- Document Chunk 7766 ---
the gradient, instead of the two related fixed values defined in A.3.1. 

--- Document Chunk 7767 ---
3.13.2.2.11 Train length 

--- Document Chunk 7768 ---
3.13.2.2.11.1 The speed and distance monitoring shall take into account the train length acquired 

--- Document Chunk 7769 ---
as part of Train Data (see section 3.18.3). 

--- Document Chunk 7770 ---
3.13.2.2.12 Fixed values 

--- Document Chunk 7771 ---
3.13.2.2.12.1 The speed and distance monitoring shall take into account the fixed values defined in 

--- Document Chunk 7772 ---
A.3.1 that are related to speed and distance monitoring. 

--- Document Chunk 7773 ---
3.13.2.2.13 Maximum train speed 

--- Document Chunk 7774 ---
3.13.2.2.13.1 The speed and distance monitoring shall take into account the maximum train speed 

--- Document Chunk 7775 ---
defined as part of Train Data (see section 3.18.3). 

--- Document Chunk 7776 ---
3.13.2.3 Trackside related inputs 

--- Document Chunk 7777 ---
3.13.2.3.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 7778 ---
3.13.2.3.1.1 The trackside related inputs to be considered for the speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 7779 ---
are: 

--- Document Chunk 7780 ---
a) Trackside related speed restrictions 

--- Document Chunk 7781 ---
b) Gradients 

--- Document Chunk 7782 ---
c) Track conditions related to brake inhibition 

--- Document Chunk 7783 ---
d) Track conditions related to powerless section 

--- Document Chunk 7784 ---
e) Reduced adhesion conditions 

--- Document Chunk 7785 ---
f) Specific speed and distance limits (e.g. EOA/SvL) 

--- Document Chunk 7786 ---
g) National Values 

--- Document Chunk 7787 ---
3.13.2.3.2 Trackside related speed restrictions 

--- Document Chunk 7788 ---
3.13.2.3.2.1 The speed and distance monitoring shall take into account the trackside related speed 

--- Document Chunk 7789 ---
restrictions composed of all speed restrictions mentioned in 3.11.2 except the maximum 

--- Document Chunk 7790 ---
train speed. 

--- Document Chunk 7791 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 7792 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7793 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7794 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 7795 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 7796 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 7797 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 7798 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 7799 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 7800 ---
Page 126/252 

--- Document Chunk 7801 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7802 ---
3.13.2.3.3 Gradients 

--- Document Chunk 7803 ---
3.13.2.3.3.1 The speed and distance monitoring shall take into account the gradient profile and 

--- Document Chunk 7804 ---
the default gradient for TSR (see section 3.11.12). 

--- Document Chunk 7805 ---
3.13.2.3.4 Track conditions 

--- Document Chunk 7806 ---
3.13.2.3.4.1 The speed and distance monitoring shall take into account the following types of track 

--- Document Chunk 7807 ---
condition received from trackside (see section 3.12.1): powerless section,  inhibition of 

--- Document Chunk 7808 ---
regenerative brake, eddy current brake and magnetic shoe brake. 

--- Document Chunk 7809 ---
3.13.2.3.5 Reduced adhesion conditions 

--- Document Chunk 7810 ---
3.13.2.3.5.1 The speed and distance monitoring shall take into account the track reduced adhesion 

--- Document Chunk 7811 ---
received from trackside or selected by the driver (see section 3.18.4.6). 

--- Document Chunk 7812 ---
3.13.2.3.6 Specific speed / distance limits 

--- Document Chunk 7813 ---
3.13.2.3.6.1 The speed and distance monitoring shall take into account the following limits: 

--- Document Chunk 7814 ---
a) the Limit of Authority (LOA), the End of Authority (EOA), the Supervised Location 

--- Document Chunk 7815 ---
(SvL) and its associated release speed, if any. 

--- Document Chunk 7816 ---
b) the maximum permitted distance to run in Staff Responsible 

--- Document Chunk 7817 ---
3.13.2.3.7 National Values for speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 7818 ---
3.13.2.3.7.1 It shall be possible by means of a National Value to inhibit the use of the service brake 

--- Document Chunk 7819 ---
command in target speed monitoring. 

--- Document Chunk 7820 ---
3.13.2.3.7.2 It shall be possible to state by means of a National Value whether an emergency 

--- Document Chunk 7821 ---
brake command has to be revoked, both in ceiling speed and target speed monitoring, 

--- Document Chunk 7822 ---
when: 

--- Document Chunk 7823 ---
a) the Permitted Speed supervision limit is no longer exceeded, or 

--- Document Chunk 7824 ---
b) the train is at standstill. 

--- Document Chunk 7825 ---
3.13.2.3.7.3 It shall be possible by means of a National Value to inhibit the guidance curve (GUI). 

--- Document Chunk 7826 ---
3.13.2.3.7.4 It shall be possible by means of a National Value to inhibit the service brake feedback 

--- Document Chunk 7827 ---
function. 

--- Document Chunk 7828 ---
3.13.2.3.7.5 It shall be possible by means of National Values to indicate to the on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 7829 ---
the required confidence level on the emergency brake safe deceleration, when the 

--- Document Chunk 7830 ---
emergency brake is commanded on dry rails (see 3.13.2.2.9.1.4). 

--- Document Chunk 7831 ---
3.13.2.3.7.6 It shall be possible by means of a National Value to indicate to the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 7832 ---
equipment the available wheel/rail adhesion, weighted between the wheel/rail adhesion 

--- Document Chunk 7833 ---
for dry rails and the wheel/rail adhesion for wet rails according to reference conditions. 

--- Document Chunk 7834 ---
3.13.2.3.7.7 In order to adapt to the train behaviour under reduced adhesion conditions, it shall be 

--- Document Chunk 7835 ---
possible by means of Natio nal Values either to limit to a maximum value the speed 

--- Document Chunk 7836 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 7837 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7838 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7839 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 7840 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 7841 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 7842 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 7843 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 7844 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 7845 ---
Page 127/252 

--- Document Chunk 7846 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7847 ---
dependent deceleration for the emergency brake when the reduced adhesion conditions 

--- Document Chunk 7848 ---
are known to ETCS (see 3.13.2.3.5) or to request supplementary DMI information 

--- Document Chunk 7849 ---
assisting further the driver in ceiling speed monitoring. Three values shall be applicable 

--- Document Chunk 7850 ---
for a given combination of the brake position and of the type of brakes: 

--- Document Chunk 7851 ---
a) the first value shall be used for “Passenger train in P” with special/additional brakes 

--- Document Chunk 7852 ---
independent from wheel/rail adhesion; 

--- Document Chunk 7853 ---
b) the second value shall be used for “Passenger train in P” without special/additional 

--- Document Chunk 7854 ---
brakes independent from wheel/rail adhesion; 

--- Document Chunk 7855 ---
c) the third value shall be used for “Freight train in P” or “Freight train in G”. 

--- Document Chunk 7856 ---
3.13.2.3.7.8 It shall be possible by means of a National Value to specify a release speed. 

--- Document Chunk 7857 ---
3.13.2.3.7.9 It shall be possible by means of a National Value to inhibit the compensation of the 

--- Document Chunk 7858 ---
speed measurement inaccuracy. 

--- Document Chunk 7859 ---
3.13.2.3.7.10 It shall be possible by means of National Values to define integrated correction 

--- Document Chunk 7860 ---
factors, namely Kv_int(V), Kr_i nt(l) and Kt_int. The integrated correction factors only 

--- Document Chunk 7861 ---
apply to the on-board equipment when the conversion model is used. 

--- Document Chunk 7862 ---
3.13.2.3.7.11 The speed dependent correction factor, Kv_int(V), shall be given as a step function. 

--- Document Chunk 7863 ---
3.13.2.3.7.11.1 It shall be possible to define up to five steps for Kv_int(V). 

--- Document Chunk 7864 ---
3.13.2.3.7.11.2 Note: An example with 4 steps is given in Figure 33. Kv_int is calculated as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 7865 ---
• Kv_int = Kv_int_0 when 0 ≤ speed ≤ V1 

--- Document Chunk 7866 ---
• Kv_int = Kv_int_1 when V1 < speed ≤ V2 

--- Document Chunk 7867 ---
• Kv_int = Kv_int_2 when V2 < speed ≤ V3 

--- Document Chunk 7868 ---
• Kv_int = Kv_int_3 when V3 < speed 

--- Document Chunk 7869 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7870 ---
V3 V2 V1 speed 

--- Document Chunk 7871 ---
Kv_int 

--- Document Chunk 7872 ---
Kv_int_1 

--- Document Chunk 7873 ---

--- Document Chunk 7878 ---
3.13.2.3.7.11.3 It shall be possible to define up to 2 sets of Kv_i nt with separate speed limits V1, 

--- Document Chunk 7879 ---
V2, .. for each set. The sets of Kv_int relate to the following train types: 

--- Document Chunk 7880 ---

--- Document Chunk 7890 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7891 ---
1) Freight trains 

--- Document Chunk 7892 ---
2) Conventional passenger trains 

--- Document Chunk 7893 ---
3.13.2.3.7.11.3.1 Note: Different sets of Kv_int are needed for different types of trains in order to 

--- Document Chunk 7894 ---
compensate the absence of the rolling stock related correction factors when the 

--- Document Chunk 7895 ---
conversion model is used. 

--- Document Chunk 7896 ---
3.13.2.3.7.11.4 The set of Kv_int for conventional passenger trains shall be divided into two sub 

--- Document Chunk 7897 ---
sets Kv_int_x_a and Kv_int_x_b, with identical speed limits V1, V2, .... 

--- Document Chunk 7898 ---
3.13.2.3.7.11.5 Subset Kv_int_x_a shall be applicable for maximum emergency brake deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 7899 ---
lower or equal to a deceleration limit, defined as a National Value. 

--- Document Chunk 7900 ---
3.13.2.3.7.11.6 Subset Kv_int_x_b shall be applicable for maximum emergency brake deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 7901 ---
greater or equal to a deceleration limit, defined as a National Value. 

--- Document Chunk 7902 ---
3.13.2.3.7.12 The train length dependent correction factor, Kr_int(l), shall be given as a step 

--- Document Chunk 7903 ---
function. 

--- Document Chunk 7904 ---
3.13.2.3.7.12.1 It shall be possible to define up to five steps for Kr_int(l). 

--- Document Chunk 7905 ---
3.13.2.3.7.12.2 Note: An example with 4 steps is given in Figure 34. Kr_int is calculated as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 7906 ---
• Kr_int = Kr_int_0 when 0 ≤ train length ≤ L1 

--- Document Chunk 7907 ---
• Kr_int = Kr_int_1 when L1 < train length ≤ L2 

--- Document Chunk 7908 ---
• Kr_int = Kr_int_2 when L2 < train length ≤ L3 

--- Document Chunk 7909 ---
• Kr_int = Kr_int_3 when L3 < train length 

--- Document Chunk 7910 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7911 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7912 ---

--- Document Chunk 7934 ---
3.13.3 Conversion Models 

--- Document Chunk 7935 ---
3.13.3.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 7936 ---
3.13.3.1.1 For trains with variable composition (loco hauled trains), the brak e characteristics can 

--- Document Chunk 7937 ---
vary together with the composition of the train. In this case, it is not convenient to pre -

--- Document Chunk 7938 ---
program the brake parameters necessary to calculate the braking curves. The only 

--- Document Chunk 7939 ---
practical way to obtain the correct values for the current tra in composition is to include 

--- Document Chunk 7940 ---
them into the data entry process by the driver. However, it cannot be expected from the 

--- Document Chunk 7941 ---
driver to know deceleration values and brake build up times. Conversion models are 

--- Document Chunk 7942 ---
therefore defined to convert the parameters entered by the driver (brake percentage and 

--- Document Chunk 7943 ---
brake position) into the parameters of the corresponding brake model. 

--- Document Chunk 7944 ---
3.13.3.1.2 Note: The process for defining the input parameters for the conversion model (brake 

--- Document Chunk 7945 ---
percentage and brake position) is outside the scope of the ERTMS/ETCS specifications. 

--- Document Chunk 7946 ---
3.13.3.2 Applicability of the conversion models 

--- Document Chunk 7947 ---
3.13.3.2.1 The conversion models shall be used by the on-board equipment if the brake percentage 

--- Document Chunk 7948 ---
is acquired as part of Train Data, and if the maximum train speed, the brake percentage 

--- Document Chunk 7949 ---
and the train length are all within the following validity limits of the conversion models: 

--- Document Chunk 7950 ---
a) 0 ≤ V ≤ 200, where V is the maximum train speed in km/h 

--- Document Chunk 7951 ---
b) 30 ≤ λ ≤ 250, where λ is the brake percentage in % 

--- Document Chunk 7952 ---
c) 0 ≤ L ≤ Lmax, where L is the train length in m  and where Lmax = 900 m if the brake 

--- Document Chunk 7953 ---
position is “Passenger train in P” or Lmax = 1500  m if the brake position is “Freight 

--- Document Chunk 7954 ---
train in P” or “Freight train in G” 

--- Document Chunk 7955 ---
3.13.3.2.1.1 Note: The overspeed above the maximum train speed which may occur due to the 

--- Document Chunk 7956 ---
ceiling speed margins is taken into account in the definition of the conversion model. 

--- Document Chunk 7957 ---
3.13.3.2.2 For trains not fitting into at least one of those validity limits, it is still possible to acquire 

--- Document Chunk 7958 ---
the brake percentage as Train Data, but the conversion models are not applicable, which 

--- Document Chunk 7959 ---
means that braking models (i.e. pre-programmed deceleration profiles and brake build 

--- Document Chunk 7960 ---
up times) shall be used by the speed and distance monitoring function. 

--- Document Chunk 7961 ---
3.13.3.3 Brake percentage conversion model 

--- Document Chunk 7962 ---
3.13.3.3.1 Input parameters 

--- Document Chunk 7963 ---
3.13.3.3.1.1 The input for the model shall be the brake percentage of the train as defined in 

--- Document Chunk 7964 ---
3.13.2.2.5. 

--- Document Chunk 7965 ---
3.13.3.3.2 Calculation of the basic deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 7966 ---
3.13.3.3.2.1 The basic deceleration A_basic(V) shall be given as a step function of the speed using 

--- Document Chunk 7967 ---
the algorithm defined in Appendix A.3.7. 

--- Document Chunk 7968 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 7969 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7970 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7971 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 7972 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 7973 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 7974 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 7975 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 7976 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 7977 ---
Page 130/252 

--- Document Chunk 7978 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 7979 ---
3.13.3.3.3 Output parameters 

--- Document Chunk 7980 ---
3.13.3.3.3.1 The ou tput of the brake percentage conversion model shall consist of two speed 

--- Document Chunk 7981 ---
dependent deceleration brake models, A_brake_emergency(V) for the emergency brake 

--- Document Chunk 7982 ---
and A_brake_service(V) for the service brake. 

--- Document Chunk 7983 ---
3.13.3.4 Brake position conversion model 

--- Document Chunk 7984 ---
3.13.3.4.1 Input parameters 

--- Document Chunk 7985 ---
3.13.3.4.1.1 The input for the model shall consist of the brake position of the train as defined in 

--- Document Chunk 7986 ---
3.13.2.2.4, the train length and the target speed. 

--- Document Chunk 7987 ---
3.13.3.4.2 Calculation of the emergency brake reaction time and equivalent build up time 

--- Document Chunk 7988 ---
3.13.3.4.2.1 The brake reaction time and equivalent brake build up time for the emergency brake 

--- Document Chunk 7989 ---
shall be determined as specified in Appendix A.3.8. 

--- Document Chunk 7990 ---
3.13.3.4.3 Calculation of the full service brake reaction time and equivalent build up time 

--- Document Chunk 7991 ---
3.13.3.4.3.1 The brake reaction time and equivalent brake build up time for the full service brake 

--- Document Chunk 7992 ---
shall be determined as specified in Appendix A.3.9. 

--- Document Chunk 7993 ---
3.13.3.4.4 Output parameters 

--- Document Chunk 7994 ---
3.13.3.4.4.1 The outputs of the brake position conversion model shall consist of: 

--- Document Chunk 7995 ---
a) two values of the equivalent brake build up time to be used when the target speed 

--- Document Chunk 7996 ---
(V_target) is equal to zero, one value for the emergency brake and one for the full 

--- Document Chunk 7997 ---
service brake: 

--- Document Chunk 7998 ---
T_brake_emergency_cm0 as defined for emergency brake in A.3.8 

--- Document Chunk 7999 ---
T_brake_service_cm0 as defined for service brake in A.3.9 

--- Document Chunk 8000 ---
b) two values of the equivalent brake build up time to be used when the target speed 

--- Document Chunk 8001 ---
(V_target) is different from zero, one value for the emergency brake and one for the 

--- Document Chunk 8002 ---
full service brake: 

--- Document Chunk 8003 ---
T_brake_emergency_cmt as defined for emergency brake in A.3.8 

--- Document Chunk 8004 ---
T_brake_service_cmt as defined for service brake in A.3.9 

--- Document Chunk 8005 ---
c) two values of the brake reaction time, one value for the emergency brake and one for 

--- Document Chunk 8006 ---
the full service brake: 

--- Document Chunk 8007 ---
T_brake_emergency_react value as defined for emergency brake in A.3.8 

--- Document Chunk 8008 ---
T_brake_service_react value as defined for service brake in A.3.9 

--- Document Chunk 8009 ---

--- Document Chunk 8077 ---

--- Document Chunk 8080 ---
(actual) train front end location and the SvL, the acceleration due to the gradient shall be 

--- Document Chunk 8081 ---
determined using the lowest (taking the sign into account) gradient value give n by the 

--- Document Chunk 8082 ---

--- Document Chunk 8092 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8093 ---
gradient profile between the location of the fictive train front end and the location of the 

--- Document Chunk 8094 ---
fictive train rear end (see Figure 35). 

--- Document Chunk 8095 ---
3.13.4.3 Rotating mass 

--- Document Chunk 8096 ---
3.13.4.3.1 The influence of gradients shall be compensated for the rotating mass of the train (see 

--- Document Chunk 8097 ---
Figure 35). 

--- Document Chunk 8098 ---
3.13.4.3.1.1 Note: Since the rotating mass works like a flywheel (rotating inertia), the effect of the 

--- Document Chunk 8099 ---
gradient is reduced. Assume for instance a (theoretical) train without any rotating mass, 

--- Document Chunk 8100 ---
not braking, on a downhill gradient from height 1 to height 2. All the energy added to the 

--- Document Chunk 8101 ---
train when it goes from H1 to H2 is converted into linear forward motion. This can be 

--- Document Chunk 8102 ---
observed as an acceleration due to the gradient. Now assume the same train with part 

--- Document Chunk 8103 ---
of the weight rotating. If this train travels the same distance from H1 to H2, the same 

--- Document Chunk 8104 ---
amount of energy is added t o the train. But now a part of that energy is converted into 

--- Document Chunk 8105 ---
rotational motion and only the remaining part is converted into linear forward motion. The 

--- Document Chunk 8106 ---
latter can be observed as an acceleration which is less than for the train without rotating 

--- Document Chunk 8107 ---
mass. 

--- Document Chunk 8108 ---
3.13.4.3.1.2 Note: For the influence of the rotating mass on the deceleration due to the brake, it is 

--- Document Chunk 8109 ---
already taken into account in the values for the brake parameters. 

--- Document Chunk 8110 ---
3.13.4.3.2 The following formulas shall be used: 

--- Document Chunk 8111 ---
a) If M_rotating_nom is unknown: 

--- Document Chunk 8112 ---
• Uphill: A_gradient = g * grad / (1000+10*M_rotating_max) 

--- Document Chunk 8113 ---
• Downhill: A_gradient = g * grad / (1000+10*M_rotating_min) 

--- Document Chunk 8114 ---
b) If M_rotating_nom is known: 

--- Document Chunk 8115 ---
• Uphill: A_gradient = g * grad / (1000+10*M_rotating_nom) 

--- Document Chunk 8116 ---
• Downhill: A_gradient = g * grad / (1000+10*M_rotating_nom) 

--- Document Chunk 8117 ---
Legend: 

--- Document Chunk 8118 ---
A_gradient = acceleration/deceleration due to gradient (downhill acceleration is given 

--- Document Chunk 8119 ---
with a negative value) 

--- Document Chunk 8120 ---
g = 9.81 m/s2 - acceleration of gravity in m/s2 

--- Document Chunk 8121 ---
grad = gradient values in ‰ (positive = uphill) 

--- Document Chunk 8122 ---
M_rotating_nom = nominal rotating mass (part of train data) as a percentage of the 

--- Document Chunk 8123 ---
total train weight 

--- Document Chunk 8124 ---
M_rotating_max = maximum possible rotating mass (see A.3.1) as a percentage of the 

--- Document Chunk 8125 ---
total train weight 

--- Document Chunk 8126 ---
M_rotating_min = minimum possible rotating mass (see A.3.1) as a percentage of the 

--- Document Chunk 8127 ---
total train weight 

--- Document Chunk 8128 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 8129 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8130 ---

--- Document Chunk 8138 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8139 ---
3.13.5 Determination of locations without special brake contribution and with 

--- Document Chunk 8140 ---
reduced adhesion conditions 

--- Document Chunk 8141 ---
3.13.5.1 As long as it uses a track condition profile given by trackside, the on-board shall consider 

--- Document Chunk 8142 ---
locations without special brake contribution over a distance going from the start location 

--- Document Chunk 8143 ---
of the profile to the foot of the deceleration c urve ( EBD, SBD or GUI, see section s 

--- Document Chunk 8144 ---
3.13.8.3, 3.13.8.4 and 3.13.8.5). 

--- Document Chunk 8145 ---
3.13.5.2 If the status of a special brake is “not active”, all locations shall be considered without 

--- Document Chunk 8146 ---
the contribution of this special brake. 

--- Document Chunk 8147 ---
3.13.5.2.1 Note: in such case, a track condition profile implying th e inhibition of this special brake 

--- Document Chunk 8148 ---
will have no effect. 

--- Document Chunk 8149 ---
3.13.5.3 From the adhesion profile given by trackside, the on-board shall consider locations with 

--- Document Chunk 8150 ---
reduced adhesion conditions over a distance going from the start location of the profile 

--- Document Chunk 8151 ---
to the location derived by adding the train length to the end location of the profile. 

--- Document Chunk 8152 ---
3.13.5.4 When slippery rail is selected by the driver, all locations shall be considered with reduced 

--- Document Chunk 8153 ---
adhesion conditions. 

--- Document Chunk 8154 ---
3.13.5.5 The speed and distance monitoring shall use, as resulting reduced adhesion conditions, 

--- Document Chunk 8155 ---
the most restrictive value of the adhesion conditions selected by the driver and the 

--- Document Chunk 8156 ---
adhesion conditions calculated from the trackside profile. 

--- Document Chunk 8157 ---
3.13.6 Calculation of the deceleration and brake build up time 

--- Document Chunk 8158 ---
3.13.6.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 8159 ---
3.13.6.1.1 This chapter describes  how the safe  emergency brake, the expected and the normal 

--- Document Chunk 8160 ---
service brake decelerations and the time intervals due to brake build up time are 

--- Document Chunk 8161 ---
calculated. 

--- Document Chunk 8162 ---
3.13.6.2 Emergency brake 

--- Document Chunk 8163 ---
3.13.6.2.1 Safe deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 8164 ---
3.13.6.2.1.1 The safe deceleration, A_safe(V,d), is safety relevant. This means th at for the 

--- Document Chunk 8165 ---
calculation of the safe deceleration, all necessary track and train characteristics shall be 

--- Document Chunk 8166 ---
taken into account. 

--- Document Chunk 8167 ---
3.13.6.2.1.2 The train and track related characteristics to be considered are: 

--- Document Chunk 8168 ---
a) The speed dependent deceleration model(s) for the emergency brake either acquired 

--- Document Chunk 8169 ---
as part of Train Data (see 3.13.2.2.3.1) or derived from the brake percentage using 

--- Document Chunk 8170 ---
the conversion model (see 3.13.3.3) 

--- Document Chunk 8171 ---
b) The acceleration/deceleration due to gradient i.e. A_gradient(d) (see c)) 

--- Document Chunk 8172 ---
c) The locations with reduced adhesion conditions (see 3.13.5) 

--- Document Chunk 8173 ---
d) The National Values for reduced adhesion condition (see 3.13.2.3.7.7) 

--- Document Chunk 8174 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 8175 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8176 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8177 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 8178 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 8179 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 8180 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 8181 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 8182 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 8183 ---
Page 134/252 

--- Document Chunk 8184 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8185 ---
e) The locations with out special  brake contribution (see  3.13.5), only if the speed 

--- Document Chunk 8186 ---
dependent deceleration model(s) for the emergency brake are acquired as part of 

--- Document Chunk 8187 ---
Train Data 

--- Document Chunk 8188 ---
f) The rolling stock  correction factors K dry_rst(V, EBCL ) and K wet_rst(V) (see 

--- Document Chunk 8189 ---
3.13.2.2.9.1), only if the speed dependent deceleration model(s) for the emergency 

--- Document Chunk 8190 ---
brake are acquired as part of Train Data 

--- Document Chunk 8191 ---
g) The National Values for confidence level on emergency brake safe deceleration and 

--- Document Chunk 8192 ---
for the available wheel/rail adhesion  (see 3.13.2.3.7.5 & 3.13.2.3.7.6), only if the 

--- Document Chunk 8193 ---
speed dependent deceleration model(s) for the emergency brake are acquired as part 

--- Document Chunk 8194 ---
of Train Data 

--- Document Chunk 8195 ---
h) The integrated correction factors Kv_int(V) (with the two pivot deceleration values for 

--- Document Chunk 8196 ---
passenger trains) and Kr_int(l) (see 3.13.2.3.7), only if the conversion model is used 

--- Document Chunk 8197 ---
i) The brake position (see 3.13.2.2.4) 

--- Document Chunk 8198 ---
j) The acquired train length L_TRAIN (see 3.13.2.2.11), only if the conversion model is 

--- Document Chunk 8199 ---
used 

--- Document Chunk 8200 ---
3.13.6.2.1.3 A_safe(V,d) shall be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 8201 ---
For locations with normal adhesion conditions  and for locations with reduced 

--- Document Chunk 8202 ---
adhesion conditions when A_MAXREDADH does not limit to a maximum value the 

--- Document Chunk 8203 ---
speed dependent deceleration for the emergency brake: 

--- Document Chunk 8204 ---
A_safe(V,d) = A_brake_safe(V,d) + A_gradient(d) 

--- Document Chunk 8205 ---
For locations with reduced adhesion conditions when A_MAXREDADH limits to a 

--- Document Chunk 8206 ---
maximum value the speed dependent deceleration for the emergency brake: 

--- Document Chunk 8207 ---
A_safe(V,d) = MIN(A_brake_safe(V,d) , A_MAXREDADH) + A_gradient(d) 

--- Document Chunk 8208 ---
3.13.6.2.1.4 A_brake_safe(V,d) shall be the safe emergency brake deceleration. 

--- Document Chunk 8209 ---
A_brake_safe(V,d) shall be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 8210 ---
If the speed dependent deceleration model(s) for the emergency brake are 

--- Document Chunk 8211 ---
acquired as part of Train Data: 

--- Document Chunk 8212 ---
A_brake_safe(V,d) = Kdry_rst(V, M_NVEBCL) * (Kwet_rst(V) + M_NVAVADH 

--- Document Chunk 8213 ---
*(1- Kwet_rst(V))) * A_brake_emergency(V,d) 

--- Document Chunk 8214 ---
If the conversion model is used: 

--- Document Chunk 8215 ---
A_brake_safe(V) = Kv_int(V) * Kr_int(L_TRAIN) * A_brake_emergency(V) 

--- Document Chunk 8216 ---
3.13.6.2.1.5 A_brake_emergency(V,d) shall be the emergency brake deceleration as a function of 

--- Document Chunk 8217 ---
the speed, of the locations with change of special brake(s) contribution encountered 

--- Document Chunk 8218 ---
between the train front and the foot of the EBD curve. A_brake_emergency(V,d) shall be 

--- Document Chunk 8219 ---
equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 8220 ---
A_brake_emergency1(V) when destfront ≤ d ≤ d1 

--- Document Chunk 8221 ---
A_brake_emergency2(V) when d1 < d ≤ d2 

--- Document Chunk 8222 ---
A_brake_emergency3(V) when d2 < d ≤ d3 

--- Document Chunk 8223 ---
.... 

--- Document Chunk 8224 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 8225 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8226 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8227 ---

--- Document Chunk 8232 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 8233 ---

--- Document Chunk 8234 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8235 ---
Where 

--- Document Chunk 8236 ---
d1, d2, d3,... are the locations with change of special brake(s) contribution 

--- Document Chunk 8237 ---
A_brake_emergencyx(V) is equal to the emergency brake model, A_brake_emergency, 

--- Document Chunk 8238 ---
applicable for the concerned combination of brake.

--- Document Chunk 8248 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8249 ---
Figure 36: Influence of track conditions on A_brake_emergency(V,d) 

--- Document Chunk 8250 ---
3.13.6.2.1.6 A_MAXREDADH shall be the value, out of the three related National Values, 

--- Document Chunk 8251 ---
applicable for this train according to: 

--- Document Chunk 8252 ---
a) its brake position 

--- Document Chunk 8253 ---
b) whether special/additional brakes inde pendent from wheel/rail adhesion are active 

--- Document Chunk 8254 ---
and it is allowed to take into account their contribution to the emergency braking effort. 

--- Document Chunk 8255 ---
3.13.6.2.1.7 Kdry_rst(V, M_NVEBCL) shall be the rolling stock correction factor, as a function of 

--- Document Chunk 8256 ---
speed (with speed steps identical wi th the ones of A_brake_emergency(V)), 

--- Document Chunk 8257 ---
corresponding to the confidence level on emergency brake safe deceleration required 

--- Document Chunk 8258 ---
by trackside (National Value). 

--- Document Chunk 8259 ---
3.13.6.2.1.8 Kv_int(V) shall be the integrated correction factor applicable for the train, selected 

--- Document Chunk 8260 ---
according to the brake position. 

--- Document Chunk 8261 ---
3.13.6.2.1.8.1 If the brake position is “Passenger train in P”, the set of Kv_int shall be calculated as 

--- Document Chunk 8262 ---
a function of the maximum emergency brake deceleration (A_ebmax) in the following 

--- Document Chunk 8263 ---
way (see also figure 10): 

--- Document Chunk 8264 ---
Kv_int_x = Kv_int_x_a  when  A_ebmax ≤ A_P12. 

--- Document Chunk 8265 ---
Kv_int_x = Kv_int_x_b  when  A_ebmax ≥ A_P23. 

--- Document Chunk 8266 ---
Kv_int_x = Kv_int_x_a + (A_ebmax - A_P12)/(A_P23 - A_P12) * (Kv_int_x_b - 

--- Document Chunk 8267 ---
Kv_int_x_a) when  A_P12 < A_ebmax < A_P23.” 

--- Document Chunk 8268 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 8269 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8270 ---

3.13.6.2.2 Safe brake build up time 

--- Document Chunk 8329 ---
3.13.6.2.2.1 The safe brake build up time, T_be, is safety rele vant. This means that for the 

--- Document Chunk 8330 ---
calculation of the safe brake build up time, all necessary track and train characteristics 

--- Document Chunk 8331 ---
shall be taken into account. 

--- Document Chunk 8332 ---
3.13.6.2.2.2 The train and track related characteristics to be considered are: 

--- Document Chunk 8333 ---
a) The values of T_brake_emergency_react and T_brake_emergency acquired as part 

--- Document Chunk 8334 ---
of Train Data (see 3.13.2.2.3.2.8) or the values of T_brake_emergency_react and 

--- Document Chunk 8335 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 8336 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8337 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8338 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 8339 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 8340 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 8341 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 8342 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 8343 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 8344 ---
Page 137/252 

--- Document Chunk 8345 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8346 ---
T_brake_emergency derived from the conversion model (see 3.13.3.4) using the 

--- Document Chunk 8347 ---
brake position and train length acquired as Train Data. 

--- Document Chunk 8348 ---
b) The integrated correction factor Kt_in t, only if the conversion model is used  (see 

--- Document Chunk 8349 ---
3.13.2.3.7) 

--- Document Chunk 8350 ---
c) The status of the regenerative brake, eddy current brake, magnetic shoe brake and 

--- Document Chunk 8351 ---
Ep brake  system (see 3.13.2.2.6), only if the values of T_brake_emergency are 

--- Document Chunk 8352 ---
acquired as part of Train Data 

--- Document Chunk 8353 ---
3.13.6.2.2.3 The safe brake reaction time T_be_react and the safe brake build up time T_be shall 

--- Document Chunk 8354 ---
be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 8355 ---
If values of T_brake_emergency are acquired as part of Train Data: 

--- Document Chunk 8356 ---
T_be_react = T_brake_emergency_react, with T_brake_emergency_react 

--- Document Chunk 8357 ---
corresponding to the combination of special 

--- Document Chunk 8358 ---
brakes currently in use 

--- Document Chunk 8359 ---
T_be = T_brake_emergency , with T_brake_emergency corresponding to the 

--- Document Chunk 8360 ---
combination of special brakes currently in use 

--- Document Chunk 8361 ---
If the conversion model is used: 

--- Document Chunk 8362 ---
T_be_react = Kt_int * T_brake_emergency_react 

--- Document Chunk 8363 ---
T_be = Kt_int * T_brake_emergency 

--- Document Chunk 8364 ---
3.13.6.2.2.4 The safe brake build up reduced time T_be_reduced shall be obtained for every target 

--- Document Chunk 8365 ---
from T_be and T_be_react as defined in section A.3.12. 

--- Document Chunk 8366 ---
3.13.6.2.2.4.1 Note: Applying the Brake Build Up Time ramp model, it is possible that the predicted 

--- Document Chunk 8367 ---
train speed reaches standstill or decelerates under the target speed before T_be time 

--- Document Chunk 8368 ---
elapses. 

--- Document Chunk 8369 ---
3.13.6.3 Service brake 

--- Document Chunk 8370 ---
3.13.6.3.1 Expected deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 8371 ---
3.13.6.3.1.1 Since the expected deceleration is not safety relevant, no worst case conditions (e.g. 

--- Document Chunk 8372 ---
correction factors, adhesion conditions) need to be taken into account for its calculation. 

--- Document Chunk 8373 ---
3.13.6.3.1.2 The train and track related characteristics to be considered are: 

--- Document Chunk 8374 ---
a) The speed dependent deceleration model(s) for the full service brake either acquired 

--- Document Chunk 8375 ---
as part of Train Data (see 3.13.2.2.3.1) or derived from the brake percentage using 

--- Document Chunk 8376 ---
the conversion model (see 3.13.3.3) 

--- Document Chunk 8377 ---
b) The acceleration/deceleration due to gradient i.e. A_gradient(d) (see c)) 

--- Document Chunk 8378 ---
c) The locations without special brake contribution (see 3.13.5) 

--- Document Chunk 8379 ---
3.13.6.3.1.3 A_expected(V,d) shall be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 8380 ---
A_expected(V,d) = A_brake_service(V,d) +A_gradient(d) 

--- Document Chunk 8381 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 8382 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8383 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8384 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 8385 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 8386 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 8387 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 8388 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 8389 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 8390 ---
Page 138/252 

--- Document Chunk 8391 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8392 ---
3.13.6.3.1.4 A_brake_service(V,d) shall be the full deceleration of the service brake as a function 

--- Document Chunk 8393 ---
of the speed, of the locations with change of special brake(s) contribution encountered 

--- Document Chunk 8394 ---
between the train front and the foot of the SBD curve . A_brake_service(V,d) shall be 

--- Document Chunk 8395 ---
equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 8396 ---
A_brake_service1(V) when destfront ≤ d ≤ d1 

--- Document Chunk 8397 ---
A_brake_service2(V) when d1 < d ≤ d2 

--- Document Chunk 8398 ---
A_brake_service3(V) when d2 < d ≤ d3 

--- Document Chunk 8399 ---
.... 

--- Document Chunk 8400 ---
Where 

--- Document Chunk 8401 ---
d1, d2, d3,... are the locations with change of special brake(s) contribution 

--- Document Chunk 8402 ---
A_brake_servicex(V) is equal to the full service brake model, A_brake_service, 

--- Document Chunk 8403 ---
applicable for the concerned combination of brake. 

--- Document Chunk 8404 ---
3.13.6.3.2 Expected brake build up time 

--- Document Chunk 8405 ---
3.13.6.3.2.1 Since the expected brake build up time is not safety relevant, no worst case conditions 

--- Document Chunk 8406 ---
(e.g. correction factors, adhesion conditions ) need to be taken into account for its 

--- Document Chunk 8407 ---
calculation. 

--- Document Chunk 8408 ---
3.13.6.3.2.2 No track related characteristics are to be considered for the expected brake build up 

--- Document Chunk 8409 ---
time. 

--- Document Chunk 8410 ---
3.13.6.3.2.3 The train related characteristics to be considered are: 

--- Document Chunk 8411 ---
a) The values of T_brake_service_react and T_brake_service acquired as part of Train 

--- Document Chunk 8412 ---
Data (see 3.13.2.2.3.2.8) or the value (s) of T_brake_service_react and 

--- Document Chunk 8413 ---
T_brake_service derived from the conversion model  (see 3.13.3.4) using the brake 

--- Document Chunk 8414 ---
position and train length acquired as Train Data) 

--- Document Chunk 8415 ---
b) The status of the regenerative brake, eddy current brake and Ep brake system (see 

--- Document Chunk 8416 ---
3.13.2.2.6) 

--- Document Chunk 8417 ---
3.13.6.3.2.4 The expected brake reaction time T_bs_react and the expected brake build up time 

--- Document Chunk 8418 ---
T_bs shall be equal to the brake build up time of the full service brake: 

--- Document Chunk 8419 ---
T_bs_react = T_brake_service_react, with T_brake_service_react corresponding to the 

--- Document Chunk 8420 ---
combination of special brakes currently in use 

--- Document Chunk 8421 ---
T_bs = T_brake_service , with T_brake_service corresponding to the combination of 

--- Document Chunk 8422 ---
special brakes currently in use 

--- Document Chunk 8423 ---
3.13.6.3.2.5 If the service brake feedback is not available for use, the expected brake build up 

--- Document Chunk 8424 ---
reduced time T_bs_reduced shall be obtained for every target from T_bs as defined in 

--- Document Chunk 8425 ---
section A.3.12. Otherwise, T_bs_reduced shall be set to T_bs for every target. 

--- Document Chunk 8426 ---
3.13.6.3.2.5.1 Note: Applying the Brake Build Up Time ramp model, it is possible that the predicted 

--- Document Chunk 8427 ---
train speed reaches standstill or decelerates under the target speed before T_bs time 

--- Document Chunk 8428 ---
elapses. 

--- Document Chunk 8429 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

3.13.6.4 Normal service brake deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 8441 ---
3.13.6.4.1 Since the normal service brake deceleration is not safety relevant, no worst case 

--- Document Chunk 8442 ---
conditions (e.g. correction factors, adhesion conditions) need to be taken into account 

--- Document Chunk 8443 ---
for its calculation. 

--- Document Chunk 8444 ---
3.13.6.4.2 The train and track related characteristics to be considered are: 

--- Document Chunk 8445 ---
a) The speed dependent deceleration model(s) for the full service brake either acquired 

--- Document Chunk 8446 ---
as part of Train Data (see 3.13.2.2.3.1) or derived from the brake percentage using 

--- Document Chunk 8447 ---
the conversion model (see 3.13.3.3) 

--- Document Chunk 8448 ---
b) The speed dependent deceleration model(s) for the normal service brake acquired as 

--- Document Chunk 8449 ---
part of Train Data (see 3.13.2.2.3.1) 

--- Document Chunk 8450 ---
c) The acceleration/deceleration due to gradient i.e. A_gradient(d) (see c)) 

--- Document Chunk 8451 ---
d) The brake position (see 3.13.2.2.4) 

--- Document Chunk 8452 ---
e) The on-board correction factors Kn+(V) and Kn-(V) (see 3.13.2.2.9.2) 

--- Document Chunk 8453 ---
f) The locations without special brake contribution (see 3.13.5) 

--- Document Chunk 8454 ---
g) The gradient profile compensated in location according to the train length (see 

--- Document Chunk 8455 ---
3.13.4.2) 

--- Document Chunk 8456 ---
3.13.6.4.3 The normal service brake deceleration shall be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 8457 ---
For positive gradient values (uphill): 

--- Document Chunk 8458 ---
A_normal_service(V,d) = A_brake_normal_service(V,d) + A_gradient(d) – 

--- Document Chunk 8459 ---
Kn+(V)*grad(d)/1000 

--- Document Chunk 8460 ---
For negative gradient values (downhill): 

--- Document Chunk 8461 ---
A_normal_service(V,d) = A_brake_normal_service(V,d) + A_gradient(d) –  

--- Document Chunk 8462 ---
Kn-(V)*grad(d)/1000 

--- Document Chunk 8463 ---
Where 

--- Document Chunk 8464 ---
grad = gradient values in ‰ (positive = uphill) 

--- Document Chunk 8465 ---
3.13.6.4.4 A_brake_normal_service(V,d) shall be the normal deceleration of the service brake as a 

--- Document Chunk 8466 ---
function of the speed, of the locations with change of special brake(s) contribution 

--- Document Chunk 8467 ---
encountered between the train front and the foot of the GUI curve . 

--- Document Chunk 8468 ---
A_brake_normal_service(V,d) shall be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 8469 ---
A_brake_normal_service1(V) when destfront ≤ d ≤ d1 

--- Document Chunk 8470 ---
A_brake_normal_service2(V) when d1 < d ≤ d2 

--- Document Chunk 8471 ---
A_brake_normal_service3(V) when d2 < d ≤ d3 

--- Document Chunk 8472 ---
.... 

--- Document Chunk 8473 ---
Where 

--- Document Chunk 8474 ---
d1, d2, d3,... are the locations with change of special brake(s) contribution 

--- Document Chunk 8475 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 8476 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8477 ---

--- Document Chunk 8486 ---
A_brake_normal_servicex(V) is equal to the normal service brake model applicable for 

--- Document Chunk 8487 ---
the concerned combination of brake position and of the value of A_brake_service(V=0) 

--- Document Chunk 8488 ---
between dx-1 and dx (see 3.13.2.2.3.1.9 and 3.13.2.2.3.1.10). 

--- Document Chunk 8489 ---
3.13.7 Determination of Most Restrictive Speed Profile (MRSP) 

--- Document Chunk 8490 ---
3.13.7.1 The Most Restrictive Speed Profile (MRSP) is a description of the most restrictive speed 

--- Document Chunk 8491 ---
restrictions the train must obey on a given piece of track. 

--- Document Chunk 8492 ---
3.13.7.2 The Most Restrictive Speed Profile shall be derived from elements corresponding to all 

--- Document Chunk 8493 ---
speed restrictions (see 3.13.2.2.13 & 3.13.2.3.2), some elements being compensated by 

--- Document Chunk 8494 ---
the train length if requested by trackside (see 3.11.3.1.3 for SSP, 3.11.4.6 for ASP and 

--- Document Chunk 8495 ---
3.11.5.3 for TSR). To do so, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board shall continuously compute the 

--- Document Chunk 8496 ---
MRSP current speed (V_MRSP), which is the lowest speed of the MRSP elements 

--- Document Chunk 8497 ---
encountered between the min safe front end and the max safe front end of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 8498 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8499 ---
V 

--- Document Chunk 8500 ---
d 

--- Document Chunk 8501 ---
Speed Restriction categories 

--- Document Chunk 8502 ---
Most Restrictive Speed Profile (with L_DOUBTOVER & L_DOUBTUNDER = 0) 

--- Document Chunk 8503 ---
Train length 

--- Document Chunk 8504 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8505 ---
Figure 39: Most Restrictive Speed Profile selection 

--- Document Chunk 8506 ---
3.13.7.2.1 Note 1: The envelope of V_MRSP over a given piece of track travelled by the train forms 

--- Document Chunk 8507 ---
the MRSP. 

--- Document Chunk 8508 ---
3.13.7.2.2 Note 2: The MRSP as a whole cannot be computed in advance by the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 8509 ---
equipment, since the locations of its speed increases/decreases depend on the size of 

--- Document Chunk 8510 ---
the train position confidence interval at a given time/location. 

--- Document Chunk 8511 ---
3.13.8 Determination of targets and brake deceleration curves 

--- Document Chunk 8512 ---
3.13.8.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 8513 ---
3.13.8.1.1 A target is defined by a target location and a target speed, to which the train m ust 

--- Document Chunk 8514 ---
decelerate before reaching the target location. 

--- Document Chunk 8515 ---
3.13.8.1.2 For that purpose, the on-board equipment shall use brake deceleration curves related to 

--- Document Chunk 8516 ---
the supervised targets, from the deceleration values as specified in sections 3.13.6.2.1, 

--- Document Chunk 8517 ---
3.13.6.3.1and 3.13.6.3.2.5. 

--- Document Chunk 8518 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 8519 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8520 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8521 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 8522 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 8523 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 8524 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 8525 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 8526 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 8527 ---
Page 141/252 

--- Document Chunk 8528 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8529 ---
3.13.8.1.3 These deceleration values being speed and distance dependent, a brake deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 8530 ---
curve shall be calculated piecewise, i.e. it shall be composed of interconnected arcs of 

--- Document Chunk 8531 ---
parabola, each one being based on one of the speed/distance dependent deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 8532 ---
values (see Figure 38). 

--- Document Chunk 8533 ---
3.13.8.2 Determination of the supervised targets 

--- Document Chunk 8534 ---
3.13.8.2.1 The on-board shall continuously supervise a list of targets, which may include the 

--- Document Chunk 8535 ---
following types of target: 

--- Document Chunk 8536 ---
a) the start locations of the MRSP elements whose speed is lower than V_MRSP and  

--- Document Chunk 8537 ---
which are in advance of the max safe front end of the train 

--- Document Chunk 8538 ---
b) the Limit of Authority (LOA) 

--- Document Chunk 8539 ---
c) the End of Authority (EOA) and the Supervised Location (SvL) 

--- Document Chunk 8540 ---
d) the location deduced from the maximum permitted distance to run in Staff 

--- Document Chunk 8541 ---
Responsible, with a target speed zero 

--- Document Chunk 8542 ---
3.13.8.2.1.1 Note: depending on the information received from trackside and the position of the 

--- Document Chunk 8543 ---
train, the list of supervised targets may be empty. 

--- Document Chunk 8544 ---
3.13.8.2.2 The list of supervised targets shall be re-evaluated when any of the elements it is built of 

--- Document Chunk 8545 ---
is changed (e.g. new MA and/or track description accepted on -board, update of stored 

--- Document Chunk 8546 ---
information in specific situations (see sections A.3.4 and 4.10)). 

--- Document Chunk 8547 ---
3.13.8.2.3 A target corresponding to an MRSP element shall be removed from the list of supervised 

--- Document Chunk 8548 ---
targets when the max safe front end of the train has passed the target location. 

--- Document Chunk 8549 ---
3.13.8.3 Emergency Brake Deceleration curves (EBD) 

--- Document Chunk 8550 ---
3.13.8.3.1 If a target belongs to the MRSP or is an LOA, the on-board shall calculate an EBD curve 

--- Document Chunk 8551 ---
based on the safe deceleration A_safe(V,d), that crosses the ceiling speed EBI 

--- Document Chunk 8552 ---
supervision limit (see 3.13.9.2) at the target location, and that extends up to the location 

--- Document Chunk 8553 ---
where the target speed is reached (EBD foot). 

--- Document Chunk 8554 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 8555 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8556 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8557 ---

3.13.8.5 Guidance curves (GUI) 

--- Document Chunk 8628 ---
3.13.8.5.1 The purpose of the guidance curve (GUI) is to provide a comfortable way of braking for 

--- Document Chunk 8629 ---
the driver, to avoid excessive wear of the brakes and to save traction energy. 

--- Document Chunk 8630 ---
3.13.8.5.2 If the National Value does not inhibit them, the on-board shall calculate a guidance curve 

--- Document Chunk 8631 ---
(GUI) for each supervised target, based on the normal service brake deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 8632 ---
A_normal_service(V,d). The foot of a GUI curve (i.e. the location where the GUI speed 

--- Document Chunk 8633 ---
is equal to the target speed) shall be: 

--- Document Chunk 8634 ---
a) the target location, in case of EOA/SvL 

--- Document Chunk 8635 ---
b) the location defined in 3.13.9.3.5.9, for others targets 

--- Document Chunk 8636 ---
3.13.9 Supervision limits 

--- Document Chunk 8637 ---
3.13.9.1 Overview 

--- Document Chunk 8638 ---
3.13.9.1.1 In this chapter the following supervision limits are defined: 

--- Document Chunk 8639 ---
• Emergency brake intervention (EBI) 

--- Document Chunk 8640 ---
• Service brake intervention (SBI) 

--- Document Chunk 8641 ---
• Warning (W) 

--- Document Chunk 8642 ---
• Permitted speed (P) 

--- Document Chunk 8643 ---
• Indication (I) 

--- Document Chunk 8644 ---
• Release speed monitoring start location 

--- Document Chunk 8645 ---
3.13.9.1.2 The purpose of the emergency brake intervention supervision limit is to assure that the 

--- Document Chunk 8646 ---
train will remain within the various limits (in distance/speed) imposed by the trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 8647 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 8648 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8649 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8650 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 8651 ---
4.0.0 

--- Document Chunk 8652 ---
05/07/2023 

--- Document Chunk 8653 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 8654 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 8655 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 8656 ---
Page 144/252 

--- Document Chunk 8657 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8658 ---
3.13.9.1.3 The purpose of all other supervision limits is to assist the driver in preventing an 

--- Document Chunk 8659 ---
emergency brake intervention by maintaining the speed of the train within the appropriate 

--- Document Chunk 8660 ---
limits. 

--- Document Chunk 8661 ---
3.13.9.2 Ceiling supervision limits 

--- Document Chunk 8662 ---
3.13.9.2.1 The ceiling supervision limits are derived from the MRSP elements, where the speed is 

--- Document Chunk 8663 ---
constant (refer to 3.13.7) or from the LOA. 

--- Document Chunk 8664 ---
3.13.9.2.2 From an MRSP element or from the LOA, the Permitted speed, Warning, Service brake 

--- Document Chunk 8665 ---
intervention and Emergency brake intervention supervision limits are defined (see Figure 

--- Document Chunk 8666 ---
43). 

--- Document Chunk 8667 ---

--- Document Chunk 8709 ---

--- Document Chunk 8711 ---

--- Document Chunk 8712 ---
values (See Appendix A.3.1)

3.13.9.3.1.4 No specific supervision limit is calculated from the GUI curve: it is only used to adjust 

--- Document Chunk 8771 ---

--- Document Chunk 8772 ---
SBD curve. 

--- Document Chunk 8773 ---
3.13.9.3.2 EBI supervision limit 

--- Document Chunk 8774 ---
3.13.9.3.2.1 If not inhibited by N ational Value, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall  

--- Document Chunk 8775 ---
compensate the inaccuracy of the speed measurement by taking into account the speed 

--- Document Chunk 8776 ---
under reading amount (V_ura) at the moment when the calculation is made: V_delta0 = 

--- Document Chunk 8777 ---
V_ura (see Figure 45). 

--- Document Chunk 8778 ---
3.13.9.3.2.2 The time elapsed between the Emergency brake intervention and the full application 

--- Document Chunk 8779 ---
of the braking effort is reached (EBD) shall be split into two parts: 

--- Document Chunk 8780 ---
a) Time during which the traction effort is still present: T_traction 

--- Document Chunk 8781 ---
b) Remaining time during which the traction effort is not present: T_berem 

--- Document Chunk 8782 ---
3.13.9.3.2.3 The traction time (T_Traction) shall be defined as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 8783 ---
a) when the traction cut-off is implemented: 

--- Document Chunk 8784 ---
T_traction = MAX((T_traction_cut_off - (T_warning + T_bs2)) ; 0). 

--- Document Chunk 8785 ---
b) when the traction cut-off is not implemented: T_traction = T_traction_cut_off 

--- Document Chunk 8786 ---
3.13.9.3.2.4 Note: When the traction cut -off is implemented, the traction cut -off command is 

--- Document Chunk 8787 ---
triggered when passing the warning limit. The term (T_warning + T_bs2) in the equation 

--- Document Chunk 8788 ---
above takes this into account, assuming that the warning limit is derived from the EBD. 

--- Document Chunk 8789 ---
3.13.9.3.2.5 T_bs2 and T_warning are defined in sections 3.13.9.3.3 and 3.13.9.3.4. 

--- Document Chunk 8790 ---
3.13.9.3.2.6 The remaining time with no traction (T_berem) shall be equal to MAX(T_be_reduced 

--- Document Chunk 8791 ---
- T_traction ; 0). 

--- Document Chunk 8792 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 8793 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8794 ---

--- Document Chunk 8804 ---
3.13.9.3.2.8 During T_traction, the estimated acceleration (A_est1) shall be the one measured at 

--- Document Chunk 8805 ---
the moment when the calculation is made, but limited to positive or null values. 

--- Document Chunk 8806 ---
3.13.9.3.2.9 If T_be_reduced > T_traction, the estimated acceleration during T_berem (A_est2) 

--- Document Chunk 8807 ---
shall be the one measured at the moment when the calculation is made, but limited to 

--- Document Chunk 8808 ---
values between 0 and +0.4m/s2. 

--- Document Chunk 8809 ---

the Emergency brake intervention and the full application of the braking effort is reached

3.13.9.3.3 SBI supervision limit 

--- Document Chunk 8824 ---
3.13.9.3.3.1 For the EOA, the on -board shall calculate the location of the SBI supervision limit 

--- Document Chunk 8825 ---
(SBI1) valid for the e stimated speed, assuming that this latter remains constant during 

--- Document Chunk 8826 ---
the interval T_bs1, until the SBD curve is reached. 

--- Document Chunk 8827 ---
𝑑𝑆𝐵𝐼1(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)=𝑑𝑆𝐵𝐷(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)−𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡 ⋅𝑇𝑏𝑠1 

--- Document Chunk 8828 ---
3.13.9.3.3.2 For an EBD based target, the on -board shall calculate the location of the SBI 

--- Document Chunk 8829 ---
supervision limit (SBI2) valid for the estimated speed, assuming that this latter remains 

--- Document Chunk 8830 ---
constant during the interval T_bs2, until the location of the EBI supervision limit is 

--- Document Chunk 8831 ---
reached. 

--- Document Chunk 8832 ---
𝑑𝑆𝐵𝐼2(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)=𝑑𝐸𝐵𝐼(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)−𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡 ⋅𝑇𝑏𝑠2 

--- Document Chunk 8833 ---
3.13.9.3.3.3 If the service brake command is available for use and the service brake feedback is 

--- Document Chunk 8834 ---
not available for use, T_bs1 and T_bs2 shall be equal to T_bs_reduced. 

--- Document Chunk 8835 ---
3.13.9.3.3.4 If both the service brake command and the service brake feedback are available for 

--- Document Chunk 8836 ---
use, T_bs1 and T_bs2 shall by default be set to T_bs. When the service brake is used 

--- Document Chunk 8837 ---
by the driver  in target speed monitoring or release speed monitoring , they shall be 

--- Document Chunk 8838 ---
reduced and possibly locked to the respective fixed values of 0s and T_bs2_locked, until 

--- Document Chunk 8839 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

to zero.

performance when service brake command is not used.

3.13.9.3.3.8.1 Note: the re-use of the same distance travelled and speed increase between the SBI2 

--- Document Chunk 8916 ---
supervision limit and the EBD, as for the estimated speed (see Figure 48), leads to an 

--- Document Chunk 8917 ---
overestimation/underestimation of the SBI2 speed to be displayed to the driver. This 

--- Document Chunk 8918 ---
simplification, which avoids the need of an iterated calculation, is how ever acceptable 

--- Document Chunk 8919 ---
and necessary since the error made tends to zero when the train reaches the SBI2 

--- Document Chunk 8920 ---
supervision limit.

--- Document Chunk 8923 ---
3.13.9.3.4.1 The on-board shall calculate the location of the Warning supervision limit valid for the 

--- Document Chunk 8924 ---
estimated speed, assuming that this latter remains constant during the interval 

--- Document Chunk 8925 ---
T_warning until the location of the SBI1 (for the EOA) or the SBI2 (for an EBD based 

--- Document Chunk 8926 ---
target) supervision limit is reached. 

--- Document Chunk 8927 ---
𝑑𝑊(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)=𝑑𝑆𝐵𝐼1(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)−𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡 ⋅𝑇𝑤𝑎𝑟𝑛𝑖𝑛𝑔 for the EOA

3.13.9.3.5 Permitted speed supervision limit (P) 

--- Document Chunk 8942 ---
3.13.9.3.5.1 In case the calculation of the GUI curve is inhibited, the on -board shall calculate the 

--- Document Chunk 8943 ---
location of the Permitted speed supervision limit valid for the estimated speed, assuming 

--- Document Chunk 8944 ---
that this latter remains constant during the interval T_driver until the location of the SBI1 

--- Document Chunk 8945 ---
(for the EOA) or the SBI2 (for an EBD based target) supervision limit is reached. 

--- Document Chunk 8946 ---
𝑑𝑃(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)=𝑑𝑆𝐵𝐼1(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)−𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡 ⋅𝑇𝑑𝑟𝑖𝑣𝑒𝑟 for the EOA 

--- Document Chunk 8947 ---
𝑑𝑃(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)=𝑚𝑖𝑛{(𝑑𝑆𝐵𝐼2(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)−𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡 ⋅𝑇𝑑𝑟𝑖𝑣𝑒𝑟),𝑑𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑒𝑡} for an EBD based target 

--- Document Chunk 8948 ---
3.13.9.3.5.2 T_driver is defined as a fixed value (refer to A.3.1). 

--- Document Chunk 8949 ---
3.13.9.3.5.3 Note: The reference for the Permitted speed supervision limit is the SBI supervision 

--- Document Chunk 8950 ---
limit and not the Warning supervision limit. As a result the permitted and warning 

--- Document Chunk 8951 ---
supervision limits are clearly separated and do not affect each other. In this way it is clear 

--- Document Chunk 8952 ---
that the warning is not part of the critical performance interval. 

--- Document Chunk 8953 ---
3.13.9.3.5.4 In case the calculation of the Guidance curve is enabled, the on-board shall calculate 

--- Document Chunk 8954 ---
the location of the Permitted s peed supervision limit valid for the estimated speed, as 

--- Document Chunk 8955 ---
follows: 

--- Document Chunk 8956 ---
𝑑𝑃(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)=𝑚𝑖𝑛{(𝑑𝑆𝐵𝐼1(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)−𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡 ⋅𝑇𝑑𝑟𝑖𝑣𝑒𝑟),𝑑𝐺𝑈𝐼(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)}

--- Document Chunk 8957 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 8958 ---
for the EOA

--- Document Chunk 8959 ---
 𝑑𝑃(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)=𝑚𝑖𝑛{(𝑑𝑆𝐵𝐼2(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)−𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡 ⋅𝑇𝑑𝑟𝑖𝑣𝑒𝑟),𝑑𝐺𝑈𝐼(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)} for an EBD based target

--- Document Chunk 9061 ---
3.13.9.3.5.9 In order to determine the reference location of the target distance displayed to the 

--- Document Chunk 9062 ---
driver, in order to check whether the target is masking another one,  and in order to 

--- Document Chunk 9063 ---
determine the foot of the GUI curve (only if it is enabled) in case of target different from 

--- Document Chunk 9064 ---
EOA/SvL, the location of the Permitted speed supervision limit, valid for the target speed, 

--- Document Chunk 9065 ---
shall be calculated from the EBD, taking into account the following assumptions: 

--- Document Chunk 9066 ---
a) the estimated acceleration shall be set to “zero” 

--- Document Chunk 9067 ---
b) if not inhibited by National Value, the compensation of the inaccuracy of the speed 

--- Document Chunk 9068 ---
measurement shall be set to a value calculated from the target speed, as defined in 

--- Document Chunk 9069 ---
SUBSET-041 § 5.3.1.2: V_delta0t = f41(V_target) 

--- Document Chunk 9070 ---
c) the safe brake build up  time shall be considered to be fully reduced as per A.3.12 

--- Document Chunk 9071 ---
algorithm, i.e. it shall be set to 𝑇𝑏𝑒_𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑐𝑡 

--- Document Chunk 9072 ---
d) if the service brake command is available for use and the service brake feedback is 

--- Document Chunk 9073 ---
not available for use, the expected brake build up time shall be considered to be fully 

--- Document Chunk 9074 ---
reduced as per A.3.12 algorithm, i.e. it shall be set to 𝑇𝑏𝑠_𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑐𝑡 

--- Document Chunk 9075 ---
e) the above-mentioned location of the Permitted speed supervision limit shall not be 

--- Document Chunk 9076 ---
beyond the target location 

--- Document Chunk 9077 ---
3.13.9.3.5.10 To do so, the same formulas defined above with V_est and V_delta0 shall be applied, 

--- Document Chunk 9078 ---
by substituting V_est with V_target and V_delta0 with V_delta0t. 

--- Document Chunk 9079 ---
𝑑𝐸𝐵𝐼(𝑉𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑒𝑡)=𝑑𝐸𝐵𝐷(𝑉𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑒𝑡 +𝑉𝑑𝑒𝑙𝑡𝑎0𝑡)−(𝑉𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑒𝑡 +𝑉𝑑𝑒𝑙𝑡𝑎0𝑡)⋅(𝑇𝑏𝑒𝑟𝑒𝑚_𝑚𝑖𝑛 +𝑇𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑐𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛_𝑚𝑎𝑥) 

--- Document Chunk 9080 ---
𝑑𝑃(𝑉𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑒𝑡)=𝑀𝐼𝑁{𝑑𝐸𝐵𝐼(𝑉𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑒𝑡)−𝑉𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑒𝑡 ⋅(𝑇𝑑𝑟𝑖𝑣𝑒𝑟 +𝑇𝑏𝑠__𝑓𝑜𝑜𝑡),𝑑𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑒𝑡}

available for use and the service brake feedback is not available for use; otherwise set to 𝑇𝑏𝑠2 as 

--- Document Chunk 9086 ---

--- Document Chunk 9087 ---
3.13.9.3.5.10.1 Justification: the two first assumptions are intended to avoid fluctuations of the 

--- Document Chunk 9088 ---
target distance displayed to the driver. Moreover the foot of the GUI curve may influence 

--- Document Chunk 9089 ---
the p erturbation location, which must be full y predictable for trackside engineering 

--- Document Chunk 9090 ---
reasons.

--- Document Chunk 9100 ---

--- Document Chunk 9101 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9102 ---
The third and fourth assumptions are intended to consider the nominal operation, in 

--- Document Chunk 9103 ---
which the train speed follows the permitted speed, leading to the reduction of the needed 

--- Document Chunk 9104 ---
brake build up times to the minimum before the target location is reached. 

--- Document Chunk 9105 ---
The fifth assumption is to ensure that the permitted speed displayed to the driver, 

--- Document Chunk 9106 ---
considering the brake build up times reduction, is not higher than the target speed at the 

--- Document Chunk 9107 ---
target location. 

--- Document Chunk 9108 ---
3.13.9.3.5.11 In case a non protecte d LX start location is supervised as both temporary EOA and 

--- Document Chunk 9109 ---
SvL and the stopping in rear of LX is not required, the location of the most restrictive 

--- Document Chunk 9110 ---
Permitted speed supervision limit, valid for the LX speed shall be used in order to 

--- Document Chunk 9111 ---
determine the location where the supervision of the LX start location is substituted by the 

--- Document Chunk 9112 ---
supervision of the LX speed (see section 5.16.3). 

--- Document Chunk 9113 ---
3.13.9.3.5.12 To calculate this location , th e same formulas defined above with V_est shall be 

--- Document Chunk 9114 ---
applied by substituting V_est with V_LX.

--- Document Chunk 9133 ---
in the calculation of this location avoids a jump of display when the substitution takes 

--- Document Chunk 9134 ---
place. 

--- Document Chunk 9135 ---
3.13.9.3.6 Indication supervision limit (I) 

--- Document Chunk 9136 ---
3.13.9.3.6.1 The on-board shall calculate the location of the Indication supervision limit valid for 

--- Document Chunk 9137 ---
the estimated speed, assuming that this latter remains constant during the interval 

--- Document Chunk 9138 ---
T_indication until the location of the Permitted speed supervision limit is reached. 

--- Document Chunk 9139 ---
𝑑𝐼(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)=𝑑𝑃(𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡)−𝑉𝑒𝑠𝑡 ⋅𝑇𝑖𝑛𝑑𝑖𝑐𝑎𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛 

--- Document Chunk 9140 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 9147 ---

--- Document Chunk 9148 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 9149 ---
Page 154/252 

--- Document Chunk 9150 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 9151 ---
3.13.9.3.6.2 If the service brake feedback interface is not available for use, then T_indication shall 

--- Document Chunk 9152 ---
be calculated as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 9153 ---
𝑇𝑖𝑛𝑑𝑖𝑐𝑎𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛 =𝑚𝑎𝑥{(0.8⋅𝑇𝑏𝑠_𝑟𝑒𝑑𝑢𝑐𝑒𝑑),5𝑠}+𝑇𝑑𝑟𝑖𝑣𝑒𝑟 

--- Document Chunk 9154 ---
3.13.9.3.6.3 Note: The reduction of T_indication by a factor is intended to improve performance 

--- Document Chunk 9155 ---
and the feasibility of this reduction is based on experience with real implementations. To 

--- Document Chunk 9156 ---
avoid very low values when T_bs _reduced is small, a minimum is defined for 

--- Document Chunk 9157 ---
T_indication, giving the driver always enough time to operate the brake. 

--- Document Chunk 9158 ---
3.13.9.3.6.4 If the service brake feedback interface is available for use then T_indication shall be 

--- Document Chunk 9159 ---
equal to 5s + T_driver. 

--- Document Chunk 9160 ---
3.13.9.3.6.5 If available for use, the service brake  feedback shall not have any effect on T_bs1 

--- Document Chunk 9161 ---
and T_bs2 when calculating the Indication supervision limit: T_bs1 and T_bs2 shall be 

--- Document Chunk 9162 ---
set to T_bs in the formulas in 3.13.9.3.2 and 3.13.9.3.3. 

--- Document Chunk 9163 ---
3.13.9.3.6.6 Note 1: This avoids that service brake feedback, while braking to o ne target which 

--- Document Chunk 9164 ---
causes the full locking of T_bs1 and T_bs2 for all the targets, affects the Indication 

--- Document Chunk 9165 ---
supervision limit for another target(s). Otherwise, the indication to the driver could come 

--- Document Chunk 9166 ---
too late. It also avoids its influence on the acceptance criteria of request to shorten MA. 

--- Document Chunk 9167 ---
3.13.9.3.6.7 Note 2: If the service brake feedback is not available for use, T_bs1 and T_bs2 are 

--- Document Chunk 9168 ---
set either to T_bs or to zero, depending on the availability of the service brake command 

--- Document Chunk 9169 ---
(see 3.13.9.3.3.3 and 3.13.9.3.3.5). 

--- Document Chunk 9170 ---
3.13.9.4 Release speed supervision limits 

--- Document Chunk 9171 ---
3.13.9.4.1 The release speed is a special ceiling speed limit, applicable in the vicinity of the EOA. 

--- Document Chunk 9172 ---
The EBI supervision limit is equal to the release speed. There is no SBI, W, P, I 

--- Document Chunk 9173 ---
supervision limit associated to the release speed. 

--- Document Chunk 9174 ---
3.13.9.4.2 Note: The release speed may be necessary for two reasons. One is that a train has to 

--- Document Chunk 9175 ---
be able to approach the EOA where the permitted speed reaches zero and might be too 

--- Document Chunk 9176 ---
restrictive to permit acceptable driving due to inaccuracy of the measured distance. The 

--- Document Chunk 9177 ---
other reason is that in a level 1 application the train has to be able to overpass the balise 

--- Document Chunk 9178 ---
when the signal clears. For these two reasons a (low) release speed may be given from 

--- Document Chunk 9179 ---
trackside or may be calculated on board, based on the distance from the E OA to the 

--- Document Chunk 9180 ---
Supervised Location. 

--- Document Chunk 9181 ---
3.13.9.4.3 With each MA, it shall be possible for the trackside to: 

--- Document Chunk 9182 ---
a) Give the value of the release speed directly to the on-board, OR 

--- Document Chunk 9183 ---
b) Instruct the on-board to calculate the release speed, OR 

--- Document Chunk 9184 ---
c) Instruct the on-board to use the national value. 

--- Document Chunk 9185 ---
3.13.9.4.4 In case the MA does not identify the variant to be used or in case of LOA, no release 

--- Document Chunk 9186 ---
speed shall be supervised. 

--- Document Chunk 9187 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 9188 ---

--- Document Chunk 9198 ---
3.13.9.4.5 Note: When the release speed is given as a fixed value from trackside, the ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 9199 ---
system cannot be responsible for stopping the train in rear of the S upervised Location. 

--- Document Chunk 9200 ---
In this case, it is the full responsibility of the infrastructure manager to set the appropriate 

--- Document Chunk 9201 ---
release speed with regard to the risk of passing the Supervised Location. 

--- Document Chunk 9202 ---
3.13.9.4.6 The start location of the release speed monitoring (i.e. where th e EBI supervision limit 

--- Document Chunk 9203 ---
related to EBD is replaced with an EBI supervision limit equal to the release speed value) 

--- Document Chunk 9204 ---
shall be the location of the most restrictive SBI supervision limit among the SBI1 related 

--- Document Chunk 9205 ---
to EOA, the SBI2 related to SvL and , when the Release Speed is calculated on-board, 

--- Document Chunk 9206 ---
the SBI2 supervision limit(s) related to other target(s), if any, between the Trip location 

--- Document Chunk 9207 ---
related to the EOA (see d_tripEOA in 3.13.9.4.8.2) and the SvL, calculated for the 

--- Document Chunk 9208 ---
Release Speed value, taking into account the following assumptions: 

--- Document Chunk 9209 ---
a) the estimated acceleration shall be set to “zero” 

--- Document Chunk 9210 ---
b) if not inhibited by National Value, the compensation of the inaccuracy of the speed 

--- Document Chunk 9211 ---
measurement shall be set to a value calculated from the release speed, as defined in 

--- Document Chunk 9212 ---
SUBSET-041 § 5.3.1.2: V_delta0rs = f41(V_release) 

--- Document Chunk 9213 ---
3.13.9.4.7 To do so, the same formulas defined above with V_est and V_ delta0 shall be applied, 

--- Document Chunk 9214 ---
by substituting V_est with V_release and V_delta0 with V_delta0rs. 

--- Document Chunk 9215 ---

3.13.9.4.8 When the Release Speed is calculated on-board (Figure 51/51a box 3), its value shall 

--- Document Chunk 9256 ---
be equal to the most restrictive value, at the Trip location related to the EOA  (see 

--- Document Chunk 9257 ---
d_tripEOA in 3.13.9.4.8.2) plus (only in level 1) a distance in advance taking into account 

--- Document Chunk 9258 ---
the maximum delay to apply the emergency brake when passing an EOA , amongst the 

--- Document Chunk 9259 ---
EBI supervision limit related to the SvL ( Figure 51/51a box 1) and, if any, the EBI 

--- Document Chunk 9260 ---
supervision limits(s) related to other target(s) between the Trip location related to the 

--- Document Chunk 9261 ---
EOA (see d_tripEOA in 3.13.9.4.8.2) and the SvL (Figure 51/51a box 2).

3.13.9.4.8.1 In order to calculate in advance the EBI supervision limit (s) referred to in 3.13.9.4.8, 

--- Document Chunk 9329 ---
the on-board equipment shall take into account an estimated acceleration set to “zero”. 

--- Document Chunk 9330 ---

--- Document Chunk 9331 ---
release speed value which satisfies the two following inequalities: 

--- Document Chunk 9332 ---

--- Document Chunk 9365 ---
